OF ARTHOUR AND OF MERLIN AUCHINLECK MS. Paragraphs in this text are signified by markers. The paragraphs have been captured, but the markers ignored. Square brackets denote editorial insertions or emendations. Ihesu Crist Heuen-king Al ous graunt gode ending And seynt Marie þat swete þing So be at our bigining And help ous at our nede, And leue ous wele to spede Þat we habbeþ euer to don, And scheld ous fram our fon. Childer þat ben to boke ysett In age hem is miche þe bett For þai mo witen and se Miche of Godes priuete Hem to kepe and to ware Fram sinne and fram warldes care, And wele ysen ?if þai willen Þat hem no þarf neuer spillen— Auauntages þai hauen þare Freynsch and Latin eueraywhare. Of Freynsch no Latin nil y tel more Ac on I[n]glisch ichil tel þerfore: Ri?t is þat I[n]glische vnderstond Þat was born in Inglond. Freynsche vse þis gentil man Ac euerich Inglische Inglische can, Mani noble ich haue ysei?e Þat no Freynsche couþe seye, Biginne ichil for her loue Bi Ihesus leue þat sitt aboue On Inglische tel mi tale— God ous sende soule hale. Now ich ?ou telle þis romaunce: A king hi?t while sir Costaunce Þat regned in Inglond. Mani A section of the ms. is missing here (the reverse of an excised miniature). H O H A Þ N H Costaunce Þat oþer broþer name was Sir Aurilis Brosias, Þe þridde broþer of gret renoun Was cleped Vter Pendra[g]oun. Ac þe eldest sone Costentine Was noble clerk and wise afine He loued God and holy chirche And holy werkes forto wirche Forþi he bisou?t his fader dere Þat him graunted his prayer Þat he most monke be At Vinchester in þat gode cite, And maki Brosias his broþer Or Pendragoun king and no noþer; Þe king was loþ graunti þertille Ac noþeles to?ain his owen wille At Winchester he was monke ymade Wiþouten his fader þe kinges rade. Sone after as ich finde in boke A gret sikenes þe king him toke Þat out of þis warld he most wende. After his barouns he gan sende And when þai were ycomen ichon Þe king seyd to hem anon ‘Lordinges’ he seyd ‘lesse and mare Out of þis warld y most fare Þerfore y pray for loue o me For Godes loue and for charite When ich am dede and roten in clay Helpeþ mi childer þat ?e may And takeþ Costaunt mi neldest sone And ?if him boþe reng and crone And holdeþ him for ?our lord euer mo.’ Al þay graunt it schuld be so. Þan hadde þis king as ?e may here A steward þat hi?t Fortiger Strong he was and wi?t ywis, Fals and ful of couaitise. Þe king he hadde yserued long And for he was so wi?t and strong In him was al his trust at nede And ?aue him boþe lond and lede To help his childer after his day And oftsiþes he gan him pray To gouerny hem wiþ al his mi?t His treuþe he dede him forto pli?t (And when þe king hadde his liif forlore Sone þat traitour was forswore And wiþ gret tresoun brak his treuþe And dede hem wrong and þat was reuþe). Out of þis world þe king went And was ybiried verrament— At Winchester wiþouten les Þer þat king bigrauen wes. Erls and barouns euerichon Token hem to red anon Wiþouten ani more duelling And made Costaunce her king And for þat he was monke þore King Moyne men cleped him euer more, Ac þe steward sir Fortiger Was wel wroþ in his maner And wiþ al his mi?t was þero?ain As fer forþ as he durst sayn. King Angys sone herd it telle He gadred him folk wel felle Of Danmark and of Sessoyne Forto wer o?aines Moyne, He filled ful mani dromouns Of kinges erls and barouns Vp þai sett sail and mast And into Inglond com an hast (Ac Inglond was yhoten þo Michel Breteyne wiþouten no). Þe Bretouns þat beþ Inglisse nov Herd telle when he com and hou Þat Angys bi water brou?t; Þe king Fortiger bisou?t He schuld afong his pouwer And be steward as he was er And help him bi day and ni?t O?ain his fomen forto fi?t, He it forsoke and seyd he nold Noiþer for siluer no for gold And feined him þat he no mi?t At batayle com forto fi?t— And al he it dede for traisoun King to be was his achesoun. Angys was riued wiþ mani a man King Moyne went him o?an, Þo he come þider wiþouten faile Sone was smiten þe batayle Þer was broken spere and scheld And mani a kni?t of hors yfeld Ac our men and king Moyne Were ouercomen wiþouten asoine, To Winchester þai flowen þo Wiþ mani si?hing and walewo Þat swiche a slei?ster wiþ hond Was fallen into Inglond— Þer was mani kni?t yslawe And mani swain ybrou?t of dawe. Angis tok in a þrowe Mani castels and tounes arowe And put þerin his men Forto stonden our o?en And sent after eld and ?ing Forto help in his fi?ting. Þo were fel kinges in lond Þat Costaunce wan vnder his hond, Mani of hem so weren þare Of þat descomfite hadden care And oft Ihesu Crist hye bisou?t He schuld hem help as he hem bou?t And hem bring out of her care After þat þai worþi ware. On a day as y ?ou telle Our princes speken wordes felle And seyd þat her king Nas bot a breþeling, ?if Fortiger her prince ware ‘No hadde we nou?t hadde so miche care,’ Þai hadden leuer þan ani þing Þat he were chosen to her king— In her witt þai vnderstode Þat it were so in his mode Her king to ben himselue. To him þerfore þai sent tvelue (Wisest þai chosen of þat lond) Þat schuld wele his hert fond Why he nold wiþ hem come So he tofore was ywone. Þis tvelue to him come So þe conseil was ynome, Wiþ grete honour and him gret And he hem badde bi him site— What he desired forto ben Bi his answere þai schuld ysen. He asked hem wat was her wille And þai him seyd tidinges ille Angys hem hadde ouercome And michel of her lond binome And mani barouns and kni?t yslawe And her kin brou?t of dawe, Þerfore þe conseyl of þe lond Bad he schuld don his hond Þis ich wo amende raþe Þat þai no hadde no more scaþe. Þo bispak him Fortiger Gode kni?t hardi—and pautener ‘Y nam noiþer ?our douke no king Whi aske ?e me conseiling? King Costauns y was to swore Euer y was ?ou þo tofore And wered ?ou wiþ mi power Wide and side fer and ner, Wiþ me nis it nou?t nov so Þerfore to ?our king ?e go Biseche him he ?ou socour And ?e wil him þan honour.’ Þan bispac to him a baroun ‘Sir our king is bot a conioun Þo he sei?e swerdes drawe To fle sone he was wel fawe He no can conseil to no gode He is so adrad he is nei?e wode. Whiles þou were in our þrome No were we neuer ouercome, Þat we forlorn at þis asaut Al we wite it þi defaut— So siggeþ al our pers.’ ‘Y leue wele’ quaþ Fortigers ‘Nil ich me noþing auentour To purchas a fole gret honour— ?if Moyne ?our king ded ware Ich wald ?ou help out of care.’ ‘Sir’ þai seyd to him þo ‘Wiltow þat we Moyne slo?’ ‘Nay ac goþ fro me bliue— While ich wot he is oliue Conseyl worþ ?ou of me non.’ Þe barouns þennes gan gon To take her king þai wenten alle And founden king Moyne in his halle Þer he sat at his mete On him þai schoten wiþ gret hete And smiten of his heued wiþ a sword Er þai spoken ani word And who so struted o?ainward Anon þai ?auen hem dintes hard, Out atte þe dore þai flowen anon And ascaped euerichon. Þerfore was contek and striif And mani it abou?t wiþ þe liif Ac seþþen þe king yslawe was And opon hem fallen swiche a cas A king þai mosten haue swiþe Al her sorwe forto liþe And þat he mi?t hem were þan O?ain Angys þat douhti man. And þan Vter Pendragon Armes mi?t bere non No Aurilis Brosias is broþer Þan þai most chese anoþer, Whereþurth þai seyd in þat nede Wele no mi?t þai nou?t spede Bot ?iue þai wold Fortiger Chese to her king þere; Nou?t fele nar þero?en Ac seyden þat it most ben, What for loue what for ay Non no durst o?ain say Ac þer þai chosen old and ?ing Fortiger to ben her king. Mirie time is Auerille Þan scheweþ michel of our wille In feld and mede floures springeþ In grene wode foules singeþ ?ong man wexeþ iolif And þan proudeþ man and wiif. Þe barouns com to Fortiger And gretten him wiþ glad cher And seyd þat her solas Þurth wicked men ylorn was Þat was Moyne her king, And his breþer were to ?ing, ‘And for we ?ou witeþ wi?t and trest (Of al men ?e mowen best Vs kepen o?ain our fon So ?e han er þis ydon) We haue ?ou chosen our king And ?ouen ?ou boþe croun and ring— Þe hei?e siggeþ and þe lowe also It mi?t no better ben ydo.’ ‘[N]ow gramerci’ quaþ Fortiger And was made king wiþouten daunger, Ac at his corounment To barouns þer weren gent Þat þis tresoun vnderstode And sore hem rewe þe kinges blod Þat it schuld be spilt so And tok rede bitvixen hem to Þe to childer ouer þe se bring And went hem forþ wiþouten lesing, No man wist of her conseyle Bot þai alon wiþouten faile. Þe king held fest noble and gent And afterward his parlement In wiche parlement he hete Men schuld him bring þe children skete, Þai were sou?t and founde hem nou?t Þo he held him iuel bicou?t Þo Fortiger it vnderstode For wreþe he wex nei?e wode— It was no wonder forsoþe to say For þai dede him after gret tray. Fortiger al þis forlete, Princes doukes also skete Fre and bond swain and kni?t Alle graiþed hem to fi?t Þat þai mi?ten flemen Angys And al her dedlich enemis, So þai deden wiþouten no And were al redi forþ to go O?aines her foman Angys Sum on gode hors of priis Sum on palfray and on stede And sum on fot ful gode at nede Wiþ arwe and bowe and alblast Her fomen forto agast. Þai wenten forþ and met Angys Wiþ mani Sarra?in of priis, Þer was mani arwe yschote And mani quarel þurth þe þrote Schaft tobroken and cleued scheld Mani a kni?t feld in þe feld Helme tobroken hauberk torent Mani noble hors yschent, Ac our men þer dede ful wel Wiþ broun swerd of grounden stiel Mani a riche Sarra?in Þai brou?ten into helle-pin. Angys sei?e his del þe wors And gan to fle wel swiþe on hors To a castel wel strong about Where was michel of his rout, Þo þat he left bihinden him Hadde chaunce hard and grim No halp hem noiþer pes no crie No fi?ting no criing ‘Merci!’ Al men maden her acord Wiþ axes speres kniif and sword, Al þat were bihinde yfounde Anon þai were leyd to grounde No mi?t þer askape neuer on Þat he nas to deþ ydon, Þus our folk hadden þe priis And went þo to bisege Angys. Þo þai hadde him long bilay Angys sent hem þan to say ?if he in pays wende most He wold taken al his ost And leden hem to his cuntraye And neuer eft don hem traye, Fortiger bi his conseyle Lete hem wende hole and hayle (Ac ferst þai sworen him an oþ Þai schuld him neuer waite loþ) Þus þai wenten to þe strond And ferden ouer to her lond. Fortiger and his ost O?ain com wiþ gret bost And held fest mani a day Of gret delite and noble play. When þis fest was don and held Þe xii traitours þat y of teld Þat hadde yslawe Moyne þe king Biþou?t hem of a selcouþe þing Þai wold go to Fortiger And asken him her lower Of þe king þat was yslawe Wiþ tresoun o?ain þe lawe, And seyden ‘King þou art aboue Þenke what we dede for þi loue We slou? our lord kende, Nov be sen ?if þou art hende Þurth ous þou art in þi power ?if ous now our lower.’ Þan bispac him Fortiger Anon to hem wiþ loureand chere ‘Bi þe lower þat God made ?e schul haue þat ?e bade So ich euer mot ythe So no schul ?e nou?t serue me For ?e han ?our lord yslawe ?e schul ben honged and todrawe’ He dede feche hors wel sket And teyed hem to her fet And dede hem drawe on þe pauement And hong hem after verrament. Mani kni?t and baroun hende Sei?en þis of her kende Opon þe king þai ourn anon As his dedliche fon Ac bitven hem stode his men Stedfastliche o?aines hem, Þer was mani heued of hitt Þer was mani þrote ykitt Mani hert forles his blod And mani þe bal vp in þe hod, Vnneþe þat ich day Þe king ascaped oway. Þe barouns went þat ich ni?t Toward her frendes ful ri?t And her gref anon hem teld Hou Fortiger her king aqueld Þurth tresoun þat [he] hadde yspeken, Of him þai wald ben awreken, Ich his frendes so bisou?t Þat opon Fortiger þai brou?t Mani erl baroun and kni?t Hardy and kene forto fi?t, Þai fou?ten wiþ Fortiger Mani moneþ and mani a ?ere Wherþurth mani a leuedi fre Her lord les and fair meyne. Fortiger nam gode coure Þat he no mi?t o?ain hem doure For þai wexen mo and mo And his men lassed alway þo, Letters he made to Angys þe welp And bad he schuld cum him to help O?aines his men þat wald him sle And he schuld haue half his fe; Angys þerof was bliþe His message he dede swiþe Mani þousand he tok wiþ him Þat were boþe stout and grim And comen ouer to Fortiger, And he hem welcomed wiþ glad chere Of his couenaunt he was biknawe And made Angys half-felawe Þat he hadde or haue mi?t Wiþ þat he schuld him help in fi?t, O?aines his men and help him were Þat were abouten, him to dere. Þis couenaunt was made stedfast And hem grayþed sone on hast To batayle forto wende, For þe barouns were hende Bi Salesbiri biside a lite Al redi bataile to smite And abiden her fomen Þat þider comen hem o?en. Þer was sone leyd adoun Mani wel bri?t gonfaynoun Þe schaftes tobroken and cloþ torent And mani a gret lording yschent Mani kni?t oþer slou? Mani hors her guttes drou?— Ich ?ou sigge ri?t treuþe Non of oþer hadde reuþe. Swerdes on helmes gan driue Mani schaft þer gan riue Mani hauberk was torent And mani þurth þe bodi schent Þer was slawe and brou?t to grounde Mani man in litel stounde A boþe half lay mani on Þe heued fro þe nek-bon Wombe and side þurthout dast Wiþ launce quarel and alblast Þat mani leuedi and damisele Biwepe it seþþen wit teres fele, Ac Fortiger hade euer four O?ain on forsoþe of our Forwhi þe barouns no mi?t Wiþstond in þat fi?t Ac gun fle wel fast þenne Sum ouer se to her kenne Sum for gret ay?e and dout To oþer kinges flowen about Also we finden in þe bok Al þat Fortiger atok He let todrawe and anhong Were it wiþ ri?t oþer wiþ wrong Þe oþer he devoided alle Of lond and tour castel and halle And bi conseyl of Angys ?aue it to Sarra?ins of pris— Þer was loue of hert cler Bitven Angys and Fortiger. Angys hadde verrament A douhter boþe fair and gent (Ac sche was heþen Sarra?in) And Fortiger for loue fin Hir tok to fere and to wiue— And was curssed in al his liue For he lete Cristen wedde haþen And meynt our blod as flesche and maþen. Mani þousand was swiche in weddeloc As we finde writen in bok Þer was wel nei?e al þis lond To þe Deuel gon an hond, Festes he made gret and fele And hadden al warldes wele And held no better lawe Þan þe hounde wiþ his felawe. Þis last wel fel ?ere; On a day sat Fortiger And biþou?t him of þe children to Þat ouer see weren ygo And of mani noble he nam ?eme Þat he hadde yboden flem, Of afterclap he hadde care Þat he schuld forfare. He hete chese carpenters Oueral in his powers And masouns þat þai no lete To him þai schuld comen sket, His hest was sone ydon Þousandes þer were anon Wiþ her tole swiþe prest Forto do þe kinges hest, Þe king hem gan fair to calle And þus he seyd to hem alle: ‘Listneþ now hei?e and lawe And vnderstond to mi sawe In mi witt ich haue yþou?t Ichil a castel han ywrou?t Of wode and lime morter and ston Þat swiche be in þis world non Þat ?if me comeþ ani nede Ich may me þere were and hede Fro min fon þat aires hem claim, At Salesbiri opon þe plain Þat ?e schul yfond To maken wiþ ?our hond Loke þat trewe and ston be riche Þe tour largge and depe þe diche, Mi deuise ich haue ysade Now hei?eþ ?ou þat it war made And ?e schullen haue hire Al þat ?e wil desire. Þis werkemen þider went þo (Þre þousand þer were and mo) Hewen schides and coruen ston And laiden foundement anon Sum rammed and doluen snel And gun þat castel fair and wel. Þat folk was boþe swift and slei?e Þat werk was arered brest-hei?e Þat ich day alle aboute So it is writen in þe brout, And wenten hom þo it was ni?t So it is werkmennes ri?t And comen al o?ain amorwe And sei?en þing of gret sorwe Foundement and werk þai founde Ligge vp so doun op þe grounde Sprad it was al abrod, For wonder þai were nei?e wode Ac her werk þai bigonne So long so þai sei?en þe sonne And als wele spedden par ma fay So þai deden þat oþer day, Ac þo þai come þider eft Her werk was al vp aleft And yschatred here and þere— Þus it ferd wele half a ?er Al þat euer þai wrou?t o day Amorwe it ouerþrowe lay. Þe king herd telle þis And gret wonder hadde ywis He dede aspie bi day and ni?t What þing hem lett mi?t Ac wite no mi?t lewed no clerk What þing felled her werk. Fortiger sat in his halle Among his kni?tes and barouns alle He bat his fest and his elbowe And seyd to hem wiþ michel howe— Wretþefulliche þere he hete Clerkes biforn him bring skete Þe best þat were in þis lond. Sone was don þe kinges sond Mani clerk was ful wide ysou?t And biforn him sone ybrou?t, Hem he aposed on and alle Whi his werk was so yfalle Her non no couþe him telle, Þe king swore he wold hem quelle Bot ?if þai wold him telle an hond Whi þat his werk mi?t nou?t stond. Ten þer were of hem ynome Wisest clerkes of þe þrome And in o chaumber ydo Þat no man most hem com to For þe hest of þe king Bot vnneþe her mete bring Astromiens þese weren Wiser neuer non neren. Þai were ix days bischet Ac ?ete þai couþe litel þe bet Bot ich ?ou sigge verrament Þai sey?en in þe firmament A child in erþe bi?eten wes Wiþouten ani mannes flesche, And þo þai com þe king bifore Þai seyd a child on erþe was bore Wiþouten mannes bi?eteing Þat wist wel nei?e al þing ‘Do him sle wel sodanliche Þe blod to þe is tresore riche Were ?our werk ysmerd þerwiþ Euer it wold stond in griþ.’ Þe king was of þis tale bliþe And dede priueliche xii swiþe (Þat were departed þre and þre) To wende about þat childe to sle ?iue þai him our finde mi?t Þai no schuld lete for wrong no ri?t Þat þai schuld sodeinliche Smite of his heued hastiliche And no word no speke him to— Þus bad him þis clerkes do For þai wende it were to her lere ?if þat child ?eue answere. Þis men on þe kinges sond Went a four half Inglond Þre and þre bi four way Þat child to finde y ?ou say; Þis clerkes of whom ich teld Wiþ þe king weren atheld Forto wite ?if it soþe were Þat þai hadde him seyd þere— ?if he founde wiþ hem lesing Her liif were at þe ending. Lete we þis clerk bihinde, Þis xii went þe child to finde, And are ich telle more ?ou Of þis romaunce, y wil now Þat ?e vnderstond and wite Hou þis child was bi?ete On swiche maner and what he hete, Now y pray ?ou listen skete. He þat was and is and ay schal ben Chese him here a swete quen In whom he nam flesche and bl[o]d Wiþ wiche he bou?t ous on þe rode Whareþurth we ben to heuen ycorn And þe Deuel his mi?t forlorn, Blisced be he in euerich song And Mari of whom he sprong. Listneþ wele to mi steuen— Þe deuels þat fel out of heuen Wiþ her pride Lucifer Sum fel to helle-fer, Sum in water sum in lond Sum in þe aire gan wiþstond Al fort our Dri?t seyd ‘Ho!’— So þai bileued euer mo, And forsoþe þai han power Man to dere þere and here. Y nil ?ou telle her priuete Bot þat longeþ now to me: Þe deuelen þat houen abouen ous Euer be luxsorius And oþerwhile makeþ hem body Of þe aire wel gent and rody And hauen mi?t and power Doun to li?t and derien her Al þo þat nillen wirche Godes comandment in chirche, Ac whilom more þan now For þurth þe mi?t of swete Ihesu Mani of hem yfelled is— Al hou y no may nou?t tellen ywis Mi matery wer to long And þe tale to ?ou wel strong. Ac þe deuelen of whom y said Sei?e hou Ihesu of a maide Þurth his milce was ybore And bou?t al þat was forlore, Þerto þai hadden gret ond And sayd þat þai wolden fond To ligge bi a maidenkin And bi?eten a child her in Swiche schuld acomber also fele So þat oþer had brou?t to wele. Bi þat day was a riche man Þat hadde to wiue a fair wiman Bi whom he hadde a sone fre And wel fair douhtren þre; A forseyd deuel li?t adoun And of þat wiif made a conioun To don alle his volunte Wharþurth in hem he had entre And brou?t hem in chideing and fi?t And made hem oft wroþ ypli?t So þat on an euen late Þe Deuel sche tau?t hir bi?ate; Þat ich ni?t þe deuel com And strangled hir owhen grom, Þe wiif hir sone sei?e ded amorwe Anon sche heng hirself for sorwe, Þo þat þe bounde ysei?e þis Anon he starf for diol ywis— Lo what wo and diol and dere Dede wretþe and foule answere! Al þe men ich ?ou say Þat woned in þat cuntray Hereof hadden gret pite Boþe vplond and in cite For þat man and eke his wiif Were yholden of gode liif. Biside þer woned an ermite Þat þider com þis to visite, Blasy ywis his name was, Þo he sei?e þis he seyd ‘Allas!’ And seyd it was verrament Þe Deuels foule encumbrement. Þre douhtern he fonde oliue And he hem dede ?ern schriue Of alle þat he couþe enserche Þurth þe lore of holy chirche And penaunce on hem layd For þat þai hadde God ytrayd And tau?t hem to serue God almi?t, And þo he went hom ful ri?t; Þis fair maidens þre Serued God wiþ hert fre In grete drede and loue. Þe deuel þat com fro aboue (He þat was fram heuen yfalle of whom y spac tofor ?ou alle) Þo he nam lickenisse of man And com him to an old wiman And bihete hir ?iftes and grete fe To wende to þis sostren þre And þe heldest to bichaunte ?ong mannes loue forto haunte. In þis lond was þo vsage Who so dede wiþ man vtrage Bot it were in wedloc In þilke time men hem tok Wiþ iuggement wiþouten les And also quic doluen hes, Bot sche hir knewe for li?t woman And comoun hore to alle men— Þan was it ri?t and lawe Þat sche no schuld ben yslawe. Þis eld wiif—þat ieul sche þe!— Com to þis sostren þre And made wailing and michel fare For þis þre maidens care, To þe eldest soster sche seyd ‘Wolewo mi swete maide Þou hast fair fot and hond And gentil viis bi Godes sond White hond and long arm, Certes it were michel harm Bot þi bodi most asay Wiþ som gentil ?ong man to play Þat þe mi?t in þis cas Finde þe ioie and solas.’ Þe maiden seyd ‘?iue so dede ic Y schuld be doluen also quic.’ ‘Nay certes’ quaþ þat eld quen ‘Þou mi?t it do wiþouten den ?er and oþer in þi bedde And þan þe wil þat ?ong man wedde.’ Þurth þis quen verrament And þe fendes enticement Þe eldest soster y ?ou say A ?ong man lete wiþ hir play, Ac þo hir liked alder best Hir gamen com al to chest For sche was nome and forþ ydrawe And of hir dede sche was biknowe, Þurth iuggement doluen sche was. Mani man seyd ‘Allas allas!’ For her and for her elderlinges Men made gret diol and wepeinges. ?ete wald þe deuel ful of ond Þe midel soster agile fond And brou?t hir vp a ?ong man Wiche þat wowen hir bigan Al his wille don him sche lete, And it was aperceiued skete Sche was brou?t bifor iustise Deþ to þoly in al wise— Sche seyd sche was a li?t woman And comoun hore to alle man. Of þat chaunce mani nam kepe And wiþ ei?en sore wepe For ribaudye gret haras Tofolwe[d] hir bodi—allas Þat þe Fende haþ swiche pouwer To deri þat God bou?t so dere! Þe þridde soster was so wo Hir þou?t hir hert brast atvo— Hir moder was ded acurssedliche And hir fader starf reuliche And hir broþer yslawe also And hir soster quic doluen þo Hir oþer soster hore strong Þat al harlotes ?ede among. In wanhope sche fel nei?e Ac þurth Godes help an hei?e Sche hir biþou?t of þermite Þat hem com to visite To him sche went þo bliue And hir schrof of hir liue And alle þe chaunces teld also Þat hir kin were comen to; Þis hermite hadde wonder gret And hir tau?t boþe and hete Haue euer Crist in mende And lete þe lores of þe Fende Pride wratþe and glotonie Niþe sleuþe and lecherie Couaitise and trecherie Bacbiteing and envie Swiche þinges he bad hir flen And gode and bonair forto ben, Alle þe werkes þat gode ware To don he hir tau?t þare And þat sche nere so michel ape Þat sche hir laid doun to slape Ar hir dore and hir fenester Hadde yblisced and ich ester— Þus he tau?t hir to done And þo sche went hir hom sone. Þe deuel hereof hadde ond Þat hir to gile wold he fond Þurth hi[r] soster ich ?ou telle Þat was his in flesche and felle. Þis hore com opon a day To hir soster par ma fay And to hir soster sche gan sigge Þat sche it schuld dere abigge Þat sche hadde hir hiritage, And ran to hir in gret rage Wiþ herlotes þat wiþ hir ware And sore bete þat wenche þare; Into a chaumber sche ran hir þo And fast schett þe dore hir to, Out sche gradde and nei?ebours come And driuen oway þis wreches sone. Þis sely þing was al day wroþ Hir owen liif was hir loþ On hir bed þo it was ni?t Al ycloþed sche fel doun ri?t And sche for?at hir vnblisced So þe hermite hir hadde ywissed, For wretþe sche þou?t of blisseing non And fel on slepe sone anon. Þe fende herof was ful bliþe To hir he com þan swiþe Ouer alle hir chaumber in he mi?t For þer nas no merk of our Dri?t, To þis maiden sikerliche He com þo and lay flescheliche. Þis maiden sone þat hye awaked Feld hir legges al naked And feled also bi her þi Þat sche was yleyen bi, Sche ros and fond hir dore loke And noþing no was tobroke, Sche þou?t it was þe Foule Wi?t þo Sche was aferd, sche nist wat to do, Hirselue sche bete and gan to tere Wiþ boþe honden hir ?alu here And wepe al ni?t wiþ gret sorwe. To þermite sche went amorwe And told him al þe cas, He was sori and seyd, allas For sche no held nou?t hir penance Sche was fallen in encombraunce, ‘Allas sir’ sche seyd þo ‘Certes sir men wil me slo Sone so þai it may wite Þat on me is a child bi?ete.’ ‘Ich leue wele’ quaþ he ‘saun faile Ich haue of þi tale gret meruaile, Siker, douhter, and y finde and se Þat þou so wiþ child be I schal þe help wiþ al mi mi?t Til ich haue þerof a si?t Go now hom douhter min And haue Crist in hert þin Do penaunce day and ni?t Serue Ihesu wiþ al þi mi?t He may ?if his wille be Out of anoye bring þe.’ Hom sche went wiþ dreri mod And serued God wiþ hert gode— And euerich day þat bi?ete In hir wombe bigan to grete. Hir no gett it nou?t to hide For hir wombe wex vnride, Þer sone after sche was ynome And yladde to hir dome, Sore mi?t hir agrise Þo sche stode bifor þe iustise. Þermite herd tellen þis And þider he com anon ywis. Þe iustise him gan biþenche And þus aposed þat wenche ‘O maiden bi mi treuþe Of þe ich haue gret reuþe, Whi noldestow vnderstonde Hou þi kin is brou?t to schond And ben out of þis world ywent? And now þou hast þiseluen yschent Þat hast mannes flesche yknawe And vnderfong o?aines þe lawe, Þis ich day þou schalt be slawe For þat wil now þe lawe.’ ‘Certes sir’ sche seyd ‘nay No dede ich neuer o?ain þe lay Bi him þat þoled ded on tre Man no lay neuer bi me No bi his moder seynt Marie Mannes mouþe kist in vilanie.’ ‘Ey’ quaþ þe iustise ‘swiche meruaile! Þou lext damisel saun faile Þi tale soþe no mi?t be Seþþen wiþ child y þe se.’ ‘Certes’ sche sayd ‘wiþ child icham Wiþouten companie of man, So y slepe þis ender ni?t Bi me lay a selcouþe wi?t Y nist neuer wat it was (Ac now ich hold to Godes gras) Ac wele ich wot bi þis day Þat no man neuer bi me lay.’ Þe iustise swore bi seynt Albon Swiche meruail herd he neuer non ‘Þine tale ich no leue For seþþen þat Adam was and Eue Child bi?eten wiþouten man Herd y neuer bot of an Þat was Ihesu our Dri?t Þurth God þe Fadres mi?t— And for þou seyst wiþ child þou art And haddest neuer of man part Ar ani man þe quic delue Telle schul wiues tvelue ?if ani child may be made Wiþouten knoweing of mannes sade.’ Opon tvelue wiues it was ydo And þai com and seyden þo Þat neuer child bi?eten was Bot Ihesu þurth Godes gras Wiþouten mannes flesche forsoþ And þerto þai sworen her oþ. Þo spac Blasy þermite ‘Iustise listen me a lite Hir tale no may sche avowe Vnder ous alle se we mowe, Ich haue hir schriuen and tau?t þe lawe To me no was sche neuer biknawe Þat ani man to hir cam Þat euer knewe hir licham. Þei sche haue serued to be spilt Þe child þerof haþ no gilt It were gret vnri?t to to slon And reuþe, for þe gilt of on, Ac lete hir in ward don Sche schal herafter child son Tvo ?er and an half þan sche mot Þe child loke God it wot, When þe child can go and speke Þan ?e may ben of hir awreke.’ ‘A min Dieu’ seyd þe iustise ‘Þine tales ben gode and wise Þerafter now wirche ichille Today no schal hir no man spille.’ In a tour þai han hir do Þat no man mi?t hir com to Bot an eld midwiif Þat schuld ?emen hir liif Þerin sche was don on hast And þerin bischet ful fast, Þilke tour was swiþe hei?e No man mi?t comen hem nei?e A windowe was þerin And a cabel made bi gin Forto drawen vp al þing Þat nede was to her libbeing. Sone so hir time come Sche childed a selcouþe grome So ich bi bok telle can It hadde fourm after a man Bot it was blacker Þan anoþer and wel rower. Þo þat child was ybore Blasi stode þe hole bifore Bi þe rope þai it adoun let And he it cristned also sket He clept it Merlin a Godes name— Þe fende þerof hadde grame For þai lese þer þe mi?t Þat þai wende to haue bi ri?t. Þo þat child ycristned was Blasi turned o?ain his pas And in þe rope anon it knitt, Þe howe wiif anon it fett And ?ede and held it bi þe fer Biheld his face and eke his cher ‘Away þou foule þing Þat þi moder swiche ending For þi sake haue schal For þou art loþlich oueral.’ Þat child spac wiþ gret den ‘Þou lext’ he seyd ‘þou eld quen! Mi moder quelle no may no man While þat ich oliues am.’ Þe wif agros of þis answere And seyd ‘Haue þou no power me to dere Ich þe hals a Godes name!’ On þat maner seyd his dame And halsed him also þare He schuld telle wat he ware Ac þei þai it hadde al yswore Þai no mi?t do him speke no more And y ?ou telle anon saun fayl Þai hadden þerof gret meruail, And alle men þat herden it Wonder hadde in her wit. Þerafterward ?ete half a ?er His moder held him bi þe fer And swiþe bitter ters lete And seyd ‘Allas mi sone swete For þe misbi?eten stren Quic y schal now doluen ben.’ Þe child seyd ‘Dame nay Ich þe swere par ma fay No schal þer neuer no iustise Þe bidelue o non wise No in erþe þi bodi reke Þerwhiles y may gon and speke.’ His moder wex a bliþe wiman— Fram þat ich day after þan He teld hir vnder sonne Al þat sche wald conne. Þo þat child couþe go Þe iustise com þider þo And dede feche þat wiman Bifor þe pople ri?t onan And swore ded sche schuld ben Ri?t anon bi Heuen-quen. Þo bispac Merlin childe To þe iustise wordes milde ‘Man wele wot þat ani gode kan O?ain chaunce no may no man, Þurth chaunce and eke þurth gras In hir forsoþe pelt y was.’ Þe iustise biheld þat childe, For Merlin he was nei?e wilde And seyd ydoluen most sche ben, Þo quaþ Merlin ‘So mot y þen For al þat euer kanestow do Schaltow it neuer bring þerto Þat þou mi moder delue mow— Bi resoun ichil wele avowe: A fende it was þat me bi?at And pelt me in an holy fat He wende haue hadde an iuel fode Ac al icham turned to gode, Ac þurth kende of hem y can bo Telle of þing þat is ago And al þing þat is now Whi it is and what and how, Of oþer þing þat is to come Telle y can nou?t al ac some— Ich wot wele who mi fader is Ac þou no knowest nou?t þine ywis Wharþurth y tel moder þine Digner to be ded þan moder mine.’ Hou noblelich þat child answerd Wonder hadde þat it herd Þat so couþe speke and go And was bot of ?eres tvo. Þe iustise seyd ‘Þou gabbest conioun! Mi fader was an hei?e baroun Mi moder is a leuedi fre Oliue ?ete þou mi?t hir se Ich wene bi þe quen Marie Men dede neuer bi hir folie.’ Þe child seyd ‘Iustise held þi mouþe Oþer y schal make it wide couþe Of hir folis mani on; Do hir after som man gon, Bot ?if y do hir it ben aknawe Wiþ wild hors do me todrawe.’ Þe iustise anon raþe and skete His moder þider feche he hete Bifor him sche com wel sone Þe iustise seyd midydone ‘Say Merlin þat þou seydest arst Bifor mi moder ?if þou darst.’ ‘Now ich ise sir iustise Þine ordinaunce no be nou?t wise, ?if ich telt þis men bifore Hou þou were bi?eten and bore Þi moder most ydoluen be And þat were alle þurth þe.’ Þo þe iustise þis vnderstode He þou?t þat child couþe gode Into a chaumber sone anon Al þre þai gun to gon And þe iustise seyd þo ‘Child Merlin forþ þou go Telle now bitven ous þre What man it was þat bi?at me.’ Þe child swore bi seyn Symoun ‘It was þe persone of her toun Haþ ypleyd wiþ þi dame And bi?at þe al a-game.’ Þat leuedy seyd ‘Þou misbi?eten þing Þou hast ylowe a gret lesing His fader was a fair baroun, Y telle þat man a conioun Þat to þe ?iueþ ani listening For þou art a cursed þing Misbi?eten o?aines þe lawe Þou schust wiþ ri?t ben yslawe Þat þou no lei?e no lesinges mo Men forto wirchen wo.’ Þe child seyd ‘Dame be stille! Wiþ ri?t may me no man spille For icham a ferly sond Born to gode to al þis lond Ac þou art digne doluen to ben— Þi sone schal þe soþe ysen. Þo þi lord com fro Cardoil In hert þou haddest gret diol, Bi ni?t it was ar þe day Þe persone in þine armes lay On þi dore þi lord gan knoke And þou stirtest vp in þi smoke Wel nei?e wode for dred and howe Vp þou schotest a windowe And þe persone þou out lete And afterward þou schet it sket, And forsoþe þat ich ni?t He bi?at þis ich kni?t— Hou seistow dame seystow au?t?’ And sche no spac o?ain ri?t nau?t Ac so gretliche sche awondred was Þat hir chaunged blod and fas. Þe iustice seyd ‘Dame what seystow?’ ‘Sir he seyt soþe bi Crist Ihesu Þei ?e me hong bi a cord He no lei?eþ neuer a word.’ Þe iustise þo hadde no game Ac nei?e wode he was for schame, Merlin him cleped to an herne And to him told tales derne ‘Sir’ he seyd ‘listen to me For soþe ichil now tellen þe Lete þi moder wende hom And sende þou after a litel grom Þat hir cun wele aspie For homward sche wil an hei?e And to þe persone sone say Hou ichaue hem boþe biwray, When þe persone haþ herd þis Sore he worþ adrad ywis Of schameful deþ to haue of þe To a brigge he wil fle Into þe water scippe he wille And so he schal himseluen spille— Bot it be soþ þat y þe telle Wiþ þine honden þou me aquelle.’ Þe iustise dede saun fail Al bi þat childes conseyl He it aspide bi on hewe Þe childes tale he fond al trewe, And seþþen he legged hir fore Þe childes moder nas nou?t forlore And al quite he lete hir go Wiþouten pain wiþouten wo. Seþþen Blasy þermite Merlin com to visite And halsed him a Godes name Þat wiþouten harm and schame He schuld him telle al þe cas Hou he euer bi?eten was, Merlin him teld ende and ord Of his bi?eteing euery word, And seþþen seyd to Blasy after ‘To kinges foure y worþ maister Hem y mot ?ete alle rade And þou schalt write her dade Þou schalt write þat y say Mani man forto averray’— Þere he teld of mani a þing Þat Blasi made of writeing Bi was bok we vnderstond Al þat Merlin wrou?t in lond. Þo Merlin was fif winter eld He was michel broun and beld So we in boke finde conne His moder he dede make a nonne Þat Ihesu Crist wiþ hert gent Serued ay wiþ gode entent. On a day as ich ?ou telle Þo ich þre sechers snelle Þat were ysent fram þe king To hauen of þis child findeing Comen al þre bi cas Into þe toun þer Merlin was, Merlin in þe strete þo pleyd And on of his felawes him trayd Þat him seyd loude to ‘Foule schrewe fram ous go! Þou art al bi?eten amis Þou nost who þi fader is Ac some deuel as ich wene Þe bi?at ous euer to tene.’ Merlin sei?e þis and vnderstode Þo þre it were þat sou?t his blod Þat þo riden þerforbi Þat of þis child herden cri, He sei?e þat ich his hors wiþdrou? Merlin schoke his heued and lou? He was of fiue winter eld And he spac wordes swiþe beld ‘Yuel þe bifalle þou conioun! Þou hast yseyd to loude þi roun Her comeþ þe kinges messanger Þat haþ me sou?t al þis ?er Forto han min hert-blod, And it no may don hem no gode; Hast þai haue me to slen Ac bi þat þai me wiþ ei?en sen Þerto worþ hem no talent And ?if þai deden þai weren schent.’ Messangers to him gan terne And he o?aines hem fast gan erne And on hem Merlin lou? forsoþe And seyd to hem ‘Wel comeþ boþe! Now ?e haue yfounden me Þat ?ou was hoten forto sle Ar ?e wiþ me spak au?t (Þus ?o was bihoten and tau?t) Mi blod to haue to þat werk Þat schuld be so strong [and] sterk— For mi blod no worþ it þe bet Neuer more þe bet yset, Ichil proue lei?ers þai beþ Þat so bispoken mi deþ Ac certes ?iue ich were ded Þe king no worþ þerof no red.’ ‘Seynt Marie!’ quaþ her on “Swiche wonder haue we herd of non Hou wostow þat we it ben Þat þe seche forto slen, And þe kinges priuete? (So ?ong þou art!) Telle it me.’ Merlin seyd ‘Wele y wot Þe kinges conseyl eueri grot And al þat on erþe worþ ydo And al þat schal be don þerto.’ Þis men hadde wonder gret— Him to sle it were vnnet. Þe child seyd ‘Nou?t me no sleþ For y schal scheld ?ou fram þe deþ Bifor þe king ich ?ou pli?t And telle and schewe þe soþe ri?t Why his werk mai nou?t stond And of þe clerkes þat ben in bond Hou þai han ylowen on me Þe king þat soþe schal yse ?if it ?our willes is Wiþ ?ou ichil wende ywis.’ Al þre þai spoken þo ‘Certes child we wil it be so. Telle ous now what is þi name Oþer what wiman was þi dame Þat we se sum witnesseing Of þi dede—þou art so ?ing!’ Merlin anon he hem sede ‘Comeþ þider þer ich ?ou lede Mi moder ?e schullen se And wiþ þe soþe finde me.’ Þer he ledde hem bi hei?e sonne To his moder þer sche was nonne Þat al þat soþe was biknawe And euerich word hem teld arawe Hou þat child fram þe iustise, Fram deþ, hir saued wiþ wordes wise, Of þis sche told hem þus saun fayl Þe kni?tes hadden gret meruail; And seþþen in gret quiet and pays He ledde hem to his maister Blays Þat hem told and wittnes bar Of al þing þat he seyd þar, Merlin to Blasi þer meche seyd Þat Blasi al in writt leyd. Þat ni?t al þe messangers Þai bileften to þe sopers, Amorwe so we seþ in boke Al fiue þer her leue toke At þe nonne and at Blays And went hem forþ wele at aise Toward þe king þer he lay So þat þai comen on a day Þurth a toun, was chepeing And to selle mani a þing. Þer Merlin houed and lou? stille And sei?e hou men loued schon to selle, Þe messanger made anon asking Whi he made swiche lei?eing, Merlin seyd ‘No se ?e nou?t Newe schon þat man haþ bou?t And strong clout-leþer hem to clout And smere to smere hem al about? He wenes to liue and hem tere Ac bi mi soule y ?ou swere His wreche liif he schal forlate Her he com to his owhen gate.’ Þe messangers herden þis And wonder hadde þerof ywis For sone þerafterward þai founde Þat man ded opon a stounde. Rest þai token þat ich ni?t Amorwe her way þai went forþ ri?t And comen bi a chirche?erd And metten a bere to chirche-werd; His bridel þer Merlin wiþdrou? And swiþe schille and loude he lou?, Þe messangers bad him þo telle Whi it was he lou? so snelle, He seyd he sei?e wepe þat schuld sing And sing þat schuld make wepeing ‘For þe prest þat singeþ þare Bi?at þat child þat liþ on bare He ou?t for his sinne sori ben, And þe bond þat ?e ?ond sen Þat so loude and sore ginneþ wepe For blis he ou?t to sing and lepe For þe prestes sone is ded Þat euer schuld haue don him qued.’ To þe moder þai gun gon And þat soþe atoken anon Alle þe soþe sche gan hem say And bad hem nou?t hir biwray For sche were þan schent ay, ‘Verrament’ þai seyd ‘nay.’ Forþ þai went in her way Þiderward þe king him lay So ich ?ou segge in mi rime Þo lou? Merlin þe þridde time, Eft him asked al his fere Whi he maked swiche chere, ‘?is’ he sayd ‘listen now Þe soþe ichil tel ?ou: Þe quen mi lordes wiif at hom Haþ puruayd a wrongful dom; Hir chaumberlain is a wiman Þat goþ in gise of a man, For he is louely and of fair hewe Our quen þat is vntrewe Bad hir be hir leman For sche wend sche were a man, Þis chaumberlain seyd þat he nold Tresoun do for no gold Wharþurth þe quen pleint made To mi lord þe king and sade Þat þurth fors hir chaumberlain Wald haue hir forlain. Þe king for þis was swiþe wroþ And wraþfulliche swore his oþ ‘?if y may atake þis wrong He worþ todrawe and tohong!’ Now wendeþ toforn on of ?ou And tel anon þe king hou Y haue ?ou teld of þe fals loue, Bid him þat he þe soþe proue.’ Forþ him went a messanger Swiftlich on a gode destrer Til þan he com to þe king Made he nowhar no targeing, Þe king he fond in his halle On þis maner he gan him calle ‘Hail þou be king Fortiger And God þe loke in þi power Saue and kepe þi mi?ti hond! Whe han went into al þis lond To seche a child bi hest þine Wiche men clepeþ Merlin, Y wot he is now fiue ?er eld Wise of speche of dede beld He can telle al þing On erþe vnder Heuen-king Þat is go and now is And michel þat to comen is. Þe ten clerkes on him lowe Aforn ?ou he wil avowe, He wil ?ou teche swiþe wel What destourbes ?our castel Þat it may stond on þe pleyn, And also of ?our chaumberlain Þat ?e no schul sle no hong For it were al wiþ wrong To sle a woman for a man Þat mannes cloþes haþ opan— Bot ?e him wiman finde ?e schuld him hong bi þe winde.’ Fortiger awondred was And al þo þat herd þis cas, Þe chaumberleyn he ofsent anon Þat in strong prisoun was ydon He was despuled fram heued to grounde Marked woman and maiden founde, Þe king was wondred out of witt And toke þe messanger bi þe slit And seyd ‘Telle me ?if þou can Who þe teld sche was wiman.’ ‘Child Merlin it gan ous say As we went hiderward in our way For he can telle and gabbe nou?t Of al þing þat haþ ben wrou?t’— And al he teld þer þe king Of his bi?ete, of his bereing And whiche þinges he gan say As he com bi þe way. Þan seyd Fortiger þe bold ‘And it be soþe þat þou me told Ichil þe ?iue lond and plou? And make þi felawes riche ynou?.’ He dede comand anon ri?t Douke erl baroun and kni?t To di?t her hors and make hem ?are Wiþ him o?ain Merlin to fare And when it was wele wiþin ni?t Wiþ Merlin he mett apli?t And when þe king wiþ Merlin mett Wel hendelich he him gret And þe king welcomed þat child Wiþ fair wordes and wiþ mild, Mani worde þai spoken sone Þat y no haue nou?t of to done No al siggen y no may Þei y sete al þis day Bot þat longeþ to þis nede Wel schortliche ich wil me spede. Þai were at ese þat ich ni?t, Amorwe þai went forþ ful ri?t And to þe stede gun ten Þer þe castel schuld ben, Fortiger spac to Merlin ‘Tel me now sone mine Whi no man no may her founde Castel here opon þis grounde And whi it is ybrou?t to nou?t Þat is here o day ywrou?t.’ Merlin seyd ‘Certes sir king Þerof nis no selcouþe þing, Hervnder is, a ?erde depe, A water boþe swift and stepe Vnder þat water ligge stones to Brod and long þai ben bo Vnder þo stones beþ depe in mold To dragouns fast yfold Þat on is white so milkes rem Þat oþer is red so feris lem Wiþin þai brinneþ boþe And beþ togider swiþe wroþe, When þe sonne is doun euery ni?t Togider þai fond forto fi?t And þurth þe strengþe of her blast Al þi werk is doun ycast— Þat iche þe say now it serche And þan mow þi werkmen werche Castel and tour after þi wille Þai mow stond long stille.’ Þe king was wondred of þis cas And al þat euer mid him was, Werkmen he dede anon Þider feche mani on Þat þer doluen in þe grounde And sone þerafter a water founde In whiche sone vnder hem alle Þai maden to þicke walles Þe water vp loden þo Alway bi to and to. Þo þai comen to þe grounde To stones þicke þai founde Þat wa[re] boþe long and brode, Hem bitven a gret schode Of grauel and erþe also Þat hem hadde schifted ato, Mani on forsoþe þer were Þo to stonnes forto arere. Þo þe stones weren ywent To dragouns þer layen ybent Þe tail vnder hem felfeld A[l]so Merlin hadde yteld Þat on was rede so þe fer Þe ei?en so a bacine cler Euerich powe a span long Þe fer out of his moþe sprong His tail was boþe long and gret A gastlich best he was to mete He hadde a bodi as a whal; Þat oþer dragoun was al Nou?t so michel so þe rede— And clowes he hadde qued Hoked tail and mouþe wide Tong so a brenand glede A rugged taile so a fende And an heued at þe ne[n]de. Boþe þai gun arise Al þat hem sei?e gun agrise Þer nas noiþer king no erl Baroun kni?t fre no cherl Þat þer durst abide leng Alle þai flowen on o reng, No man nome ?eme who þer was he Ac ich tofore oþer gan fle. Þe dragouns arisen of her den And no folwed neuer on þe men Ac togider smiten anon Swiche batayl nas neuer non Þai kest fer on swiche maner As al þe cuntre were afer, Wiþ mouþe wiþ clowes and wiþ tayl Þer þai maden a gret batail Þe erþe quaked vnder hem þo Þe weder chaunged abouen also Þai biten and smiten and fer cast Þai fellen and risen and fou?ten fast. Almest a day þis fi?ting Last wiþouten ani resting And þo þis more rede dragoun Drof þis white fer adoun Til þai com into o valaye And þer þai gun to rest baye Ich vnderstond so long a while While men mi?t gon a mile; Þe white þere arered mi?t And gan eft wiþ þe rede fi?t And þe rede he drof o?ain Til þai com to þe playn, Þe white dragoun wiþ gret main Þe rede drof, þat men it sayn, And þe rede adoun cast Þat wiþ strengþe of his blast Þe white brent þan rede Þat of him nas founden a schrede Bot dust forsoþe ich saye, And þe white flei?e oway— Nist neuer seþþen man Whiderwardes he bicam. Alle þat euer sei?e þis Wonder hadde gret ywis Of þe dragouns þat fou?ten þo And of child Merlin also Þat he couþe so priue þing Soþe schewen to þe king. Þo spac Merlin to Fortiger ‘Sir þou sest þis þing is cler Þat ich haue yschewed þe; Þe clerkes do bring bifor me Þat to þe mi lord þe king On me lowe swiche lesing And y schal asken hem wharefore Mi blod þai wold haue forlore.’ ‘Certes’ quaþ king Fortiger ‘It schal be don wiþouten danger Y schal þe don after mi mi?t Al þi wille and þat is ri?t.’ Þe king anon wiþ his men Sent after þis clerkes ten, Þo þai com bifor Merlin He asked hem al on Latyn Þurth wiche þing þai vnderstode Þat þurth þe vertu of his blode Þe kinges castel schuld on hast Haue ben gode and stedefast, Þe clerkes spoken to þe child Dradefullich wiþ wordes milde ‘We sei?en’ he seyd ‘heraboue Ouer ous a sky houe Þat ous schewed þe bi?ate Of swi[che] a þing on erþe late Þurth was blod þe castel Schuld stond fair and wel Þis we wenden verrament— Do wiþ ous al þi talent.’ ‘Ow’ quaþ Merlin sikerlike ‘Now ?e sen ?e ben biswike Þe sky þat ?ou schewed þat It was þe fader þat me bi?at, For he me hadde nou?t to his wille Þurth ?ou he wald do me spille, Ac for he haþ biswike ?ou Y pray mi lord þe king nov Þat he graunt ?ou to liue For al þis gilt y ?ou for?iue’— Þe king it al hem graunted raþe And hye him al ‘Merci!’ quaþe. Þo þe king and child Merlin And euerich went vnto his in, Merlin bileft wiþ Fortiger Ich vnderstond al þat ?ere Bi whos conseyl and rede and witt Þe castel was maked in a fit Hei?e and strong of trewe and ston Swiche nas in þis lond non. Þo þe castel was ymade Men ?eue þe king sone rade Þat he schuld at Merlin wite Whi þe dragouns batail smite, ‘It bitokneþ’ þai seyden alle Sum tokening þerafter schuld falle; Merlin com tofor þe king And al þai asked him of þat þing Whi þe dragouns togider fou?t It bitokned sumwhat hem þou?t, Merlin made sumdel danger And þo bispac him Fortiger ‘Merlin bot þou it me telle Ichil þe do anon quelle.’ Quaþ Merlin ‘Y sigge apli?t ?if þou me slou? it were vnri?t Ac þei þou haddest nome an hond Me to sle or don in bond Þou mi?test fayle verrament So doþ mani of his talent For certes sir Fortiger Y no ?iue nou?t of þi power, Ac ?if þou wilt finde me borwes Þat þou no schalt me waite sorwes Y wil þe telle and noþing ly?e What þe dragouns signifie’— Þat gentil folk and eke þe king Awondred of his answering. Þe king swore opon a boke Þat he nold him neuer harm loke And seþþen he fond him sikerliche To borwe tvo doukes riche, Þo him spac an heye Merlin ‘Now herken king to tale min, Þe red dragoun so strong in fi?t Bitokneþ þe and al þi mi?t, Whiche þou hast procourd fro fer Þe ded of Moyne þe ri?t air; Þat þe rede þe white drof To a valay biside a grof Token þou hast made flem Þe ri?t aires out of þe rem In cite toun and in feld And al þe men þat wiþ hem held. Þe white dragoun signifie[þ] Þe ri?t air þat haþ envie To þe þat heldeþ al his lond Wiþ gret wrong vnder þine hond; Þat he flei?e into þe valaye And recouerd mi?t, y say, Bitokneþ þe air þe se bi?ounde Þat haþ gret socour yfounde And is hiderward wiþ mani kni?t Di?t o?aines þe to fi?t; Þat þe white drof o?ain Þe [rede] ri?t to þe plain And him þere adoun cast And al tofrust him wiþ his blast Bitokneþ þe air of þis lond Þat schal þe keuer into his hond And into þi castel driue Wiþ þine children and þi wiue And mani noble of þine mene He schal wiþ þe þerin brenne. Þe tayle of þe dragoun rede Þat is so long and so vnrede Signifieþ þe wicke stren Þat schal com out of þi kin And of þi wiues fader Angys Þat schal be ded and lesen his pris, His kin and eke þin Schal don wo to Bretouns kin; Þe heued of þe white tayle Signifieþ gret conseyle Þat schul held wiþ þe kinges blod Of þe gentil men and gode— Sir forsoþe þis is þe tokening Of þe dragouns fi?ting, Puruay þe now ich þe rede Þer is comen gret ferrede.’ Þo agros sir Fortiger Bot his lippe and hong his cher And to Merlin seyd anon ‘Þou most ous teche hou to don O?aines our fomen forto ware Oþer of þi liif þou art al bare, Anon þai wold him han ynome Ac þai nist where he was bicome. Þe king and his folk also Þerfore made michel wo Þai him sou?t and nou?t him founde— He was oway in a stounde Vnto his maister Blasy And þer he told him sikerly Of þe dragouns rede and white And Blasy dede it al in write. He told him of þe rede dragoun Swiþe michel confvsyoun Of him and of his fals stren In Inglond þat schuld ben Mani sori chaunce and hard Þat sone þ[er] fel þerafterward; Sum fel now late also And sum beþ nou?t ?ete ago, For it is alle þester þing Nil ich make þerof no telling Ac forþ ichil wiþ mi tale— Listneþ now gret and smale! Miri time it is in May Þan wexeþ along þe day Floures schewen her borioun Miri it is in feld and toun Foules miri in wode gredeþ Damisels carols ledeþ. A baroun com to Fortiger Þer he sat at his diner And seyd ‘Allas mi lord þe king Y sigge þe an hard tiding, Orpedlich þou þe bistere And þi lond þou fond to were Vter Pendragoun and mani anoþer And Aurilis Brosias his broþer (Pople boþe gret and smale Wiþ hem is comen wiþouten tale) At Winchester þai ben almast— Sir þine help now on hast! Socour about now after sende (Þai ben here nei?e at þine hende) Þat þou mi?test o?ain hem fi?t And hem to sle anon doun ri?t.’ Vp him stirt sir Fortiger And ofcleped his chaunceler Þat letters fele him made ywis Vnto his eldfader sir Angys, To erls doukes and to kni?tes Þat were of swiþe gret mi?tes; Þe buriays of Winchester he gret And bad þai schuld þe gates schet And helden wele her leute And to him loke þat cite ?if þai wold his loue winne Þat his fon no com þerinne, And seyd he wald hem com to As swiþe as he mi?t it do. To Fortiger þai comen anon Erls barouns euerichon, Angys his eldfader cam And wiþ him wel mani a man Amirayls and doukes hei?e Þat in batayle were slei?e, Mani þousand þer were bi tale Boþe of gret and of smale; Þo þai togider weren ycome Her conseyl was sone ynome Wiþouten let forþ to wende Her fomen forto schende Þat þai no entred in þe lond Harm to don oþer schond. Vp þai lift gomfaynoun And went to Winchester toun; Vter Pendragoun and his ferrede To Winchester þai gun spede Wiþ so michel pople of men Þat þai wre?en doun and den Þat come boþe bi water and lond Forto winnen Inglond, Þai vndede her gomfaynoun Wiþ a bri?t gliderand lyoun Þat her faders hadde yben. Þe buriays it gun ysen Þe gomfaynoun sone þai knewe Costaunce ded þo gun hem rewe Þat hadde her noble lord yben And Moynes ded þat was his stren And wist wele þat king wiþ wrong Sir Fortiger hadde ben long Þat cursed was in liif and dede, And al þat held his f[e]rrede Þer þai spoken hem bitvene For liif for dede no for tene And þei þai alle hong schold Wiþ Fortiger be þai nold And turned hem al bi on acord To Vter Pendragoun her lord; Þe gates al þai deden vp wide And lete al þe folk in ride, Hem and al her ferrade Þai welcomed wiþ chere glade And hem del[i]uerd þe toun als snel And hemselue and þe castel— What þurth þanke and frende gret Þai wonnen þer þat hem was net. Fortiger þat comend was Sone was told him þat cas He was nei?e wode out of wit And seyd it schuld hem iuel atsit, Swiþe he hei?ed wiþ al his men, And Vter Pendragoun hem o?en And desplayd his gomfaynoun A litel wiþouten Winchester toun Þat ich oþer folk ysey?e Þai were nei?ed so nei?e; Of þis lond baroun and kni?t Of þe lyoun hadden a si?t King Costaunce þat hadde yben And Vter Pendragoun was his stren, Anon turned her mode To Vter Pendragounes ri?t blod. Þer was þousandes mani on Opon Fortiger þai turned anon And seyd to him ‘Wicke traytour Þou schald abigge þine errour!’ Fortiger his swerd out drou? And mani of hem þer he slou? (Wiþ gret ire þai run him on) For he hem wende al his men Ac o?ain him þai were al went Whereþurth he was al yschent, Fortiger was noble kni?t He fau?t and slou? adoun ri?t To his help þer com Angys Wiþ mani Sarra?in of priis Þat wise wordes couþe speke Stedes prike and launces breke Þe barouns þai bisett anon Forto sle hem euerichon. Þer was a baroun a noble man Þat brac hem al fram He dede his stede swiþe gon Til he com to Vter Pendragon And seyd ‘Welcome air of þis lond! No duelle her nou?t for Cristes hond, For loue of þi fader fre And for drede eke of þe Þe barouns ben to þe went And for þi loue almest yschent For Fortiger and eke Angys Hem han al biloken ywis And þenke hem sle to grounde ?if þou duellest ani stounde.’ ‘Owe’ quaþ Vter Pendragoun ‘bi God aboue Now y schal se who me wil loue No schal ich neuer worþ bliþe Bot ?iue ?e al hei?en swiþe!’ Princes doukes erl and kni?t Priked her stedes ari?t It was no nede hem to hast Ac so quarel of alblast Þai flowen þider ri?t anon Wiþ her lord Vter Pendragon. Þer was sone verrament ?ouen mani noble dent Schaft tobroken and swerd ydrawe Mani noble kni?t yslawe And þer fau?t sir Vter Pendragon, Fau?t þer as a wode lyoun, And his broþer nou?t for?at He leyd on mani a sori flat Sum he cleue, to þe bacin, Til þat he com to þe chin, He hadde of some sone [þe h]eued Fram þe nek-bon yreued, Þer was slayn mani men Sum on hille and sum in den, Ac þei Fortiger were gode kni?t And wele him couþe helpen in fi?t Þurth þe barouns of þe lond And oþer men mi?ti of hond He was þere ydriuen so nei?e Wiþ his men oway he flei?e Vnto his newe castel ymade Of whom ich toforn sade, Aurilis Brosias þer anon And his broþer Vter Pendragon Þere hem wroken swiþe wel Wiþ her brondes of ful gode stiel Mani hundred of Sarra?in Þai sent þer to helle-pine. Þo Angys al þis slei?ster sei?e Wiþ al his mi?t anon he flei?e Into a castel of lime and ston Þat man no mi?t him dery non, Þat bihinde was yfounde Anon was ybrou?t to grounde. Þan Vter Pendragoun þere Folwed after Fortiger, Þo þai to þe castel-?ates come Wilde fer anon þai nome Opon þe gates þai kesten it And hem brend in litel fit, Fortiger and wiif and child Brent þer in þat fer wild And al þat þer was yfounde Was ybrent into þe grounde. Men seyt ?ere and oþer to Wrong wil an hond go And euer at þe nende Wrong wil wende; Þus ended sir Fortiger Þat misbileued a fewe ?er— Þei he wer strong of mi?t To nou?t him brou?t his vnri?t. Sir Vter Pendragoun Wiþ his folk went anon Forto bisege þe king Angis Ac in a castel he lay of priis Þat wiþ no gin y ?ou pli?t No man þerin com mi?t. Also þai in þe sege lay Fiue barouns com on a day Þat hadde ben wiþ Fortiger And seyd to Vter Pendragoun þer Al hou Merli[n] was ybore And hou messangers him ?ede fore Hou he was brou?t bifor þe king And hou he couþe tellen al þing, Hou þe dragouns vnder mold Ben þe kinges deþ it schold And hou Fortiger him wold haue nome Ac he nist where he was bicome, And seyd ‘Sir verrament ?if he were here in present Bi his conseyl ?e schuld anon Angys ouercomen and slon.’ Herof awondred Vter Pendragon And sent messangers anon Forto finde Merlin swiþe, Þai wenten forþ wiþ chere bliþe. On a day þis messanger Sett hem alle to þe diner, A begger þer com in Wiþ a long berd on his chin A staf in his hond he hadde And schon on his fet badde. Wiþ his scholder he gan roue And bad gode for Godes loue, Þai seyd he schuld nou?t haue Bot strokes and bismare, Þe eld man seyd anon ‘?e be nice euerichon Þat sitten here and scorn me In þe kinges nedes þat schuld be Forto finde Merlin child, Þe barouns ben witles and wilde Þat senten men him seche Þat nou?t no couþe knoweleche, Today he haþ ?ou oft mett No knewe ?e him neuer þe bet, Wendeþ hom bi mi rede For him to finde no schul ?e spede Biddeþ him and þe barouns fiue Þai comen and speke wiþ him bliue And siggeþ Merlin wil hem abide In þe forest herebiside’— Þo he hadde seyd hem þis Þai nist where he bicom ywis Þus telleþ þe letters blak It was Merlin wiþ hem spak. Þe messangers were abobbed þo Þai nisten what þai mi?ten do Hom þai went anon ri?t And to þe prince þai teld þer si?t, Vter Pendragoun had meruaile And al þat herden it saun faile Þai hadden wille and talent fin To sen and speke wiþ Merlin, He bad Aurilis Brosias gent To þe sege take entent Þat Angys no mi?t oway Noþer bi ni?t no bi day Ar he war of him awreke For he wald wiþ Merlin speke. Aurilis Brosias bileft stille To kepe Angys in þe castil And sir Vter Pendragon To þe forest went anon Where þat Merlin dede him se In o day in þre ble— In o day an hogges herd Þat þe prin[c]e þe way lerd, And eft a chapman þat bar his pac And long wiþ þe prin[c]e spac And seyd of Merlin openliche He wald him telle neweliche, And afterward a fair swain Þat þe king com ogain And seyd him þat ich ni?t He schuld of Merlin han a si?t. Þo it was wel fer in ni?t Merlin com to him ypli?t In þe gise of a swain Þat he hadde arst ysain And seyd so we finde in boke To þe prince ‘God þe loke! Icham Merlin leue sire Wiþ whom to speke þou hast desire.’ Vp stirt Vter Pendragon And biclept Merlin anon And bad he schuld wiþ him bilaue And al his wille he schuld haue, Merlin seyd were so he ware To his wil he war al ?are. Merlin teld him in þat cas ‘Y com fram Aurilis Brosias Bi mi conseyl he haþ þis ni?t Angys slayn y þe pli?t.’ Vter Pendragon made ioie þan So doþ þe foule when it dawy gan Al þat þer was so made blis And amorwe went hom ywis And founden Angys yslawe His heued vp set his bodi todrawe, Al his folk so was schilt And neuer on þer nas spilt. Sir Vter Pendragon þere Asked Aurilis Brosias hou it were, ‘Certes’ seyd Aurilis Brosias ‘toni?t A swain com to me ful ri?t And hastiliche warned me Þat Angys com me to sle, Vp ich stirt and him met And to þe grounde ichim stet Y not who him on brou?t No what Deuel he here sou?t Ac wiþ mi swerd scharp of egge His liif y dede him þere legge.’ Þo spac Vter Pendragon To his broþer swiþe anon ‘Broþer’ he seyd ‘þat was Merlin Þat so þe halp in nede þin Þat here stont now bi me’— And he him þonked wiþ hert fre And proferd him al his þing To ben vnder his ?emeing. Also þai spac wiþ Merlin A bod com fram þe Sarra?in Þai wold ?eld þe castel ?if þai mosten wenden wel To her lond wiþouten dere, Merlin ?af hem answere Þat þai schuld wende anon Bi þe princes leue ichon And so þai deden bi Godes sond Alle þai wenten to her lond. And alle þe lond þo com anon And maked her oþ to Vter Pendragon And þo þe oþ was ymade Bi comoun dome bi comoun rade Vter Pendragon coroun nam And king of Inglond bicam, Þe fest of þe corounment In Winchester was verrament And held it ful seuen ni?t Þe fest noble apli?t. Ac ich ?ou telle þat Merlin To Aurilis Brosias hadde hert fin And loued better his litel to Þan al þat oþer bodi þo, Ac ich ?ou telle naþeles A swiþe gode kni?t he wes He forsoke scheld no spere Neuer o?aines kni?t to bere Wiþ swerd he couþe kerue wel Boþe in yren and in stiel. Ac forsoþe afterward Vp him com a chaunce hard, Of Danmark Sarra?ins Þat were of Angys lins Þat hem sou?t gret helping About hem of mani king (So michel pople wiþ hem com Þat it no mi?t telle no man) Wiþ fele schippes and gret ynowe Vp þai comen at Bristowe. Merlin þis wist anon And seyd to Vter Pendragon And to his broþer also And teld to hem boþe to ‘Y ?ou telle saun fayle Vp ?ou is comen a strong batayle Of Sarra?ins of michel priss Forto awreke þe douke Angys, In þis lond bi our day So michel folk nas neuer y say, Ac ?our on wiþouten les Worþ yslawe in þat pres Ac ich ?ou telle who so it is Schal wende into heuen-blis Þerfore no for[s] no makeþ Ac gode hert to ?ou takeþ; ?our folk departeþ atvo O?aines hem ?e gin to go Vter Pendragon hem schal asayle On þe lond-half saun fayle, Aurilis Brosias y telle þe Þou schalt wende bi þe se And þer þou þe conteyn so Þat þou hem wirche deþes wo’— For noþing he nold say Whiche of hem schuld day. As he hem bad þai deden so Her folk departed atvo, Vter Pendragon wiþ mani man Anon þe Sarra?ins ?ede o?an And also sone so he hem mett Wiþ swerd and launce he hem gret Mani haþen þer was forsoþ Þe heued cleued to þe toþ Þe nek-bon dassed atvo Þe arm þe bodi smiten fro Wiþ swerd þe body atvo ydast Þe bodi out of þe sadel cast, Þe boke it seyt, nou?t y no lye, Þer was don swiche cheualrie Þat no tong telle no mi?t Þe haluendel wiþ tale ri?t; Aurilis Brosias to þe se went To whom Merlin hadde gode talent. Merlin sent þan anon To sir Vter Pendragon And bad him orpedliche he schuld keþe For he no schuld þere þoly deþe, Þo Vter Pendragon herd þis His hert bicome ful of blis Wiþ wretþe and wiþ talent fin He smot opon a Sarra?in, He and al his felawered Þer þai deden noble dede— Al þat euer wald ariue Þai binomen day o liue. Vter Pendragon so hard hem held Þat þai wiþ strengþe lete þe feld And Aurilis Brosias hem held so hard Þat he hem brou?t o?anward, And þo þai noure fle mi?t Wiþ Aurilis Brosias þai gun fi?t And so fele about him were His liif þai binomen him þere; Ac þo Vter Pendragon vnderstode His broþer deþ he wex ner wode, Þo he bisou?t his doukes fi?t And him bistired þo as a kni?t Þat of þritti þousand and mo No lete þai fiue oway go, Of our wer slawe þan anon Þre þousend and ten and on— Þre mile-wayes oþer to No mi?t no man step no go Noiþer on hille no in den Bot he steped on ded men Þe blod ouerran þe cuntraye Oueral in þe valaye. So it fel to þe ni?t Vter Pendragon com fram þe fi?t, Doukes kinges and barouns Orped squiers and garsouns Hom went to her in, Bi rede amorwe of Merlin Aurilis Bros[i]as out þai sou?t And richelich in erþe him brou?t. Þan he was helden a douhti kni?t And ful wele held his lond to ri?t Here he liued seþþen ?eres fele In miche pride and gret wele, Fer and nei?e wide and side His fomen durst him nou?t abide— Bi Merlins red euer he wrou?t Þat into gret power him brou?t. He ouercom king Claudas Þat so strong and stern was, Þurth his mi?t also he wan Þe douhti king Harinan And of him he hadde first Gascoyne And Normondye and Boloyne And al þe marche to Paito And Chaumpeine and eke Ango. Þis ich king Harinan To wiue had a fair wiman Sche hi?t Ygerne wiþouten no Þe fairest lif þat liued þo, Þe douke Hoel of Cornewaile Spoused hir after him saun fayl Þurth whom seþþen his liif he les— ?e schul seþþen here in pes. ?ete hadde Vter Pendragon Wonne to him þe king Ban And Bohort his broþer also Better bodis no mi?t non go, King Ban hadde to his demeyne Þe cite of Benoit of lasse Breteyne Wiþ cites and borwes castels and pleyns And Bohort hadde þe cite of Gaines Wiþ al þe ri?t þat longed þerto And þus þai hadde schift atvo. And afterward wiþouten fable Our king bigan þe rounde table— Þat was þurth Merlines hest. Of kni?tes þat men wist best In þis warld þurthout Þat table schuld sitte about, At þat table non sitt mi?t Bot he were noble and douhti kni?t Strong and hende hardi and wise Certes and trewe wiþouten feyntise, Her non oþer schuld faile No neuer fle out of bataile Whiles he on fot stond mi?t Bot ?if hem departed þe ni?t, At bataile and at bord also Bi hemselue þai schuld go— So monkes don in her celle Bi hemselue þai eten ich telle. Wher wer were alder mast Þai were þider sent on hast. Þis table gan Vter þe wi?t Ac it to ende ha[d]e he no mi?t For þei alle þe kni?tes vnder our Lord Hadde ysiten at þat bord Kni?t bi kni?t ich ?ou telle Þe table no mi?t nou?t fulfille Til he wer born þat schuld do al Fulfille þe meruails of þe greal. It was opon þe Pentecost In time þat þe Holy Gost Among þe tvelue apostles cam So sparc of fer and in hem ran Our king Vter Pendragon Lete bede wel mani a man Doukes kni?tes erls and king To Cardoil to his gestening Swiche was his won apli?t To helden ful seuen ni?t And euerich wiþ him schuld bring His leuedi to þat gestening, Fram Kent to Norþhumberlond Fram Wales and fram Scotlond Baroun erl douke and kni?t To þat fest com apli?t. In þat time was ded Hoel, And þe noble baroun Tintagel Þat was douke of Cornwayle Hadde spoused Ygerne saun faile Þat fair wiman þat swete liif Þat hadde ben Holes wiif. Þese to Cardoil boþe come Men hem bi þe hond ynome And ledden hem bifor þe king, He made hem fair welcoming Ac þo he sei?e þat leuedi bri?t His hert was chaunged apli?t He was nomen wiþ loue-las Þat he no wist were he was, Naþeles Ygerne anon Was wiþ leuedis to chaumber gon Whar sche was for hir beaute Fair onourd in leaute; Þe king þe douke sett aboue Toforn al oþer for her loue Alder next his side he sat And of his dische and plater at. Þis ich douke Tintagel Hadde a boteler hi?t Bretel Þat him serued day and ni?t At his bord so it was ri?t, Ygerne hadde a chaumberlains A gentil man þat hi?t Iurdains. Þe king at his mete sat Michel he þou?t and litel he at He tok a coupe in his hond Þat was worþ a schire of lond And seyd ‘Bretel þou com me ner, Þis to Ygerne þi leuedi ber Bid hir drink þis licour And do þe coupe in hir tresour.’ Bretel tok þe coupe anon Bifor his leuedi he gan gon On his knewe he him sett And on þe kinges halue hir gret And seyd ‘Dame þe king þe sent (And drinkeþ to þe) a fair present To þe he drinkeþ þis licour Þe coupe he ?eueþ to þi tresour.’ Wel sore gan þis present rewe Dam Ygerne þat leuedi trewe Sche seyd ‘Go o?ain anon To þe king Vter Pendragon Say y nil nou?t it take at o word Wiþouten leue of mi lord Þat ich þis present vnderfong, ?if ich dede it were wrong’— Bretel went o?ain anon And seyd to Vter Pendragon. Þo he hadde it yseyd Þe king sore was amayd Ac after sche it nam on hast Þurth hir owhen lordes hest Vlfin þerof was messanger He was þe kinges conseyler, Vnneþe sche it nim wold Ac þo sche algat schold Swiþe sore sche gan to wepe Wonder hem þou?t þat bi hir sete. Þo alle þe cloþes weren ydrawe After mete so it was lawe Þe king ?aue fair ?iftes To douk baroun and to kni?tes Ac non no had swiche saun faile So þe douke of Cornwaile For þe loue of Ygerne In whas loue he dede berne. Anon after þo leuedis alle Were ofsent into þe halle, Þe king toke Ygerne bi þe hond Þe fairest leuedi of þis lond And sett hir bi him on þe benche Win and piment he dede senche, Oþer kinges and doukes hei?e Token oþer leuedis slei?e Togider hem set and made solas. Þe king bisou?t Ygerne of gras Þat sche schold ben his lef, Þe leuedi seyd ‘I nam no þef To breke mi treuþe o?ain mi lord Raþer ich wald hing bi a cord No schal y neuer for loue no ?ift Wiþ mi bodi don vnri?t,’ Oþerwise for no preier Þe king nold sche yhere, Þe king spac no more þo Sumwat elles he þou?t to do. Þo þai were al at aise Ich went to his in a-paise Ac ich ?ou telle þo at arst Þe king nei?e for loue brast Ac no man nist of his pin Bot his conseiler Vlfin Þat bad him nou?t care biginne He schuld wele hir loue winne. Tintagel and eke Ygerne To her in went ful ?erne Þe leuedi toke þan þe kni?t And into chaumber went ful ri?t Toforn him a-knewes sche fel And seyd ‘Lord ?if it be þi wille Þat þou wost hennes wende! Þe king is about, me to schende, Þe worþschip þat he doþ to þe Al is forto schende me He haþ me of vilanie bisou?t Me to aforce is in his þou?t.’ Þo þe douke þis vnderstode For wretþe he wex nei?e wode, He hadde in toun v hundred kni?tes He hem ofsent anon ri?tes And told hem þis vilainie And seyd he wald hom an hei?e He bad hem trosse and make ?are Ar day he wold homward fare For he hadde leuer dye in fi?t Þan schond þoli and vnri?t, His kni?tes to him ?euen asent And trossed swiþe verrament, Bi þat it was li?t o day Þai weren al ywent oway Þe douke þe leuedi and his kni?t. Þe king seye þe dayli?t Þat ni?t he hadde litel yslape He stirt vp al in rape His chaumberlain him com to His cloþes on forto do, Þo he was cloþed he com adoun Sikeende and romende vp and doun. Afterward com in anon Barouns and leuedis mani on To chirche þai ?ede more and lasse Forto heren þer her messe Ac al þai loked swiþe ?erne After Tintagel and Ygerne. Þo þe messe was ysonge Þe king spac wiþ his tonge ‘Where is þe douke Tintagel? Icham adrad him is nou?t wel.’ ‘Certes sir’ quaþ a kni?t, ‘He is went homward toni?t Wiþ wiif and kni?tes to his lond.’ ‘Eye’ quaþ þe king ‘þat is me schond! Þef! He haþ broken mi statout He schal abigge wiþouten dout’— His statout was and his lawe Þat non no schuld in seuen dawe Þat were of priis oþer of noblay Fram þat fest wende oway Bot it were bi þe kinges wille And who so dede he schuld spille. Þo þe king vnderstode Þe douke ywent he was nei?e wode, Of þat despite pleynt he made And to his folk seþþen he sade Þat he was digne to dye anon Þat swiche despite hadde ydon. Þe king him di?t in a stounde And þe kni?tes of þe table rounde (Þe noblest men þat were oliue) And riche kinges tvo and fiue Noble kinges of þis lond Al wonnen vnder his hond, Wiþ mani erl baroun and kni?t Armed went anon ri?t Þe douke Tintagel to nime So þe kinges wiþþerwine; Ac þe douke Tintagel Þis bifore wist it wel He hadde sent fer and nei?e After frendes and souders slei?e Fiftene þousand kni?tes hende Þat schuld his lond help to defende, Naþeles o?ain þe king Þai no hadde power in fi?ting— At cite borwe and castel Þai were astored swiþe wel. Þe king com wiþ his barnage And tounes brent in gret rage He bilay him swiþe long And men slou?—it was wiþ wrong. Þe douke himselue Tintagel Lay in a swiþe strong castel, Our king Vter Pendragon Him asailed and ek his men Wiþ heweing and wiþ mineinge And wiþ mangunels casteinge Ac Tintagel þat hende kni?t His castel wered wele apli?t, And þennes ouer miles þre Lay Ygerne so fair and fre In a castel, [a] roche of ston— Man no mi?t hir dery non. Iurdains and eke Bretel Boþe were wiþ Tintagel And al þat mi?t armes bere To helpen him his castel to were, Þe king him hadde wel long ylay And was ful of wretþe and tray Þat he no mi?t him nim anon And sike he was in euerich bon For loue of þe cuntasse Gode he no couþe more no lasse. On a day it bifel so: Vter Pendragon was swiþe wo Vlfin he tok his chaumberlain And went to plaien him on þe plain An beggere þere he mett Þat þe king wel fair gret, For Godes loue þat bad him gode, Þe king answerd wiþ dreri mode ‘Beggere’ he seyd ‘so mot y liue Y no haue here nou?t þe to ?iue.’ ‘Sir’ quaþ þe beggere þo ‘Tel me þan of þi wo Whi þou makest swiche chere.’ Þe king seyd ‘Vlfin no mi?tow here Of þis begger aposeing Þat dar so speke to a king?’ Vlfin þe begger biheld on And him knewe wel sone anon Bi his semblaunt and winking Þat he made opon þe king And seyd ‘Sir par ma fay Þis is a begger of noblay Þou mi?t be þerof ful fawe It is Merlin, þat þou schalt knawe.’ His semblaunt turned anon Merlin Þe king þo hadde ioie fin Of his hors sone he li?t And kist Merlin anon ri?t So dede Vlfin also Michel ioie he made þo. Merlin seyd to þe king ‘Al y knowe þi glosing Y wot þou louest par amour Ygerne þat swete flour, What wiltow ?eue me, ar tomorwe Y schal þe lese out of þi sorwe?’ ‘Merlin’ quaþ þo þe king ‘Help me now in þis þing And þou schalt haue whatow wilt ?erne— Do me to haue swete Ygerne.’ ‘Wiltow me ?iue’ quaþ Merlin ‘Al þe bi?ete þat schal be þine And þou hir haue ar day?’ ‘?a’ quaþ þe king ‘par ma fay.’ ‘Now’ quaþ Merlin ‘þi pais þou held And ar day þou schalt hir weld.’ Þe king was swiþe bliþe þo To his pauiloun he gan go At þe soper þai were glade Michel ioie and mirþe þai made. Ar it day were Merlin hete Þe kinges men arm hem skete And bisett þat castel Where þe douke was Tintagel And tau?t hem gin and eke way Þe castel to win ar ani day. Þai went al to þis asailing Bot Vlfin and Merlin and þe king At hom bileued and bispake Hou þai mi?t of loue take, Merlin bad Vlfin and þe king Riden wiþ him wiþouten duelling So þai deden and riden ?erne Toward þe castel þer was Ygerne, Þo þai þe castel were nei?e Merlin kidde þat he was slei?e Herbes he sou?t and fond And gnidded hem bitvix his hond Þe king he smerd viis and liche And made þe king Tintagel liche Himseluen he made like Iurdains Þat was þe lordes chaumberlains Vlfin he made liche Bretel, And went þo to þe castel. On þe gate loude þai bete Seriaunce com and hem in lete Þai wende it were her seygnour And ladde him in wiþ gret honour For swiche was cloþ bodi and fas, To hir chaumber he nam his pas Þe king ?ede after þo wel swiþe Was he neuer are so bliþe, To þe king þo spac Merlin ‘Spede þe now on nedes þine— Ar þou arise of hir bed Þou worþ swiþe sore adred.’ Þe king þerof nou?t no schrof Ac to Ygerne bed he drof Ygerne wende it were her lord And him afenge wiþ fair acord Þe king no made nou?t long soiour Þat he no plaid wiþ þat flour So oft so his wil was— Þat ich ni?t bi Godes grace Þer was bi?eten hem bitven King Arthour þat noble stren. Þerafter in a litel þrawe A cri þer com her lord was slawe, Þo com Merlin to his bed ‘Arise vp for it is nede And þine men þou schewe þe to! Men seyt þou art to deþ ydo.’ Vp strit þo þe king He no made þer no duelling So we finden on þe boke He kist þe leuedi and leue he toke Into halle he com wel swiþe Al þat folk of him was bliþe For þai wende forsoþe þere Þair owhen lord þat it were: Þe messanger was foule yschent Þat to hem brou?t þat present And oft ycleped foule lei?er, Wiþ gret oþes he gan him swere And seyd he was in þe plas Þo þe castel ynomen was And al þat folk he herd waile For þat erl of Cornwaile. Þe king asked his destrer red And seyd he wold kiþe he nas nou?t ded He priked him forþ out atte gate— Forsoþe it was almost to late For of þe way litel þai ware Þo þai herd, wiþ gret care Þe doukes man Tintagel Com fleinde fram þe castel. Þo þe leuedi herd þis Wo was hir liif ywis For hir lord Tintagel, Sche was bigiled sche wist wel In hir þou?t wele it ran On hir was bi?eten a barn— What for sorwe wat for schame Wers was neuer gentil dame. So we finde in our boke Merlin þo went to a broke Þe king wiþ water þer he wesche His owhen stat he hadde ywis And seþþen he wesche hem boþe to Her owen stat þai hadden also, Þo þai wenten al þre To þe kinges meyne Ri?t so þe day bigan dawe Þai fond Tintagel yslawe, Þerof forsoþe our king Ioie made wiþouten lesing. Long þerafterward verrament Was ymade acordement Bitvene Ygerne and þe king Þurth hei?e mennes conseyling, And þo was iugged wiþouten faile Bi hei?e mennes conseyl— Þe king was iugged Ygerne to spouse Þerof Ygerne was ioiouse. King Nanters of Garlot Þer nam Blasine God it wot Ygerns douhter bi Hoel, Hir lord was bifor Tintagel, In whom he bi?at Galaas Þat strong and hardi and noble was. King Lot þer nam Belisent Also Ygerns douhter gent In whom he seþþe bi?at Wawein And Guerehes and Agreuein And Gaheriet þat was so fre, For better kni?tes no mi?t non be. King Vriens þe þridde nam Þat was king of Schorham In whom he bi?at Ywayns Hende and noble and kni?t certeyns— Þese þre sustren were bi Hoel, And oþer mo bi Tintagel Þat elleswhere were to loke So we finde writen in boke Al four made spouseing Togider and swiþe fair gestening Þer was iustes and turnamens Swiþes noble verramens, Þe fest lasted fourten ni?t To al þat euer come ypli?t. Þo þe fest was ydo Merlin com þe king to And seyd he hadde do þe dede Of gode conseyl and wise rede And seyd ‘Sir biþenke þou þe What þou next ?eue me— Þe child bi?eten in þi quen. Ichil þe telle hou it mot ben: Hir wombe greteþ, þou mi?t toni?t Fele hou it stireþ þat litel wi?t, When þou it feleþ in hir wawe Bid hir sche be biknawe Who so haþ bi hir lay, Þe soþe sche wil sone say; Þat schaltow hir hot ywis So sone so it born is It be yborn to þe gate And ?ouen whom men findeþ þerat, Þer man schal yfinde me To fong þat child þat is so fre. Þou hast a baroun in þi lond Of gentil blod and mi?ti hond Þat is Antour þi baroun heye Þat is a man of gret noblay Þ[at] ha[þ] bi?eten a noble [qu]en And sche is wiþ child so is þe quen, In þis lond nis swiche blode No milk þat haþ half so gode; Pray Antour wiþ wordes milde Þe milke he ?iue to þi childe And ?if he þerof ?iue graunt Our Lord y take to waraunt Þi child worþ þe noblest man Of al þis world an for an— Ac to þi quen be nou?t biknawe Þat þat child be þine awe.’ Þe king swore bi Crist his sire He nold neuer tel it hire, Al he dede so Merlin bad, Þe quen agros and was adrad And seyd ‘Lord wiþ child ich am Not ich neuer who is þe man Bi?eten it was þat ich þrawe Þat mi lord was yslawe, So mot ich proue, and y the, Y wend mi lord it hadde ybe Do wiþ me what þi wille is Þe soþe ich haue yseyd ywis.’ ‘Dame’ he seyd ‘no drede nou?t þe Al þe gilt y for?iue þe Wiþ þat at when þou child hast Þou do nim þat child on hast Do bere it to þe gate And ?iue it whom þou findeþ þerat Þat y no here þerof tidinge Neuer eft more wiþouten lesing.’ ‘Sir’ sche seyd ‘bleþeliche It schal be don sikerliche.’ Þe king þerafter amorwe aros And osent sir Antour of gret los, Þo he was comen þe king him nam And al his men ladde him fram And gan his priuete vnhele, And þat he it schuld hele; He seyd he hadde bi?eten a child And teld him hou wiþ tale milde ‘Late’ he seyd ‘þi wiif it loke, Of hir milk and ?iue it souke, And þou schalt haue riche mede Brod londes and hei?e stede.’ Þe king vnneþe al þis bi?at Þe quen childed after þat A fair knaue a gentil bi?ate Þat was born to þe gate An old hore man it was bitake So we finden in þe blake It was Merlin þat him afeng Forþ he ?ede wiþouten lesing To a chirche he went, wiþ honour And dede þat child cristen Arthour, After he went swiþe And bar it to sir Antoris wiue A-childbed he hir fond And tok it hir in þe hond And bad it hir loke wiþ mild mode ‘Þi mede schal be riche and gode.’ Merlin went anon oway No sei?e no man him after, mani a day. Antors wiif child hete Cay Sche dede it fram hir oway And lete souke Artouret Þat milk was wel bisett He wex fair and wele yþei And was a child of gret noblay He was curteys hende and gent And wi?t and hardi verrament Curteyslich and fair he spac Wiþ him was non iuel lac. His fader he mi?t oft ysen Ac him no knewe neuer þe quen NArtour no mi?t neuer wite Þat þe king him hadde bi?ete While þe king was libbeing So ich in þe brout yfinde Ac his fader wele he wende Were Antour þe kni?t hende. His moder starf so God wold And richeliche was brou?t in mold, Afterward long þe king In bedde fel in gret sekeling And was ycomen ri?t to his fin, Ri?t þo bifor him stode Merlin Þe king quiked anon ri?t Þo he had of Merlin si?t, He asked where he hadde yben Þat he no mi?t him fer ysen, He seyd ‘Fer hennes saun fail. Now is to comen mi trauail, Þou schal be dede sone ywis And wenden into heuen-blis Þi sone after worþ king Bi Godes grace and min helping Bi wos day worþ don alle Þe meruails of þe sengreal.’ Þe king herof lete ful gode And þonked God wiþ mild mode Merlin fram him went oway Þe king starf þat ich day, For him wepen lowe and hei?e Swiþe sore wiþ her ei?e Þe holy bischop þat hi?t Brice For him dede þe office In erþe he was sikerliche Layd swiþe nobeliche. After his enterement Þai gan make a parlement To whiche parlement was yfet Al þat hadde power gret Of þis lond al about Þider com wel gret rout Of kinges erls baroun and kni?t Princes doukes mani ypli?t, Non no wist hem among Þat Arthour of þe king sprong Bot sir Antor and sir Vlfin And þe gode clerk Merlin, Ac for in spouse he nas bi?ete No man no most it wite. Þis parlement last mani a day To chese a king of gret noblay To þe hei?e and to þe lawe To gouern hem in her lawe Ac þai no mi?t nou?t acord For ich of hem wold be lord, Þis last half ?er so Þat þai no mi?t comen at on þo. On Cristenmesse-euen þe bischop Brice Kid þat he nas nou?t nice Þer he was among hem alle Þis wise he gan hem calle ‘Lordinges’ he seyd ‘?e no may acord Forto chese ?ou a lord Þerfore y pray for loue of Crist Wircheþ now bi gin and list It is a wel gode time apli?t. To chirche goþ al toni?t And pray to Crist so gode and fre A king ous sende þat bihouesum be To þe ri?t o?ains þe wrong, He graunt to chesen ous among And þat we haue þerof tokening Tomorwe at our seruise ending And þat it so mi?t ben’ And euerichon seyden ‘Amen.’ Þus þer ?ede more and lasse Ani?t to chirche amorwe to masse And maden solempne bisecheinge Forto haue a ri?tful kinge And þo þe seruise don was Outward þai wenten her pas— Tofor þe chirche-dore þai founde A ston stonden on þe grounde Long and hei?e forsoþe to say Þerin a swerd of gret noblay, King and douke baroun and kni?t Ich hadde wonder of þat si?t Þe bischop com and it sey?e And þonked Ihesu Crist on hei?e. Ichil wele þat ?e it wite On þe pomel was ywrite ‘Icham yhot Estalibore Vnto a king fair tresore’ (On Inglis is þis writeing ‘Kerue stiel and iren and al þing’).
