Þe bischop seyd to hem anon ‘Þis swerd who drawe of þe ston He schal be our king ymade Bi Godes wille and our rade’— Þai ?aue al herto concentement. King Lot proued verrament Out it to drawe anon ri?t Ac he no mi?t for alle his mi?t, King Nanters no king Clarion No mi?t it drawe out of þe ston No no gentil man of priis No mi?t it ones stiren ywis. Þider com ich noble blod And to Candelmesse þer it stode, Al þat was born in Inglond On þis swerd cast his hond Ac for liif no for deþe Þai no mi?t it stir vnneþe, Þer it stode til Ester-tide; Þider tocomen men ful wide Fram þis half se and eke bi?onde And nou?t þai sped bi Godes sond, And ?ete it stode to Pentecost; Þer com þider mani an ost To turnaien in þat tide Almost fast þerbiside. Kay his sone, sir Antour Him made kni?t wiþ gret honour— Þis Kay it was þat nas nou?t late Forto souken his moder tate Ac Arturet forsoþe it seke Þat bicom mild and meke; Kay was swiþe noble kni?t, Ac he stamered a litel wi?t Þat he it hadde in nortoure Þurth þe norices coure. Arthour had serued Lot Swiþe long wele y wot, Ac þo Cay was kni?t ymade Sir Antor ?af to Kay rade Forto ofsende Arthour o?ein Forto make of him his swain For he was hardi trewe and trest, Of al þis lond and ?ong man best; Kay was swiþe wele ypaid Al was don þat Antor seyd Arthour com hom and was wiþ Kay, And went hem to þat turnay. Þer Kay contend him apli?t So a wele doinde kni?t Boþe at side and at ende He feld kni?tes swiþe hende; Þo he com amidward About he leyd on so hard Þat his swerd brast atvo, Anon he bad Arthour þo ‘To mi leuedi swiþe hende— Anoþer swerd bid hir me sende.’ And so he dede wiþouten abode Swiftliche hom he rode, His leuedi finde he no mi?t O?ain he went anon ri?t And to þe swerd in þe ston Wel ri?t he gan forto gon No man was þer verrament Ac alle weren at þe turnament. Arthour tok þe hilt bi hond Þe swerd out drawe he gan fond— Ac for nou?t out it cam. In his hond he it nam His hors he lepe vp anon To þe turnay he com son And seyd ‘Haue þis swerd sir Kay Þi leuedi finden y no may.’ Kay þis swerd wele knewe ywis To Arthour he seyd ‘Where hadestow þis?’ ‘Certes’ quaþ Arthour ‘herbi?onde In a ston ich it fond’ (Arthour no sei?e it neuer ar No wist neuer why it stode þar). Sir Kay seyd þo to Arthour ‘Telle it to no man par amour Þat þou þis swerd out drou? And þou schal haue gode ynou?,’ Arthour seyd ‘Certes nay.’ Forþ went anon sir Kay And ledde his fader sir Antour To þe chirche of seyn Sauour And seyd ‘Ichaue þis swerd out drawe Þat ich be king it is lawe.’ Sir Antor biheld þat sword And seyd at þe first word ‘Þou gabbest me bi God aboue! ?if þou say soþ eft þou it proue For bifor þis hei?e men Þou most it pelt in o?en And bot þou mi?test drawe it out Þe wold schame berd and snout.’ Þai wenten boþe to þe ston And Kay pelt it in anon Ac þei he war strong and wi?t Drawe it out he no mi?t, Þo bispac him sir Antour ‘Telle me sone par amour Who it was þis swerd out drou?,’ And þo stode sir Kay and lou? ‘Sir’ he seyd ‘bi Godes sond Arthour toke it me in hond.’ Antor cleped Arthour þo And dede him to þe ston go And boþe swiþe and eke soft In and out he pelt it oft, Antor was hereof ful bliþe And drou? Arthour to chirche swiþe And seyd to him priueliche þo ‘Arthour listen now me to, Seþþen þou were born verrament Ich haue ?ouen þe norisement’ And þer he teld him al þe cas Hou he bi?eten and born was Hou his fader was þe king And hou þurth his bisecheing ‘Kay mi sone a norice y toke And þou mi wiues tate soke.’ Þo seyd Antor ‘Nim coure Mi sone þou art þurth norture It nis no ri?t þat þou me werne Ri?tfulliche þat y wil ?erne Ich pray þe graunt me a bone Þat ich þe wil axi sone— Ich þe wil help, sone Arthour, King to ben wiþ michel honour.’ Þo bispac Arthour þe hende ‘Crist of heuen me defende Þat ich þe wern ani þing Of what þou makest axing.’ ‘God þe for?eld’ seyd sir Antour ‘Now y þe pray par amour Þi steward make mi sone Kay, So long so þou liue may In nesse in hard y pray þe nowe In al stedes þou him avowe— And y schal þe help in þis nede Þurth Godes help þat þou schalt spede.’ Þo bispac him sir Arthour ‘Y graunt þi wil sir Antour Þat Kay þi sone be mi steward, Y schal him avowe in nesse and hard, When ich euer faile Kay Crist me for?ete þat day.’ Forþ ?ede Antor anon ri?t And sir Arthour made kni?t, First he fond him cloþ and cradel Þo he fond him stede and sadel Helme and brini and hauberioun Gaumbers quissers and aketoun Quarre scheld gode swerd of stiel And launce stef biteand wel, Þer he ?aue him anon ri?tes To his seruise fourti kni?tes, Amorwe þai went to turnament And so þer dede verrament Þat ich day sir Arthour Þe los he bar and þe honour. Amorwe Antor þat was nou?t nice Went to þe bischop Brice And teld him he wist a kni?t Boþe gent and noble apli?t ‘Þat schuld be our king wiþ lawe For he may þat swerd out drawe.’ Þe bischop was herof bliþe And sent after Arthour swiþe, Toforn al þe hei?e of þe lond Arthour tok þe swerd in hond He drou? it out and pelt o?en Wonder hadde mani men For no man stiren it no mi?t Bot he on y ?ou pli?t. King and erls wiþouten dout Þer gun him anon rebout Forto prouen his maner Ac euer he was of milde chere No couþe her non better deuise Þan he hem answerd in al wise, Sir Antor him halp also Þat he was king chosen þo And þer was boden to his gestening Mani prince and mani king, Al þat euer com wold At seyn Ion tide com schold. Merlin com hem bitven Sir Arthour þe prince to sen Of whos come miche blis Sir Arthour made ywis, Swiþe anon hete Merlin Men schuld ofsende þe douke Vlfin Sir Iordains and sir Bretel Þat hadde yben wiþ Tintagel. Al þre þai comen swiþe Merlin was þerof wel bliþe Merlin seyd ‘Y wil ?e wite Hou þat Arthour was bi?ete’— Þer he told hem ende and ord Of his bi?ete eueri word Wharof Vlfin wittnes bar And seyd certes þat he was þar And Antor bar witnesse þerto And seyd þe king him seyd so. Þo loued Iordains and sir Bretel Sir Arthour wiþ hert lel For loue of Ygerne fre Her leuedi þat hadde ybe His men þo þai bicomen swiþe To help him vp deþe and liue, Þis barouns and eke Merlin Wenten to þe bischopes in And al him teld fair and ?erne Hou Arthour was bi?eten of Ygerne, Þe bischop þonked God so gode Þat he was of þe kinges blode. Merlin seyd ‘Listen meruaile ?ou is comand strong bataile Kinges sex at þis fest Þer schul arere michel chest Wharefore ?e schul þan wite wel Boþe in iren and in stiel And loke þat ichon held wiþ oþer As ich man schal wiþ his broþer For ich ?ou bihot al þe honour Schal bileue wiþ ?ou and wiþ Arthour,’ Þar þai biheten þat non nold Oþer fail for no gold, Þe bischop seyd his helping He schuld haue in al þing. What helpeþ it make tale long? Þai hem poruaid alle among Swiþe redi alle þing Þat schuld to þat coroning. Mirie it is in time of Iune When fenel hongeþ abrod in toun Violet and rose-flour Woneþ þan in maidens bour Þe sonne is hot þe day is long Foule[s] make miri song— King Arthour bar coroun In Cardoile þat noble toun. King Lot þat spoused Belisent Com to þis coronment (He held þe lond of Lyoneis Man wel strong and curteys) Wiþ fiue hundred noble kni?tes Hardi and strong and leue to fi?tes. King Nanters com God it wot Þat held þe lond of Garlot Swiþe noble man and wi?t And wele couþe fende him in fi?t He hadde yspoused Blasine Arthours soster fair and dine, Seuen hundred kni?tes y telle þe He brou?t wiþ him of meyne, Of noble destre[r]s and stede Þat swiþe gode were at nede. King Vrien com þerto, Þe þridde suster hadde also Þe lond of Gorre he held ywis He was ?ong man of noble pris XX þousand he brou?t and fiue No better kni?tes nere oliue. Þer com ?ete king Carodas Þe king of Strangore he was A swiþe mi?ti man of mounde And kni?t of þe tabel rounde, Þei he fer hadde yride VI hundred kni?tes he brou?t him mide Þat wele couþe iuste in feld Wiþ stef launce vnder scheld. ?ete þer com king Yder King of þe marche of gret pouwer Wiþ him he brou? pritti score Wi?t kni?tes him bifore. Þer com king Angvisant King he was of Scotlant Of al þe sex he was richest Of grete power and ?ongest V hundred he brou?t wiþ him ywis Wi?t and strong kni?tes and al Scottis. And mani oþer bi souþe and bi est Þider com to þat fest, King and baroun y ?ou say Welcomed hem wiþ gret noblay Biforn hem al þe bischop Brice Arthour crouned and dede þe office; Þo þe seruise ydon was To mete þai turned her pas Þai founde al redi cloþ and bord Vp first ?ede þe hei?est lord Men hem serued of gret plente Mete and drink of gret deynte Þer was venisoun of hert and bors Swannes pecokes and botors Of fesaunce pertris and of crane Þer was plente and no wane Þer was piment and clare To hei?e lordinges and to meyne Þai hadden also noble seruise So ani man couþe devise; Þo þai hadde yeten alle Hei?e and lowe in þe halle To ?euen ?iftes sir Arthour aros To hei?e men of grete los And to haue of hem vmage So it was ri?t and her vssage. As he was fair doinde þis King Lot king Nanters and oþer of priss Of his ?iftes spite hadden And his coroun anon wiþradden, Vp þai sterten wiþ gret bost Euerich king wiþ al his ost And seyd an herlot for noþing No schuld neuer ben her king And þou?t wiþ gret deshonour Forto misdo sir Arthour, Ac Arthour men bitven þrest— Forþ com Merlin in þat chest And seyd he nas harlot non Ac nobler þan her ani on; Þer he teld, al hem bifore, Hou Arthour was bi?eten and bore. Þe wise men of þat lond Þonked Ihesu Cristes sond Þat her king schuld ben Of Vter Pendragouns stren; Þe barouns seyd to Merlin ‘He was founde þurth wiching þin, Traitour’ þai seyd ‘verrament For al þine enchauntement No schal neuer no hores stren Our king no heued ben Ac he schal sterue ri?t anon’— Toward þe king and gun gon. Þe king was armed swiþe wel And alle his frende in iren [and] stiel, O?ain wiþstonden nobliche And al out driuen sikerliche Wiþ swerdes and kniues sone anon Out of halle þe kinges fon. Þe sex kinges were wel wroþe And al her barouns sworen her oþe No schuld þai neuer tviis eten Er þai of Arthour were awreken And swiþe telt her pauiloun A litel wiþouten Cardoil toun. Þe bischop stode on þe castel-wal And gan to preche to hem alle And seyd Arthour was kinges stren Of king bi?eten and born of quen Þe king it wist in his liue Blisced his child and bad him þriue And tok him to sir Antour To norice wiþ gret honour, ?if þai wisten nei?er blod To make him king it nar nou?t gode ‘Ac for he is king and kinges sone Y cors al mididone His enemis wiþ Cristes mouþe Bi est bi west bi norþ and souþe!’— ‘Tprut!’ þai seyden euerichon. Merlin went adoun anon And Arthours frende anon ri?t He told, hei?e and lowe ypli?t, Four þousand among hem he fond Hardi and noble and wi?t of hond Ac alle it were forsoþe fotmen Bot fiftene score and ten, Þe oþer were so gret rout Þat þai wrei?e þe cuntre about. Merlin bad hem noþing drede ‘Bot alle doþ bi mi rede,’ Wiþ him þai went to þe gate anon Wele atired euerichon, Merlin made enchauntement And kest gret encumberment Into þe pauilou[n]s, wild fer Þat brent bri?t so candel cler, And seyd to hem euerichon ‘Now sle swiþe ?our fon!’ Forþ þai went on hors gode To þe pauilouns þat on fer stode And on her fomen smiten anon O liue þai reften mani on Wiþ scharpe speres and swe[r]des kene Tventi score and fiftene O liue-dawe þai brou?ten þere Er þai wist where þai were For her witt was oway go For þe fer þat brent so— And þe oþer her wit binam fulliche Þat com on hem so sodanliche. Þer were so fele naþeles Þat litel sen þe slau?ter wes Ac þurth þis encumbrement Þai flowen alle verrament Til þai com fer oway A mile þennes in o valay; Þer wiþstode þis sex kinges O?ain Arthour wiþ fi?tinges, And her folke wenten o?en Mo þan ten þousand of men Fram þis contek þat were ascaped Sore adrad and awaped. Þe kinges gadred hem togider alle And seyd gret schame hem was bifalle Þat Arthour wiþ a litel punay Hadde ydriuen hem oway, Euerich to oþer þus made his mon ?if þai were of Arthour on Awreken alle þai hadde wonne, Alle þai swore bi mone and sonne Hye schulden abigge þat ich striif— And went o?ain als biliif. Nanter þe king of Garlot Biforn he went God it wot He was a wele limed kni?t Hardi and strong and wise in fi?t, A stef launce he bar an hond Wiþ spores he smot his stede strong, Arthour sei?e where he cam A stef launce anon he nam His fet in þe stiropes he strei?t Þe stirop tobent (þe hors aquei?t) Þe stede he smot and he forþ glode O?aines þe king Nanters he rode. Nanters him mett amid þe feld And hitt Arthour on þe schelde Þat his launce gan to riue And tobrast on peces fiue, Arthour smot so Nanters þo Þat his scheld brak atvo And of his hors so him cast Þat almast his nek tobrast. Þo king Lot sei?e þis Hou his nevou was feld ywis (He was on of þe strongest man Of al þis lond an for an) A launce he tok of gret valour And smot his stede o?ain Arthour, Euerich gan oþer wiþ launces take Þat al to peces þai gun crake Wiþ so gret ire togider þai mett Þat her bodis togider stet, So astoned was king Lot He lese his sadel God it wot And ouer þe croupe of his stede To grounde he fel þat he gan blede. Arthour aforced, him to dere, Ac michel folk com him to were Þer come swiþe michel route To slen Arthour al aboute, Arthour drou? his swerd anon Þat he drou? out of þe ston A kni?t he toke wiþ þe egge Þat him clef heued and rigge Into þe sadel so seyt þe bok Al he hirt þat he toke So sore he leyd on al aboute Þat þai his dintes gun doute. Þis to kinges weren arisen Þat were first of him agrisen Þai and her feren four Wiþ four launces smiten Arthour Al at ones (þat was no glewe) And Arthour stede adoun þrewe Þe king bineþen þe stede aboue Forsoþe sir Arthour was aswowe. Sir Antour al þis ysay Bretel Vlfi[n] and sir Kay Þai com swiþe to þis rideing Forto helpen her king; Kay ful ri?t bigan to bere To king Angvisaunt a spere He smot him þurthout þe scheld And his hauber felefeld And þurth his scholder an ellen long And of his hors to grounde he þrong, And ?ete he feld verrament King Carodas wiþ þat dent— Þat was a dint of gret mounde Þat tvay kinges þrewe to grounde. Vlfin and Nanters met þo Þat her launces brosten atvo Togider wiþ bodis þai metten Þat boþe to grounde þai stetten Þe hors hem lay anoward Þat hem þou?t chaunce hard, Antor wiþ launce þe king Yder To grounde bar of his destrer, Bretel and king Vrien Her launces brust hem bitven, Þerwhiles king Lot wiþ gret rout To sle Arthour he was about. Kay his steward ysei?e þis He was nei?e of his witt ywis Wiþ his swerd he gan him stere His ?ong lord forto were Wiþ pure strengþe of swerdes dint King Lot he feld verrament And was about, him to slen Ac oþer stirt hem bitven, Þer kidde Kay þat he was wi?t For he no feined neuer of fi?t Til þat Arthour y ?ou pli?t Was opon his stede di?t, And þo he was opon his stede Wiþ swerd he gan about rede Sum he binam scholder and arm And sum þe liif—it nas non harm— Non no durst abide more His stroke for he smot so sore. Her ?e schul vnderstond Þat men o fot of þis lond Helden wiþ king Arthour And dede him wel gret honour Wiþ axes staues and wiþ bowe Dede so þat alle þe oþer flowe, And þis kinges flowen also. Arthour after hem gan to go And so he rode wel fele he feld Þat no more no tale teld, He ouertok þe king Yder And wold him heued wiþ his swerd cler Ac a litel forbi he smot, His hors he hit God it wot Þe nek he karf adoun to grounde Doun fel Yder bi Godes mounde; O?ain turned þo kinges fiue And halp him oway wiþ þe liue Ac ich ?ou swere in þat rideing Þai lau?t woundes wel sore biteing Yder þai keuerd naþeles, And þo he brou?t on hors wes Þai flowen also swiþe anon As her steden mi?ten gon And swore al wiþ wordes flegge King Arthour it schuld abigge. King Arthour þo went o?en Togider he gadred al his men And depar[te]de wiþ hem þe tresour Þat he wan, wiþ gret honour, And þo he þonked þe King of glorie Þat him hadde ?ouen þe victorie To ouercomen his fomen. Into Cardoil he went o?en And held fest noble and gent Wiþ his meyne verrament Of al þat euer wald þider gon, Curteyseliche were ressaiued anon, Þis fest last fourteni?t Þat was riche and noble apli?t. Þo þe fest was ydo Merlin com þe king to To Londen he bad him hei?e And þer schewe his curteisie And when he com þer saun fayl He wold him schewe gret conseil Ac nou?t ar he had fest ymade, To al þe lond and made ful glade; King Arthour dede his conseyl And went to Londen saun fail Where þe king sir Arthour Was afong wiþ gre[t] honour. Sone after seyn Iones misse Þe king lete bidden more and lesse Into Londen to his fest Swiche he made and held onest Þurth þe conseyl of Merlin; He seriaunted þo þurth him— Merlin tok þo to ich mester Þat slei?e were and of power. Þo drou? bi half þe clerk Merlin Þe king Arthour and eke Vlfin And Bretel and sir Antour And Kay þe steward of valour And seyd ‘Listen to me now For soþe ichil telle ?ou: XI kinges and doukes on Han ysworn Arthour to slon Swiche is now her parlement Now in þe marche verrament, O?aines hem ?e no haue no mi?t Bot ?e hauen help to fi?t Y wil ?ou telle what do ?e mote ?if ?e wil finden bote. Mi lord Vter Pendragon Wan vnder him þe king Ban And his broþer Bohort also No better bodis no mowe go Þai were sworn to Vter mi lord, To hem ich rede sende word To lesse Breteine, for it is nede, Þat Vter Pendragon is dede, ?e mot hem sigge verrament Þat he vnto þis parlement Wiþouten abod wel swiþe come To don vmage Arthour his sone; Þai wil comen anon y wot And help þe o?ain king Lot And elleswhere [wiþ] her power, ?ou worþ to hem wel gret mister Herafterward par ma fay— Ichil ?ou tel som day. Þis message sir Vlfin Þou most bere bi conseil min And þi fere schal be sir Bretel Loke ?e ben atired wel Wiþ gode armes on gode stede, Þerto ?ou worþ a litel nede Ar ?e comen o?ain to ous— Now hei?eþ ?ou for loue of Ihesus!’ Al þis hem liked wel And sir Vlfin and sir Bretel Wele hem atired sikerliche And went forþ wel hastiliche. Þo þai com þe se bi?ounde A gret wildernisse þai founde Bitven Fraunce and Breteyne Þai sei?e mani mounteyn and pleine, Þo þai sei?e a litel hem aboue Seuen kni?tes yarmed come Of wiche to her steden smiten And to hem-ward gun priken Wiþ loude cri and bad hem ?eld. Bretel tok his launce and scheld Þat o kni?t sone he mett And wiþ his scharp launce him gret He bar him þurth þe þrote anon Þat ded he fel, ded so ston; Þat oþer he mett o?ainward A dint he ?af him so hard Þe launce ran þe brini þurth Þe kni?t fel ded in a forwe, In his falling brast þe spere— Bretel bar it no ferþere. Oþer to þer come glide Vlfin gan o?ain hem ride Opon a stede stef and strong Wiþ a launce gret and long Þat on he bar þurth scheld and hat Þat neuer seþþen mete no at, Þe oþer o?ain Vlfin brac his spere Ac he no mi?t Vlfin dere Vlfin him ?aue a din[t] of wo Þurthout þe membre and sadel also, Stede and kni?t ouerþrewe anon Þe kni?t brast his nek-bon, Vlfines launce tobrac. Þe þre come þo gret rac Þe oþer foure forto wreken Þe þre gun her launces breken And her noiþer hirt nou?t; Bretel kidde þat he was au?t His swerd he drou?, þat on he hit His heued fram þe bodi he kit, Þat oþer oftoke sir Vlfin And so him hit on þe bacin Þat he him cleue to þe toþ So ous seyt þe brout forsoþ Þe oþer kni?t her lord þat was Wel swiþe went o?ain his pas— ?if he abod ani longere Wele he sei?e it was his lere. Þis ich kni?tes four and þre Wiþ Claudas hadde ybe Wiþ Claudas hadde werred o?an Þe king Bohort and þe king Ban; Claudas was þo ouercome, Priueliche and went to Rome Him to puruay sum socour To wreke him of his deshonour Þerwhile þo kni?tes cert Were ywent into desert To libben bi her robrie— Ac þer hem fel gret vilanie. Þerafter Vlfin forþ him rode And eke Bretel wiþouten abod No lete þai neuer iornaying Til þai com to Ban þe king And þo he com bifor Ban Þus his wordes he bigan: ‘[I]hesus Crist Heuen-king Þe loke sir Ban þe king And þi meine so gent and fre Þat ich here about þe se! Þe barouns of Breteine þe more Tiding þe sent þat reweþ hem sore Vter Pendragon þi lord is ded And is departed þurth Godes red King is made his sone Arthour And þe greteþ wiþ gret honour And bad þe and [þi] broþer gent Com to his parlement Forto wite and vnderstond Of þe lawes of his lond.’ King Ban wiþ noble cher Welcomed þo messanger And seyd her wil do he wold And his broþer also schold, Þe messangers þo he made Wele at ese wiþ gret ferrade Bohort þer after swiþe he sent, Bi on asent and swiþe went Into þis lond wiþ mani fair Forto se þe kinges air. In euerich toun fram Portesmouþe To Londen of gret valoure Men made song and hopinges O?ain þe come of þis kinges No was wonded for drie no wete Þat i[n] lond eueri strete Was bihonged ich say forsoþ Wiþ mani pal and riche cloþ, Euerich man of ich mester Hem riden o?ain wiþ fair ater In euerich strete damisels Karols ledden fair and fels. Þo þai were to court ycome Þai were hendeliche welcome, Himselue þe king Arthour Hem com o?ain wiþ gret honour, Curteiseliche and hem gan calle And anon ledde hem to halle Wiþ her broþer Gvinbaut Noble clerk so Dieu me saut In þe sterres he was þe best deuine In al þe warld wiþouten Merlin. Þer atwot þe clerk Merlin At þe fest þe douke Vlfin And Bretel þat was his felawe Hou þai hadde þe kni?tes yslawe, Ac al þat euer herden þis Wonder hadde þerof ywis Þat he told her bataile And þer no com nou?t saun faile And namliche Bohort and Ban And Gvinbaut þe þridde man; Þere þo men mi?t yhere Þe queintise of þe spere Of þe sonne of mone and ster, When þe welken turned of herre, And of mani priue werk Bitven Merlin and Gvimbaut þe clerk. Herafter sone Merlin swore And sir Vlfin and sir Antore And sir Kay and sir Bretel Tofore þe king on o messel Þat Arthour was Vter stren Bi Ygerne þat was his quen, Þerafterward sone forsoþ Þe kinges swore Arthour hold-oþ And deden him also swiþe omage So it was ri?t and vsage, And þo held Arthour fest apli?t Þat last ful fourten ni?t Of ich riches and deinte Certes þer was gret plente. Þo was þer made a turnament Þat was swiþe noble and gent Of bacheler and ?ong kni?t Swiþe strong and swiþe wi?t, Þo þat were of ?ond half O?ain þo weren of þis half. Þe best was Lucan þe boteler A ?ong kni?t of grete power, Wiþouten þe steward Kay (He was a kni?t of gret noblay), Grimfles Maruc and Guinas (Ich of hem wel noble was) Placides and eke Driens Holias and Graciens Marliaus and Flaundrins Sir Meliard and eke Drukins And also Breober[i]is Þese born oway þe priis, No man no herd of fairer Turnament no nobler. Þo al þis mirþe was ydo Merlin com þe king to And to hem seyd ‘Bieu sengours ?e ben yswore to king Arthours ?e mot boþe wiþ him ride To Leodegan of Carmalide For bi mi rede he schal spouse Gvenour his douhter precious Sche is boþe fair and wise Of al þe lond sche berþ þe priis; Hir fader Leodegan Is a swiþe noble man Ac king Rion wiþouten lesinges Him werreþ opon wiþ tventi kinges, Þere ?e mot him help ywis Forto win los and pris.’ ‘Certes’ quaþ king Ban þe gent ‘Þerto we han gret talent ?if king Claudas in our lond Þerwhiles nold ous wait no schond For he ous haþ werred long Wiþ vnri?t and michel wrong.’ ‘Nay’ quaþ Merlin ‘drede ?ou nou?t ?if þou lesest þerfore ou?t For þe mountaunce of pani on Þou schalt han hundred o?an.’ ‘To þat couenaunt’ quaþ Ban þe king ‘We beþ redi in al þing Anon to go wiþ king Arthour To his manschipe and his honour.’ Merlin seyd ‘Bi seyn Ion Arst ?e mot anoþer don, XI kinges and a douke Beþ hiderward wiþouten dout To slen Arthour and his man In þe forest of Rokeingham Þere ?e mot help him were Vnder scheld wiþ swerd and spere.’ ‘Allas’ quaþ Ban ‘for Cristes sond We no haue no folk of our lond,’ Quaþ Merlin ‘So God me spede No schal ?ou faile non at nede.’ Þer it was forboden anon Ich man bi way forto gon Noiþer mile tene no fiue Opon pain of her liue; Þis was don for non oþer þing Bot for aspies andwaiteing, Whereþurth alle weren yhent Þat fram þe barouns weren ysent And non com o?ain verrament To wray þe kinges parlement. ?ete Merlin went to Rokingham (Vlfin and oþer wiþ him he nam) Mani pauilouns and telt And dede þerin flesches and selt And oþer store of mele and win And tok it to lok sir Vlfin And bad he no schuld lete passe Noiþer þe more no þe lasse Þat mi?t bere ani tiding To þe barouns of her king No of his parlement— No þai no deden verrament. Þo ?ede Merlin to Ban þe king And tok of him his kinges ring And to king Bohort also, To lasse Breteine he ?ede þo Ouer þe se in on ni?t Fele iurnes y ?ou pli?t For in þe brut ich it lerne To Leonce of Paerne Þat was kinges Banes steward A wise man wiþ hore bard And to Farien wel noble kni?t Bohortes steward þat was apli?t And schewed hem her lordes ring And bad þai schuld him socour bring; Leonce and eke Farien Togider brou?ten her men Fourti þousand þat were teld On stede in armes swiþe beld, XV þousende þai leten þere Her lond to kepen and to were And xxv þousend wiþ him toke So we finden in þe boke Wiche ouer se þe clerk Merlin Brou?t and loged bi Vlfin. To kinges court he gan þo fare And asked ?if þai weren ?are For her fomen were nei?ehond, King Ban seyd ‘For Godes sond Whi no hastow brou?t me socour?’ Merlin seyd ‘Al rady to ?our honour’— Þo þai di?t hem swain and kni?t And wenten þider þat ich ni?t. Þo þai þider weren ycome Ordeind and teld her þrome Fourti þousand men þai founde To batail men of gret mounde; Michel ioie made king Ban And Bohort also of her man For þai deden þere finde XXV þousinde, Arthour hadde þousandes fiftene And namo also y wene, For al þe barouns and þe kinges Were in þe marche wiþouten lesinges Wiþ al þe men y ?ou say Þat þai mi?t hem puruay. To slen Arthour lasse and more Al þai hadde togider swore Ac forsoþe non of hem No wist of Arthoures men Ac we finden in þe boke Þat þai hadde þer bispoke On Arthour wiþ her route Þai wold happen al aboute And hem to taken in þe forest When þai sei?en time best. To, þis tresoun forto don, Com þe king Clarion Þat was king of Norþhumberlond Wiþ seuen þousand kni?tes strong. King Brangores þat held Strangore Þider com bi Godes ore And brou?t wiþ him fiue þousand kni?t In bataile þat were strong and wi?t. Cradelman king of Norþ Wales Hardi man and wise of tales Sex þousend þider he brou?t Of liue or deþe þat litel rou?t. A king þer com, ‘of an hundred kni?tes’ His name was cleped bi ri?tes For he no ladde neuer lasse rout Þan an hundred kni?tes about, He was king wel fer bi norþ A wel strong man and michel worþ Kni?tes he brou?t four þousinde Men no mi?t non better finde. King Lot þat held londes tvo Leonis and Dorkaine also He brou?t seuen þousend kni?tes Swiþe hardi and stronge in fi?tes. ?ete þer com king Carodas Þat of þe rounde table was Seuen þousand he brou?t also No better kni?tes no mi?t go. Nanters þe king of Garlot Þider com God it wot Vp Arthour, þat was wroþ and grim Sex þousinde he brou?t wiþ him Stronge kni?tes and noble saun faile Þat wise and hardi were in bataile. ?ete þer come king Vrien Wiþ sex þousand of wi?t men Wele atired on gode destrers, Wiþouten fotmen and squiers. ?ete þer com king Yder Wiþ fiue þousand of gret power. ?ete þer com king Angvisaunt Þe riche king of Scotlaunt Wiþ sex þousende kni?tes, beld Boþe in toun and eke in feld. ?ete þer come þe douc Estas Erl of Canbernic he was (Arundel was hoten þo Cambernic wiþouten no) He brou?t wiþ him þousandes fiue Non better nere oliue. Alle þese priueliche To Rokingham com sikerliche And loged hem in þe forest Stille wiþouten ani chest Wiþ al þat þai procoure mi?t Boþe of baroun and of kni?t, Ac Arthour was wel stilly Wiþ his folk nei?e hem bi— Noiþer baroun no king Nist nou?t of his being. Þe fertþ ni?t after her soiour Merlin bad þe king Arthour And Bohort and king Ban Hem atiren and her man And com wiþ him anon ri?tes And kiþe ?if þai were noble kni?tes; Boþe in iren and in stiel Þai hem armed swiþe wel, Ar day þre mile-way And wiþ Merlin went y say. In þis time Lot þe king In bed was in gret meteing, Him þou?t water winde and rain In her teþ was hem o?ain Her pauilouns ouerþrewe þe þonder; He ofwoke and had wonder His sweuen he teld his feren hard Þai him axed whiderward Him þou?t þat his sweuen bar, Þe soþe anon he teld þar. Þiderward wel swiþe an hye Þai senten spies forto aspie Þis spies anon forþ stetten And wiþ Merlin sone metten And wiþ Arthour king of los, Of þat meteing hem agros. Merlin hem sei?e and bad hem bide, Fleand oway þai gun ride And euer grad ‘Traisoun traisoun!’ Þe oþer herof herd þe soun And hem atired verrament Ac Merlin cast enchauntment Þat her pauilouns on and alle To þe grounde gun to falle And so ich in þe boke yfinde Þe mest part he made blinde, King Arthour and Bohort and Ban Opon hem smiten onan And eke alle her ferrede Wiþ hors fete on hem trede Wiþ speres stong wiþ swerdes korwe Ten þousende kni?tes bi þe morwe Ar ani of hem mi?t hem stere Oþer sen abouten, hem to were. Ac naþeles þis xi kinges Flowen oway wiþ michel genge A litel þennes intil a lowe; A loude horn þai gun blowe, Of her kni?tes and gaderd hem so Togider þritti þousende and mo. Ich king [hadde] to his dale Þre þousand gret and smale, Her hors girten and sadels ri?t And made hem redi forto fi?t On þe hille þai gun ten Arthour and his folk to sen Þo sei?e þai seuen baners, Of whiche Lucan þe boteler Of þe first maister was For swiþe hardi man he was, Grifles ladde þe secounde A wi?t man of gret mounde, Þe þridde folc ladde Bretel Strong [kni?t] and doinde wel, Þe ferþ baner ladde Kay Þe kinges steward of noblay, Þe fift baner ladde Vlfin A noble baroun gode afin, Ich hadde of þis to his baner Þre þousand of gret power; Arthour on hors sat stef so stok And gouerned þe seuend flok And ladde wiþ him four þousinde Wi?t men and wel doinde. Þe oþer no mi?t ben ykidde Bihinden hem þai weren yhidde. King Lot king Nanters and king Vrien And king Carodas wiþ his men Þis foure bihinde were And lete þe oþer al forþ fare, And in þe sonnes vpriseing Bigan certes þis rideing Þer mi?t men se þe baners roten Þe stedes forþ wel ?ern schoten, Þo þai first oþer metten Ich oþer wiþ launces gretten Mani in sadles held hem stille And mani also of hors felle Mani brac his spere þare Mani oþer þurthout bar. Kai þan felled þe king Yder Wiþ his spere of his destrer, Þe king of hundred kni?tes Kay doun feld anon ri?tes, Kay vp stirt and king Yder Afot fou?ten wiþ swerdes cler, On boþe half so com her men And swiþe stirten hem bitven. Þer come Lucan þe boteler And bar Eustas of his destrer, Eustas þe douke of Arundel Bi Yder stode and werd him wel. Grifles feld þe king Clarion, Þe king of hundred kni?tes com And hit Grifles bi þe side Of his stede he gan doun glide, Vp strit Grifles and stode bi Kay And fau?t so a kni?t of noblay. Forþ com Vlfin and eke Lucan And feld king Cradelman And wiþ oþer kni?tes mo Riden he [þe] kni?tes to, Þe douke Grifles and þe steward Kay On hors þai brou?t par ma fay; Þo þai were mounted y sigge apli?t Þai kedden her noble mi?t Þan þe king of þe hundred kni?tes Kay doun feld anon ri?tes And þre kni?tes al arawe He binam þer her liif-dawe. Arthour wiþ his mi?ti hand Feld king Brangors and king Anguisaunt— Þo were afot seuen kinges Gret slau?ter was at her rideinges Þat þai no mi?t nou?t keuer her destrers For her alder powers. King Lot and king Carodas And Nanters þat bihinde was And eke þe king Vrien Wiþ tvelf þousand of strong men Þe hors of baundoun lete þai frem And come flingand wiþ al her men So Arthours folk þai metten And of her steden mani stetten, In þat ich hard meteing Al þai socourd her kinges And brou?ten hem on her steden Þe better þo þai mi?t speden. Þer wer fele of hors yfeld And kni?tes yslawe vnder scheld, Ac þer schewed king Arthour At þat batayl gret vigour; Of his men mani feld ware, Now he was here now he was tare And chalanged his men bi ri?t And wi?tlich bigan for hem to fi?t Wiþ his swerd of gode egge Sum he clef to þe rigge And sum he smot þe nek atvo And sum he smot þe schulder fro. Þe oþer kinges were wi?t also Arthours folk þai deden wo— XXX þousand forsoþe y wene Fou?ten þer o?ain sextene. Lucan Grifles and king Arthour Vlfin Bretel and sir Antour Þis ich seuen saun fail Þe cark hadde of þe batayl, Þe folk descomfit hadde men sen No hadde her mi?t þe better ben. Ac in al þis sur carking Merlin com to Ban þe king And seyd ‘Sir time it is Þou help king Arthour ywis’ Also swiþe þan Ban þe king Went forþ wiþouten letting. Farien a kni?t of gret power He was douke of þe first bane[r], Maruc loked þe secounde A kni?t of swiþe gret mounde, Of þe þridde maister was Þe noble king Belias, Þe ferþ ledde Bleoberiis A baroun of wel noble pris, Þe fif[t] ladde Gracian Strong baroun and noble man, Þes fiue so y finde Led of men fiftene þousinde Þer ich of hem hastiliche W[ent] hem forþ hardiliche; Bohort afterward cam Wiþ four þousand of noble man In þis world wele to fi?t No were yhelden non better kni?t. Also þai maden þis [s]ailing Þe oþer com on hem smiteing Wiþ her speres and feld to grounde Mani þat þai þere founde. In þis time king Lot Went out of þe plas God it wot And king Nanters and king Vrien Wiþ mani noble of her men And king Carodas þe wi?t And king of þe hundred kni?t Þese so michel pite sei?en Þat þai wepe wiþ her ei?en For þe sle?ster of her man, And sore þe dede of king Ban And Bohort also his broþer— Þere no schuld go no noþer. Adoun þai li?t and her hors girten, Wiþouten stirop þerin stirten Euerich of hem nome in his hond A launce boþe stef and strong. King Nanters king Lot king Karodas Þis men armed, wiþ gret ras King Ban þai hitten alle at ones Adoun þai þrewe him on þe stones, King of þe hundred kni?tes and king Vrien King Bohort þai riden o?en And hitten him boþe at a dent And feld his stede verrament, Ac Ban vp stirt and Bohort also And wele hem wered o fot bo Þe oþer hem were about to dere Ac manliche þai gun hem were. King Arthour sei?e doun king Ban Swiþe wo him was forþan His stede he smot þider anon; A kni?t þat was about, king Ban to slon On þe helme he smot forsoþ Þurth helme and palet to þe toþ And pelt doun þat bodi dede And tok þat stede gode at nede, King Ban þan þurth fine mi?t On þat stede lepe apli?t Þo he þe stede was opon He ?aue a nedel of his fon; Anoþer king Arthour hitte Þe bodi to þe nauel he kitte Fro þe scholder y tel ?ou It was a dint of gret vertu, Arthour pelt adoun þat buke Þat hors he lad Bohort þe douke. Þo þai on hors seten boþe Þai were aschamed and eke wroþ So we finden on þe boke Who þat ani of hem oftoke Of liue no hadde þai no bote Ac to þe deþ went God it wot. What gette it al to tellen here? Arthur and Ban and her fere So michel pople toforn hem slowe Þat her enemis hem wiþdrowe And gun to fle to on brigge Þat þai toforn dede l[e]gge. Þer spac Morganor on hast King Vriens sone o bast (He was on of þe best kni?t Þat mi?t held swerd in fi?t) He seyd ‘Sir listneþ alle, O our folk we moten calle Bi on horn þat y schal blawe Oþer þai worþ alle yslawe And destroied of our fon,’ Þe kinges seyd ‘Þat is wele don.’ Morganor þo gan to blowe Þat folk so gun his horn knowe Swiftlich al þai gunnen flen And to þe kinges socour ten, Þo þai comen to þe brigge Ich on oþer gan to legge Ac also wolf þe schip gan driue Arthour smot hem after swiþe And king Ban and her men Slou? of hem þousendes ten. Þer þai hadde mani slawe Ac Merlin gan hem wiþdrawe And seyd o?ain wende þai schold Þe siluer to part and þe gold And mani oþer riche þinges Þat þer hadde left þe riche kinges, Arthour þou?t gode afin Þe riche conseil of Merlin (Þe oþer oway þai leten flen) And gan o?ain wiþ his folk ten; Of gold of siluer and noblesse Þai founden grete riches Arthour it ?af Bohort and Ban And bad it part among her man— So þai deden, wiþ gret honour To hem and to þe king Arthour. After þat gentil parting To Londen went Arthour þe king And king Bohort and king Ban And alle her noble man, Fourten ni?t Arthour held fest Swiþe noble and swiþe onest. Þo þe fest ydon was Merlin teld Arthour þat cas Arthour he seyd þis þinges ‘No drede þe no more of þis kinges Now þai han ymade it tou? Sone hem worþ to don ynou? E[r] þan com þe Trinite Ich wald ?iuen o cite Wiþ þat þai hadde made acord And þat þou were made her lord, For here is comand to þis lond Gret hunger and here-gong Sex hundred [þousand] Sarra?ins Forto awreke þe douke Angis Þis lond þai comen al about, Of hem no þarf þe noþing dout Her schal com a bachelrie Of þe to haue cheualrie And of þe to ben made kni?t And for þi lond þai wil fi?t Þai schul don mani agrise Of hem þi los schal arise; Þou schalt hem alle knowe wel And of þe kinges wite eueri del Þai schullen hauen in her lond Of wer to don ful her hond. And ich ?ou sigge Bohort and Ban Sendeþ hom al ?our man ?our lond to loke and ouersen Bot it swiþe fewe ben, Arthour schal alle his tounes Astore wiþ flesche and venisouns Wiþ corn and mele and men strong O?ain her fon to werre long, And þou Arthour me schalt abide Bitven Inglond and Carmelide In þe toun of Brekenho Til ich meself þe com to.’ Þis was do wiþouten doute, Arthour his tounes stored aboute Wiþ corn mele flesche and fische And wiþ men strong ywis; Þe douke [D]o wiþouten fable Of Cardoil hadde ben constable, Of Londen bi Merlines rade He was þo constable ymade. Leonce he sent hom of Paerne Ban and Bohort, swiþe ?erne, And þe douke also Pharien And þe baroun Gracien Wiþ her ost þe lond to loke So we finden on þe boke King Arthour Bohort and Ban Wele wiþ sex score of her man Went hem to Brekenho So Merlin hem seyd to Bitven Inglond and Carmelide Merlines com forto abide Þat þo fro hem was ywent Þai nist whider verrament. Þo þai hadde þere a while abiden On a day out þai riden And sei?e com bi on lowe An eld cherl wiþ aruwe and bowe Þe cherl bent his bowe sone And smot a doke mididone And wiþ a bolt afterward Anon he hitt a maulard. Þis foules he nam þo O?ain þe king he gan go Arthour him asked as y ?ou telle ?if he wold þo foules selle, Þis old man seyd par ma fay He wold hem ?iue for monay. Þe king him axed, so most he liue Hou he wold þe foules ?iue, Þeld man seyd ‘Sir king Nou?t þou schust make hucking Ac þou schust hote hem bere forþ And tviis ?iue me þe worþ Fo[r] ich þe wold soner ?iue Þis to foules so mot y liue Þan þou a pani of þi gold Þat liþ bidoluen depe in mold’— Wiþ þis word þe foules to Sir Kay he tok hem bo. To þat eld seyd Arthour ‘Who teld þe of mi tresour?’ ‘Certes’ he seyd ‘þe clerk Merlin For swiþe late y spac wiþ him.’ Þe king nold him leue nou?t, Þeld man seyd him no rou?t ‘For king’ he seyd ‘þou hast of me And y no haue nou?t of þe.’ Bretel and Vlfin him vnderstode And seyd anon wiþ milde mode ‘Sir, God þe ?eld þis foules to ?iftes þou hast him ?euen mo And ?ete þou schalt wiþ Godes mi?t Mo presantes and ?iftes him di?t’— Þer þai wisten bi Vlfin Þat þis eld was Merlin. Merlin him schewed to king Arthour And he him kist wiþ gret honour And Bohort and Ban and oþer swiþe Of his come weren bliþe. A damisel of gret valour Was þo comen to king Arthour To knowe him lord and don omage Þat sche no hadde afterward damage, And alle hir kni?tes deden also Þat wiþ hir were comen þo, Li?anor þat may was hot Erl Siweinis douhter God it wot. Þo Arthour hir hadde ysei?e Bi hir he wald haue ylei?e So he dede þurth Merlin A child he bi?at hir in Þat wex seþþen of gret mounde And kni?t of þe table rounde. Þere þai soiournd euerichon Til þat lenten were half agon. Lete we hem þer stille be And of þe kinges telle we XI, þat flowen are Hou þai bicomen and whare. In time of winter alange it is Þe foules lesen her blis Þe leues fallen of þe tre Rein alangeþ þe cuntre Maidens leseþ here hewe, Ac euer hye louieþ þat be trewe. Þe kinges þat descomfit ware Al day and al ni?t hadde yfare On hors, armed, wiþ gret hete Wiþouten drink wiþouten mete Til þai com to Norhant A fair cite of gode waraunt Norham was þat time y wene A prout cite and strong and kene, Ich ?ou telle at on word King Vriens was þerof lord. Þis kinges alle þider comen ware And hadden sorwe and gret care For her kni?tes were so yslawe And her kin brou?t o liue-dawe Swiche diol þai hadden dayes to Nold þai mete to mirþe do; Vp him stirt Baudamagu A kni?t of gret vertu And seyd ‘Kinges leteþ ben ?our diole is rewþe forto sen ?e habbeþ frendes fer and wide To hem ?e schulleþ nouþe ride And ?our diol to hem speke Þurth whom ?e worþ awreke.’ Þurth his speche comfort þai nome, Þe þridde day and togider come And euerich oþer ?aue swiche solas So þai mi?ten in þat cas, Þat day þai maden hem at aise To bed ani?t þai ?eden in paise. Þe ferþ day euerich aros And sone days hem agros For to hem com a messanger And gret hem wiþ rewelich chere And seyd into Cornnewaile Sarra?ins were comen saun faile And hadde nei?e strued al þat lond Wiþ wilde fere and wiþ brond And þe lond of Dorkaine also Ystroied and don michel wo Nambires þai hadde bilay And destrued al þe cuntray Boþe wiþ fer and wiþ sword, Spard þai noiþer knaue no lord, Þer was so michel pople of hem Þat tellen hem no mi?t men. Þo þe kinges yherd þis In her hertes nas no blis Al her flesche bigan to quake So þe feuer hem had ytake, Ich of hem seyd, allas Þat ani of hem ybore was; Þe wailing þat þai made Today no mi?t ich fulrade Ac swiche sorwe made apli?t Ich of hem fourten ni?t Þat litel mete com hem among Bot ‘Waileway!’ and wepeing strong. At þe fourten ni?tes ende King Brangore wi?t and hende Com him forþ into þe halle And ofsent his feren alle To hem alle þan spak Brangori ‘Yblisced be þe King of glorie Of his grace and of his sending, What helpeþ ous swiche morning? Fond we ous to bistere And our lond sumdel to were. We no haue pouer Arthour o?en For king Bohort and king Ban No for Merlin þe gode clerk Þat can so michel schandliche werk, We no haue deserued of Arthour To haue nonskinnes socour To helpen ous o?ain Angys kende Þat þenkeþ ous forto schende And we haue ylorn our mi?t Nou?t wiþ wrong ac al wiþ ri?t Þat wold haue our lord kende Yslawe þurth lore of þe Fende. Of king Leodegan help worþ ous non For of Yrlond þe king Rion Him haþ awerred to ?er and more Wiþ tventi kinges bi Godes ore, No of king Pelles of Listonei No worþ ous help par ma fay For þe ward of Pelleore His broþer, liþ sike and sore And schel be seke fort þe meruaile Of þe greal be don saun [f]aile, No forþer of þe king Alain No worþ ous noiþer help no main For he liþ sike and sike schal ben For[t] þe best kni?t of stren' (Y haue seyd wherfore it is Þat he bicom sike ywis), ‘No of þe king of þe Marais Normaga of Sorailes No may þer com help to ous For him awerreþ Galaous, No of þe king Bremeins No of þe king Adameins No of þe king Clamadas No may [ous] com no solas For alle hem werreþ Galeus Þe riche king so vertouous; Lokeþ now hou we may spede For we habbeþ wel gret nede.’ Þo bispac Cradelman King of Norþ Wales a wise man ‘Þe best conseil þat y can— Part we alle our man And hire we alle þo Þat we wiþ catel may ago And ich man wende to his cite Þat we wene strangest be And kepe we þe strait wais Oueralle in þe cuntrays And robben hem her sustenaunce, Wiþ skec and don hem combraunce And waiten hem al þe qued Þat we mowe bi mi red.’ Þo bispac sir Lot þe king ‘Gode ware al þis conseiling Ac ich wot when Arthour seþ Þat we of þe payens awerred beþ An oþer half he wil ous anoie And wiþ schond ous destroie.’ Þe king of þe hundred kni?t Seyd ‘Drede ?ou nou?t, y ?ou pli?t Arthour wiþ Bohort and Ban Beþ toward Leodegan And help him o?ain Rion And hem warnisen euerichon Boþe cite and castel Wiþ mete and men swiþe wel Þat hem no stondeþ no doute Of þe payens no of her route, Of him no haueþ non drede For it is soþe þat ich ?ou sede; Mi conseyl is ?e don anon So þou seydest king Cradelman.’ Þis conseyl þai deden þo And senten after mani mo Kni?tes, swaines, man þat wold Winnen siluer oþer gold Forto loke wiþouten asoine Al þe marches of Galoine And of Cornwaile þe pleines And eke þe place of Dorkains And of Gorre also ich say And eke þe entres of Galeway. Alder first Yder þe king Þre þousand hadde of bileueing Þat yslawe no were nou?t O?aines Arthour þan þai fou?t And viii þousand of purchas He hadde also bi Godes gras, And to [h]is strong cite Nante Wiþ alle þis men he wante, And ?ete he hadde þousandes þre Of þe cite bi mi leute; Þis Ider loked wele þe wayes Wiþ his folk in þat cuntreys And payens he ouercam Oft and her mete binam And so wele in armes dede Þat men hem blisced in eueri stede. King Nanters þe wi?t man So went forþ into Hussidan His owhen cite þat was of priis Wiþ þre þousand him bileued ywis In þe bataile þer he was, Wiþ seuen þousand of purchas, And fif þousand in toun he fond Orped men and gode of hond; Þis loked wele þe paþes And þe paiens oft deden scaþes Boþe o lif and eke tresour Þai dede þe paiens misauentour. King Lot went to Dorkaine Wiþ þre þousand bileued wiþ paine Þer he was at þe bataile And wiþ fiue þousand of purchas saun faile, And four þousand he fond in his toun Wi?t men and of grete renoun, And ?ete for his wi?t pruesse And hendeschip and largesse Þre þousand after him come Gode bataile forto done. VIII þousand þo hadde Lot Þat wele him holpe God it wot Þe waies and þe paþes ?eme And of þe Sarrains h[e]m reme And often deden hem gret greuaunce And robbed hem her sustenaunce. Þo went king Clarion To Norþhumberlond anon To his cite þat hete Orlende Wiþ þre þousand þat were hende Þat him bileued at þat fi?t O?ain Arthour þe gode kni?t, VIII þousand he hadde of purchas Þat wele deden in eueri plas, Þe wayes þai deden wele awayt And þe paþes þat were strait And oft deden þe Sarra?ins Grete schame and grete pines. After went anon ri?tes Þe king of þe hundred kni?tes (Aguigines was his name He was a kni?t of gret fame) He went him to Malaot A riche cite God it wot, Þe cite on leuedis was And stode in a wel gret pas Where þe Sarra?ins com and ride, Þre þousand he brou?t him mide Ascaped fram deþes hond; Þat leuedi marched on his lond Þerfore sche com to his socour And fond kni?tes of grete valour Ynou? to loken her lond— And so þai deden wiþ mi?ti hond. After went Cradelman To Norþ Wales þat he cam Wiþ þre þousand of his kni?tes Þat were ascaped fram þe fi?tes, He purchast seuen þousinde So ich in þe boke yfinde Four þousand he fond at hom Þat were bliþe of his com For vnneþe fram hem fiue mile Woned a wiche hete Carmile (Hir broþer hi?t Hardogabran A swipe riche soudan) Of wichecraft and vilaine And eke of nigramace Of þis warld sche couþe mast Wiþouten Arthours so[ster] abast— Morgein forsoþe was hir name And woned wiþouten Niniame Þat wiþ hir queint gin Bigiled þe gode clerk Merlin. Þis Carmile in þat cuntray Hadde a castel of gret noblay Of þat castel hadde socour Þe Sarra?ins and gret recour Wharþurth þe king Cradelman Was soure carked and alle his man, Ac swiþe wele noþelas Þe marche he loked and eke þe pas (Ac Carmile par ma fay Bi Merlines liif-day No mi?t do wiþ hir wicheing In Inglond non anoiing). King Brangore þo went forþ To Estrangore wel fer bi norþ And woned þat wiche biside— Þe more noi?e him gan bitide. Þre þousinde wiþ him he nam Þe slei?t þat were ascaped fram, Sex þousinde he hadde of purchas And fiue of his cite þat was, Þat loked þe cuntray And often dede þe panimes tray. Þis Brangores of valour Ludranes douster þemperour Bi þat time hadde yspoused, A leuedi gent and preciouse, Ac þe king of Hungri and of Blaske Hir hadde first to wiue ytake; Bi hir form husbounde Sche hadde a child of gret mounde Þat was yhoten Sagremor, In ward wiþ þemperour, Þat was air of þempire And of Blaske and of Hungrie— ?e schul here afterward hou Segremor Com to kni?t of king Arthour Whereþurth þemperour sikerliche Him hadde ygraiþed richeliche And hadde him sent [fr]o Costentinenoble To Inglond-ward wiþ mani noble. ?ete went forþ king Carodas Þat of þe rounde table was To Galence his cite A cite riche of gret plente, Wiþ him he hadde þre [þ]ou[s]and kni?t Þat were ascaped fram þat fi?t And þer he fond foure þousinde Noble kni?tes so ich finde And seuen þousand of gret powers He purchasced on hei?e destrers, Þat wiþ swerd and launce and kniif Binomen mani painems her liif And wiþ skekes and wiþ fi?t Þe wayes loked wele apli?t. Þerafter þe king Anguisaunt Went to Coranges in Scotland Wiþ fiue þou[s]and gode kni?tes Alle ascaped fram þe fi?tes, Of purchas he hadde þousendes ten Swiþe wele fi?tand men Wiþouten mani þat he fond In his cite and in his lond; He nas bot tventi mile-way Fram Nambire þat was bilay Of mani þousand Sarrain Whereof he hadde mister fin To fele kni?tes him to helpe To fi?t o?ain þe Sarra?in welpe— So þai deden wiþ chere bliþe Swiþe oft and mani siþe On hem schoten bi wayes and paþes And dede þe Sar[a]ins gret scaþes. Þo went Eustas to Arundel Wiþ þre þousand armed wel Þat were ascaped fram þe batayle, Wiþ seuen þousand sau[n] faile Þat wele loked paþ and way Oueral in þat cu[n]tray. King Vriens bileued stille In Norham sori and eke ille For depart of his felawe And for her men þat weren yslawe, He hadde in alle þousandes ten Boþe wi?t and hardy men Þat anoied bi al her mi?t Þe Sarra?ins bi day and ni?t. Now ?e schul vnderstond Fif ?er þis last in Inglond Þat no corn no was ysowe Noiþer on doun no on lowe, Alle þis ich ?eres fiue Þis kinges þus ladde her liue Wiþ þat þai mi?t reue and robbe Of Sarra?ins wiþ swerd and clobbe, Þe lowe folk in þe cuntray Were yslawe for nou?t al day— And alle yslawe hadde yben No hadde sir Wawain to hem sen Þat was þo a bacheler Iolif and of strong power. Ac ar ich ?ou more þing Of paiems telle oþer king Of Nanters sone and of his feren Noble þing ?e schullen yheren His sone was hoten Galathin— Now listneþ wele for loue min. Of Ygerne þat ich er of spake Hou Hoel hir hadde spoused to make— On hir he bi?at Blasine gent And so he dede Belisent King Nanters hadde spoused Blasine And Lot Belisent fair and dine Y wil wele þat ?e it wite Nanters in Blasine hadde bi?ete A fair ?ong man Galathin Wi?t hende and gentil afin, Lot bi?at in Belisent Four sones swiþe gent Gveheres and eke Wawain Gaheriet and Agreuein. Galathin in þis time Com to his moder Blasine And asked ?if it were soþ Þat men seyd souþe and norþ ‘?if mi nem be king Arthour? Telle me dame par amour.’ Blasine þo bigan to wepe And seyd ‘Sone so God me kepe Mi broþer king Arthour is In on wombe we weren ywis Bot he is Vter Pendragons stren Þerfore þi fader him wold slen, And nere þi fader was slawe in fi?t Nou?t wiþ wrong bot al wiþ ri?t.’ Þer sche him teld anon Arthours bi?ete of Vter Pendragon And alle þe destaunce whi and wharfore Arthours deþ þai hadden yswore, And seyd ‘Sone were þou wiis Or so þou þe heldest of priis Þou scholdest bi day and bi ni?t Wiþ queyntise and al þi mi?t Fond forto maken acord Bitven Arthour and þi lord.’ Galathin swore wiþ wordes bold He nold neuer o?ain [him hold] And seyd he wold of him afong Helme and swerd and launce strong And of him be dubbed kni?t And wiþ him be in pays and fi?t. A messanger he sent anon And badde him swiþe to Wawain gon And sigge him wiþ wordes bonaire He com to þe newe faire Of Brocklond to speke him wiþ Mani word of loue and griþ, Þis erand bar þe messanger Wawain answerd wiþ glad chere Þat ?if he hadde liif of manne He wold speke wiþ him þanne. In time þat þis sond cam Gawinet fram hunting nam, Þre grehoundes he ledde on hond And þre raches in on bond. His moder biheld him and wepe sore And seyd ‘Sone now þi nore! Þou lest þi time wiþ vnri?t Þou hast age to ben kni?t Þou schust leten þi folye Þi rage and þi ribaudye, Þenke on þi nem Arthour Kni?t þat is of mest valour And fond to make gode acord Bitven him and Lot þi lord’— Þer sche told, him bifore Hou Arthour was bi?eten and bore. His breþern seyd he hadde wrong For it was al on him ylong Þat þai her time lorn so And bot he wald wiþ hem go Þai wolden fare to king Arthour And him seruen wiþ honour. Þo bispac him child Wawain Whom Crist ?af boþe mi?t and main ‘Swete dame and breþern þre Wiþ gret wrong ?e blamen me Seþþen ich euer born was Nist y neuer are þis cas, Ac seþþen þus fer comen it is Y bihote þe King of blis No schal y neuer armes afong Bot of king Arthours hond,’ His þre breþer þer on hast Þer biheten anon þat hast. Þo bispac Wawain curteys ‘Ma dame purvaieþ ous harnais And we nil neuer blinne What we may þe acord winne.’ ‘Sone’ sche seyd ‘sikerliche ?e schullen haue neweliche Hors and armes and alle þing Þat bihoueþ to ?our dubbeing.’ Þerafter sone bi Godes sond Galathin went to Brocklond O?ain him com Wawain þe fre Wiþ his gentil breþer þre And in her togider coming Þai maden ioie and gret kisseing. Þo seyd Wawain to Galathin ‘Certes gentil nevou min No hadde it be for loue þine Ich and al breþer mine Were ywent to our em Arthour To seruen him, and make amour Our fader and him bitven Þurth help of Heuen-quen.’ ‘Yherd be Crist!’ quaþ Galathin ‘Þat is desire and wil min For þat ich selue þing Ich made after þe sending Togider y pray þe wende we.’ ‘Bleþeliche’ quaþ Wawain þe fre, Þer þai setten ioifulliche Day to wende sikerliche— And ?if þai no hadde togider ywent Inglond hadde ben yschent. Mirie is þentre of May Þe foules make miri play Maidens singgeþ and makeþ play Þe time is hot and long þe day Þe iolif ni?tingale singeþ In þe grene mede f[l]ou[r]es springeþ. King Lot and þe leuedi Belisent Hadde puruayd her sone gent Fif hundred on hors wel In armour of iren and stiel Erls sones and barouns boþe Alle in sout of o cloþe, Ac of hem, bot nei?en, kni?t Þer no ware y ?ou pli?t; He blisced Gawaynet And Gueheres and Gaheriet And Agreuein þat was so hende And on Godes name bad hem wende. On þis maner dede Blasine King Nanters leuedi dine Hir sone Galathin Sche graiþed in atire fin To hundred feren sche him fond And blisced him wiþ hi[r] hond, Of þis to hundred were xx kni?tes Swiþe noble and gode in fi?tes. Galathin and Gawainet Togider com þer þai hadde sett And wenten forþ in her way Toward Londen forsoþe to say Þai wenden haue king Arthour founde In þe noble toun of Lounde, Þe þridde day in her iurneie Þai were Londen swiþe nei?e Þai sei?en hem com swiþe ner Seuen hundred charged somer And seuen hundred cartes also And fiue hundred waines after go Ycharged alle wiþ ale and bred Wiþ fische and flesche and win red Robbed of men of þe cuntray To leden to her ost oway— For þe poudre of þis charging No mi?t men se sonne schining. Þre þousand seyt our boke Þat robberie went to loke, Þis robberie þan hadde ydon A king hi?t Leodebron And þe king Senigram Swiþe fel and wicke man And þe king Maudelec Þat euer waited scaþe and skec And þe king Sernagare, Of Yrlond al þai ware; Þis four heþen kinges Went to loken þis robbeinges, And were so wroþ þat king Arthour Hadde ywarnist toun and tour Þat þe cuntre aboute Lounde Slowen and brent to þe grounde Men sei?e þe fer fer away Þennes ouer a iurnay, Man and wiif and children bo No hadde þai no pite to slo Þe folk schirsten so hei?e and loude Þat it schilled into þe cloude. Wawain sei?e and herd þis fare And asked men what it ware And þai him teld sone anon So ich toforn haue ydon, Wawain asked where was þe king, Þai seyd, þurth Merlins conseiling He was went to king Leodegon To help him wer o?ain king Rion, Quaþ Waway[n] ‘Bi mi leute We nil suffre now þis pite Seþþen king Arthour is out of lond We wil þe painemes wiþstond And saue his lond—we beþ his men— Til þat he com hider o?en.’ Þat folk abouten him gan ten And asked wat folk it mi?t ben, Þai seyden whos sones þai were And wherefore þai comen þere (Þe folk þat was of þis lond Þonked Ihesu Cristes sond) Chasteleins sones and vauasours (Seþþen wele deden wiþ king Arthours), And fele men of þis lond Þer fellen to þis children hond Fif hundred of wi?t man. Wawain hete on hast þan Euerich man him arme wel Boþe in yren and in stiel And suwen him, for our slei?t He wald awreke anon ri?t; Now hadde he a þousand and hundred to (Of wiche four score and no mo Hardi and wele doinde kni?tes) Þat him suwed anon ri?tes In four parties so y finde And dede hem o?ain þre þousinde And acontred þat carroy. It was passed þe midday And þo fel fro Wawain Sumdel of his mi?t and main— For of his strengþe þe maner Sumdel ?e may lern and here: Bitven auensong and ni?t He no hadde bot o mannes mi?t And þat strengþe him last Fort arnemorwe bi þe last, And fram arnemorwe to þe midday He hadde strengþe of kni?tes tvay, Fram midday fort afternone He nadde strengþe bot of one, Fram afternone to auensong So to kni?tes he was strong; Þis was þe manere of Wawain Of his strengþe and of his main. In þe time of midday On þe paiens he smot par fay Wiþ an ex scharp and strong Þe bite was to fot long, Whom he mi?t take and hitt Þe heued he clef oþer of kitt He hem tohewe ich ?ou swer So flesche doþ þe flesche-heweere He and his hors fram heued to taile Blodi weren al saun fayl Of þe paiems þat he slou? Wiþ gode ri?t and no wou?. Alder next him was Galathin Þat him halp wiþ mi?t fin, What Sarra?in so he mett Wel soriliche he hem grett Þat wom euer þat he hitt Þe heued to þe chinne he slitt Oþer þe scholder oþer þe heued Fro þe bodi was bireued Oþer legge oþer fest Oþer what he mi?t take best, Who so euer he atrau?t Tombel of hors he him tau?t. Wawaines broþer Agreuein Þer him kidde a noble mayn For xx kni?tes al arawe Þer he brou?t o liue-dawe. Þe þridde broþer Gueheres Smot him in amid þe pres, On alle half about he smot And mani slou? God it wot. Þe ?ongest broþer Gaheriet, No child no mi?t fi?t bet Þan he dede verrament Þer he bisett mani a dent Þurth armes out euerichon He clef þurth flesche and bon, Fourti Sarra?ins and mo Þer he dede to helle go. Oþer men þat mid him were Deden nobleliche þere Þai slou?wen and brou?t to grounde Mani paien in litel stounde. Ac certes o?ain Wawain Non no mi?t kiþe his main For arme non ywrou?t wiþ hond O?ain his dent no mi?t stond; Þat he tok he al torof, So dust in winde and aboute drof. Þer he him contende so manliche Þat in litel while sikerliche Child Wawain and his felawe Þis þre þousand brou?ten of dawe Bot tventi paiems þat gun ascape And, fleand oway wiþ gret rape, Of wiche þe ten com bihinde To on ost of seuen þousinde, Wiþ loude voice and to hem gradde ‘Harou painems ?e ben to badde! Cartes and somers ous beþ binome And alle our folk is ouercome And yslawe euerich man Bot we, and oþer ten Þat herebineþe fram ous ?ede More socour to bring hem midde.’ Euerich payem þo was sori And criden a grisely crie ‘As armes for Mahouns sake Þat þis traitour were ytake!’ Þat armes hadde ron þerto Ac som no hadde non þo Ac þai hem hadde laid for hot In þe cartes God it wot Wiche þe children hadde sent To Londen verrament— Alle þe cartes and somers Were sent þider wiþ men of powers. Þis paiens wiþouten let O?ains þis children set O?ain a þousand come seuen Þat was noþing delt euen, Ac þe help of our Dri?t Wiþ Wawain and his gan ali?t No herd men neuer so fewe in lond Noblicher so fe[l]e wiþstond. Þer aros noble bataile A boþe half wiþouten faile, Ac Wawain swiþe noble was For þer he met king Thoas A wi?t geaunt gret and strong Of fet fourtene he was long A king he was of Yrlond, Wawain his ax left an hond On þe helme he him hitt Þat to þe brest he him slit. Galathin mett king Sanigran An vnsely hoge man Wiþ his swerd he him hitt Þat his heued of he kitt. Wawain broþer Agreuain Amid þe pres kidde his main For a left half and a ri?t He leyd on and slou? doun ri?t. Þer com þe king Gvinbat And ?af Gueheres swiche a flat Þat he fel adoun to grounde Ac he stirt vp in a stounde And so smot a Sarra?in Þat he clef his bacin And eke his heued to þe toþ And on his hors lepe forsoþ, Gaheriet sei?e Gvinbat Þat his broþer ?aue swiche a flat And Gvinbat him com sei?e And gan to flei?e swiþe oway— For þe strokes he sei?e him ?eue He no durst abide so mot y liue For þo Gaheriet was ymade kni?t In euerich place and eueri fi?t He kidde ner as miche main So dede his broþer Wawain. Gvinbat flei?e out of þe place Gaheriet on hors his trace Folwed out fram þat ost Wele þe schote of an alblast So we finden on þe bok In o valay he him oftok In wiche valay þe oþer ten Þat scaped Wawain and our men Hadden brou?t þousandes ei?t Of our men to make slei?t; Gaheriet no lete nou?t for þat Þat he no folwed king Gvinbat, And folwed him wiþouten doute Alon amidward þe route And smot him so on þe helme cler And þerof carf a quarter And þe scheld þurth ato Wiþ þe scholder and arme also. King Gvinbat in þat stounde Aswon fel adoun to grounde, Gaheriet þo turned his bridel And swiþe wald o?ain ride Ac þe paiems about him come And wold him han ynome Ac þer he carf wiþ swerd and smot Mani to þe deþ God it wot He nas nou?t tventi winter eld Ac in armes he was beld, Sum wiþ swerd so he hitt Þat to þe chin he him slitt Of mani he smot þe nek ato And wounded and dede michel wo, Non durst him nei?e verrament For doute of his hard dent. Þo þai him dede gret vilanie His hors slou? biforn his ei?e, Gaheriet afot stode And werd him wiþ hert gode Boþe he slou? hors and man Him aboute, fiue and ten, So sore he hitt so sore he smot Non durst him nei?e God it wot. Þer þai þrewen on him anon Stones and kniues mani on Swerdes staues and launces long And wounded him swiþe strong And tviies feld him on þe ston, Allas help no hadde he non, On him þai schoten atte last And deden of his armes on hast Forto haue anon yreued His bodi fram his gentil heued. In þat time a gentil swain Wel gode scour com to Wawain ‘Wawain’ he seyd ‘þi broþer y say Riden ?onder to ?on valay Folwand on heþen king, Me þenkeþ he makeþ long duelling Go we þider for our Leudi Y herd þer gret noise and cri Y dar legge heued min Þat þer ben mo Sarra?in Þat beþ comand hiderward And han þi broþer in hondling hard.’ ‘Allas’ he seyd ‘icham yschent Be mi broþer so yhent, As lef me were to ben of dawe As mi broþer were yslawe,’ And seyd to Galathin ‘Gode nevou, broþer min ?ond bineþen icham adred Þurth his folye he is misled.’ Quaþ Galathin ‘Lete be þi striif And wende we þiderward biliif, While we speki and makeþ tale He may lachi deþes bale.’ Þer þai smiten al about Þai four dassed out of þe rout Galathin and eke Wawain Gveheres and Agreuein, Sum oþer of þe best After þese four þrest; Þo þai sei?en ich ?ou say VIII þousand in o valay Of wiche her maister king Was yhoten Gvinbating, Anoþer hi?t Medalan Boþe wi?t and hoge man. Wawain swiþe among hem smot His broþer to seche God it wot His ex he houe swiþe hei?e Galathin was him wel nei?e Þai laiden on, hem about And toschiften al þat rout (Sum þe scholder and som þe regge He cleued wiþ swerdes egge Of sum þe midel ato he girt Mani he slou? and mani he hirt) Abouten hem swiche slei?st þai made Þat y no may it nou?t al fulrade; Gveheres and Agrevein Schewed also her main Mani þai hitten and smiten þurth Þat fellen ded in þe furth. No fined þai neuer swiche a slei?t What þai to Gaheriet com ri?t And pitouseliche him ligge founde Deueling opon þe grounde, Mani on about him were His armour of þai gun to tere. Þo was Wawain so wroþ His owhen liif was him loþ Þer he smot sore apli?t Boþe a left half and a ri?t, On he smot þat þe dent þrest Þurth helme and heued to þe brest Anoþer on þe schulder he hitt Þat to þe ribbes he him slitt Anoþer he toke aboue þe scheld Þat his heued flei?e in þe feld, Þus he serued mani arawe Also dede his felawen So fele þai slowen hors and man Þat tellen alle y no can; Þos þat Gaheriet held þo Alle hem bifel sorwe and wo No durst no abide lenge Ac flowen oway on on renge. Þo Gaheriet sei?e Wawain He lepe vp wiþ al his main His armes he tok vp anon And swiftliche dede hem opon And toke a swerd in his hond gode Afot mani he schadde blode, A destrer þo ladde Agreuein And toke it Gaheriet bi þe rein And seyd ‘Worþ heron hastiliche!’ And seyd ‘Þou dest foliliche Þo þou folwedest hunting Ani man in þis gret þring,’ Vpon þe stede Gaheriet Lepe anon wiþouten let, Alle his felawes weren bliþe Out of þe route dasten swiþe Anon þai gun hem wiþdrawe What þai com to her felawe. Þese Sarra?ins þo gun vnplie Her baners and after hei?e, To nimen þis children anon Mahoun þai sworen euerichon Vnder hem alle so was y finde Almest fiften þousinde; Our was litel more þan on Ac Crist hem halp wele to don, Our were gode bodis alle Þe Sarra?ins þai gun to talle A boþe half þai laiden on So fast þo [so] þai mi?ten don. Listneþ now gret and smale Hou ?ou seiþ here þis tale: Þe vplondis men þat hadden ladde Cartes and somers so Wawain badde To Londen wel wele þai come. Þe citisains fair in hem nome And asked hem for Heuen-king Whennes com þat noble þing, Alle þai telden hou Wawain And his feren þurth noble main Hadden met toward Lounde Þre þousand, [and] leyd to grounde And þe Sarra?ins hadde yschent And to Londen þat catel sent, And seyden to þe constable þo Þat was yhoten sir Do Þat Sarra?ins seuen þousinde Hadde asailed hem bihinde. Sir Do went to Algate And dede blowe an horn þerate, Of þat cite þe alderman Ich wiþ his ward cam, Þo þai were þider ycome Seuen þousand were in her trome, Þo spac sir Do þat was kni?t Trewe hardi and eke wi?t ‘Loke’ he seyd ‘leue frende Herbisiden ben childer hende Þat han þis ich dawe Mani cursed painem slawe Þat hadden robbed þis cuntray Of al þis ich fair pray, Þis children han hem yschent And þis present hider sent, We were coward and vnhende Bot we holpen þo children kende; It beþ Galathin and eke Wawain Gveheres Gaheriet and Agreuein— Þurth þe grace of Crist Ihesu And þis children y telle ?ou Bitvene Arthour and þe xi king May be pes and acording. As armes' he seyd ‘par amour And dasse we to her socour!’ Wiþouten abod sone anon Her armes þai deden on Euerich of þe alderman His baner biforn him nam And þe constable sir Do His baner toke also, Of þe seuen þousand to þai lete For alle chaunce Londen to kepe And wiþ hem toke þousandes fiue Swiþe gode in fi?t and striue Her steden swiþe þai bistriden And toward þe children swiþe riden. Lete we now ben her cominge And speke we of þe children fi?ting, Þis children fou?ten so y finde O?ain fiftene þousinde And no hadde bot four score kni?tes And fif hundred of squiers wi?t And tventi also þat schulden ben Kni?tes when þai mi?t her time sen And þre hundred of þe cuntray Boþe on fot and hors y say— Þat was a þousand, an hundred las Nas þer namore in þat cas, Ac Gvinbating and Medelan To vnsely hardi man Wiþ viii þousand in a þrome On our folk dasseand come Wiþ strong cours and gret hete So þai hem wald nim and þrete. Gvinbating an hoge spere O?ain Wawain he gan to bere Wawain it sei?e sone on hast His scheld þero?in gan cast, His scheld perced Gvinbating Ac his strong hauberk noþing Þe launce brac atvo apli?t; Wawain nou?t stired ac sat vpri?t His ax he hef wiþ boþe his hond To hit Gvinbating ich vnderstond On his helme he him smot, Þe ax glod God it wot Of þe gode ax þe scharpe egge Fel doun on þe hors rigge And tocarf it euen ato, And to þe grounde wiþouten no Þe kni?t donward gan butten Amidward þe hors gutten— And no hadde Wawain þer o fot ylawe He hadde þer þe king yslawe. Þo þe Sarra?in ysei?e þis Þer com man[i] hundred ywis Her lord to ben bitven And Wawain to nimen or slen, Þe Sarra?in her lord vp nome And on hors sett him sone And sir Wawain þai asailed strong His hors þai slowen wiþ wrong, Him to nim þai deden strengþe— And non durst him nei?e his ax-lengþe Ac þai him þrewe wiþ swerd and spere Him to nimen and him to dere. At þat rideing slou? Galathin Swiþe mani Sarra?in So dede also Gveheres Mani heueded in þat pres Agreuein dede also Mani slou? and dede wo So dede þe child Gaheriet No man no mi?t fi?t bet. Miday passed and none cam Wawain strengþe double gan Þo he seyd and swore ‘Par De Today no schul ?e nimen me!’ Wiþ boþe his honden his ax he hef And fele he slou? in stounde bref In blod he stode ichil avowe Of hors and man into þe anclowe Þat he hadde himselue yslawe, Wiþouten slei?t of his felawe. Þo sei?e he wiþ gret main A paiem smot to Agreuein Þat he fel on his hors nek Him to heueden he gan to bek, Wawain wiþ his ax-helue Lepe þo fet ten and tvelue And ouer al þat bitven hem was To help his broþer in þat cas (Þat ich painem wele he knewe Þat on his broþer nek hewe), Þe paiem seye he mi?t nou?t flen His scheld he kest him bitvene And Wawain s[mo]t on þe scheld Þat it clef and fel in þe feld ?ete decended þat ich dent Þurth þe armes verrament And þurthout flesche and bon and blode Þat at þe girdel-stede it stode. Þat dede bodi he put adoun And lepe anon in þe arsoun And seyd ‘Today ich ?eld ?our rentes Wiþ hard woundes and deþ-dentes, Mi strengþe is dubled bi God aboue And þat ?e schul ?ete today proue,’ And slou? to grounde al doun ri?t Boþe a left half and a ri?t So he smot in al þat route Þat grete hepes him lay about Of mani paiem miscreaunt, Þe brut þerof is mi waraunt. Agreuein also wiþ his sword Of Sesox smot þe nek ford; Þat sei?e Gvinbating, þe qued, Þat Sesox his nevou was ded Wreken him he wold fond A strong launce he tok on hond And smot Agreuein so God it wold Þurth þe hauberk felefold (And þurth þe ruhel) vnder þe arm —He hadde nei?e ?ouen him deþes harm— Þat Agreuein and his destrer To grounde he kest wiþ gret power. Gaheriet Gveheres and Galathin Þo bicome sori afine For ich of hem wende certein Þat dede were Agreuein And wenten swiþe to þat rideing; Galathin smot first Guinbating Wiþ his sword ful but Þat on his arsoun donward he lut, Gveheres him dede more harm For he smot of his ri?t arm, Forþ com swiþe Gaheriet He him þou?t to hit bet For he him [tok aboue] þe scheld Þat his heued flei?e in þe feld; Galathin wit fot him stett Out of his sadel he him pett And Agreuein tok þat destrer And flei?e þeron so a speruer And abouten hem þai redden And her noble strengþe kedden— Þo non of hem no wist þere Whare Wawain was bicomen nowhere. Al þe ost of Guinbating Flowen to Medelan þe king And þo wiþdrou? him Agreuein What he sei?e child Wawain, Al fiue togider þai ?ede And our folk þo ?ede hem mide. Þo þai loked hem biside And sir Do þai sei?e com ride Whom þai knewe bi þe vplondis men Þat bifore were went hem fram Hastiliche þo þai ali?t And on her stedes her sadles di?t, Þis fiue þousand fram Lounde To hem com in a stounde. Þe children were of socour bliþe Opon her hors þai lopen swiþe, Wiþ hem and riden sarreliche Her fon toward sikerliche, O?ain hem com þe paiems fling For þe deþ of Guinbating, Launces þai broken mani on Afterward drou? her swerdes anon— For pouder þat ros hem bitven Non no mi?t oþer ysen. Þer was noble contenaunce In bataile of remembraunce Wawain him conteind þan so Þat men of Londen and sir Do Wonder hadde hou man on Swiche pruesse mi?t don, So mani paiems saun faile Were yslawe at þat bataile Þat þe blod ran in þe valaie So water out of a laie. Þer com þe strong king Medlan And feld Do þat gentil man Þe helme hadde him bireued Forto smite of his heued, No man no mi?t him binim Þat vnsely wiþþerwin Bot Wawain þat bi him cam And he him of his tolling nam, Þat he was gode kni?t he kidde Biforn him þe way he ridde What he com to Medelan Þat vnsely hoge man, Wawain on þe helme him smot (Þe ax sank depe God it wot) What he com to þe brest— Þe paiem fel wiþ iuel rest. Þe Sarra?ins sei?en þis And gun fle wel swiþe ywis, Wawain þan and his nevou And his broþer y telle ?ou And her feren and sir Do And þe gode of Londen also Driuen hem fiue mile-way, And mani of hem forsoþe y say— Of hem þai slou? þousandes þrettene Þat nold no more don hem tene Wiþouten al þe oþer heþen man Þat þai slou?wen tofor þan. Þo þis slei?t was ydo To Lunden al þai comen þo Men hem o?ain comen of þe toun Wiþ wel fair processioun, Of þe cartes alle þe priis Bifor Wawain þai brou?t ywis And sir Do him bisou?t cert So he wald he schuld it part, Wawain seyd to sir Do ‘Wo worþ me þan, wo, Ac to hem þat habben nede mast Departeþ it now on hast’— Wawain was þe better ay Þerfore ypraised par ma fay Þis þing was deled and di?t So hem þou?t best apli?t. Þerafter þis children of mounde Soiournd wel long in Lounde Þat no Sarra?in hem mi?t Noiþer deri bi day no ni?t, Sir Do made hem gret solas And alle þat euer in Londen was, Lete we hem þer soiour And wende o?ain to king Arthour. Marche is hot miri and long Foules singen her song Buriouns springeþ mede greneþ Of euerich þing þe hert keneþ. Arthour went [fr]o Brekingho Merlin, Ban, Bohort also And her feren þritti and [n]i[?]e, Was þer no more compainie Bot in alle fourti and to Alle chosen so mot y go Bi clerk Merlines conseyl Þe wi?test þat he wist saun fail. Forþ þai wenten al in paise What þai com to Carohaise A riche cite of al þing Þer was Leodegan þe king Þat was king of al þat lond And hadde Carmelide in his hond And made swiþe gret pite For he was bilayn in þat cite Of king Rion and kinges fiftene Þat al born corounes schene Þat hadden him and al his man Ouercomen bifor þan, No he no hadde men þat mi?t Him to awreke y ?ou pli?t And conseild him þat ich stounde At kni?tes of þe table rounde And at barouns of þe lond Hou þai mi?t hem were fro schond, Amid þe strete in þat cite Þe king þer stode wiþ his meine On a Palmesonnes-aue Sum conseil of hem to haue. Ri?t þo entred king Arthour And Ban and Bohort and sir Antour And her feren wiþouten doute Al þai comen in on route, Alle it were ?ong man Bot it were þe king Ban And Bohort and Vlfin þe bel And sir Antour and sir Bretel Þis were noble kni?tes fiue And alle of midel liue, Þe oþer al were bachelers Sittand on hei?e destrers. Merlin seyd ‘Þe king is ?ounde Li?teþ al to þe grounde ?e schullen wende on on ring ?our hors schul þe gromes bring, And þou sir Ban þe king To Leodegan so ?eue greteing And sey þe wordes him to Þat we bispeke at Brekenho.’ Hou þai went and on swiche maner Now ?e may al yhere, Of swiche bodis noble and wi?t Tofor men me þink it ri?t Her names to tellen ?ou in sawe Hou þai wenten al on rawe: First wenten þre wiþ gret honour Ban and Bohort and king Arthour King Arthour ?ede bitven apli?t And king Ban him ledde bi þe hond ri?t Bohort him ladde nobleliche Bi þe left hond sikerliche, Alle þe oþer com after þo Ioinand bi hond to and to; Þe ferþ so was Antour Kayes fader of gret valour On his hond ?ede sir Vlfin At euerich nede gode and fin; Þe sext kni?t so was Bretel Of gret noblay strong and lel On his hond ?ede þe steward Kay Þe seuend kni?t of gret noblay; Þe viii Lucan þe boteler A gode kni?t of gret power, Erl Does sone þat loked Lounde Þe ix was ich vnderstonde; Grifles so was tiþe Wi?t he was and noble swiþe Marec so ?ede on his hond On of þe best of al þat lond; Þe xii Drians of þe forest sauage A strong kni?t of hei?e parage, Belias þe lord of maiden castel On his hond ?ede fair and wel; Þe xiiii so was Flaundrin A noble kni?t of gentil lin On his hond ?ede Laninas An hardi kni?t, þe fiftend was; Þe xvi was Amores þe broun A stalworþ kni?t vnder hauberioun Aucales þe rede ?ede him bi, Þe xvii kni?t, strong and hardi; Þe xviii was Bliobel A kni?t doand swiþe wel Þe xix was Bleoberiis, Of gret los and michel priis; Canode þe xx was He no flei?e neuer for no cas Aladanc þe crispe was xx and on Non better bodi no mi?t gon; Þe xxii was Islacides Wi?t and strong in eueri pres Lampades was xx and þre A noble kni?t gent and fre; Þe xxiiii kni?t was A noble kni?t yhote Ieroas, Cristofer of þe roche norþ Þe xxv was forsoþ; Þe xxvi was Aigilin A wi?t kni?t of gentil lin Þe xxvii was Calogreuand A gentil kni?t of noble hand; Þe xxviii was Augusale Of no man no held he tale Wi?t Agrauel was xx and ni?e Ful of wi?tschip and curteisie; Þe xxx was Cleades þe fondling Man sei?e neuer better ?ongling, Þe gode kni?t Gimires of Lambale Þe on and þritti was bi tale; Þe xxxii was Kehedin Fair and wi?t and gentil fin Þe þre and þritti was Meraugis A gode kni?t of noble priis; Þe xxxiiii was Gornain An hardi kni?t of michel main Þe xxxv was Craddoc An hardi kni?t in ich floc; Þe xxxvi was Claries He was ful wi?t in eueri pres Þe xxxvii was Blehartis Bold of dede of speche wiis; Þe xxxviii was Amandan orgulous A kni?t of dede vertuous Þe xxxix Osoman, cert His surname was ‘hardi of hert’; Þe xl was Galescounde Þer nas no kni?t of more mounde Þe xli was Bleherris King Bohortes godsone ywis; Þe xlii Merlin was þar Bifor Arthour þe ?erd bar— Þis alle ?ede hand in hand As y ?ou seyd bifornhand. Leodegan and al his ginge Gret wonder had of her cominge Kni?tes swaines leuedis beld Maden crud hem to biheld Wonder þai hadden euerichon For non no knewe her non. O?ain hem ?ede king Leodegan And him gret þe king Ban Leodegan seid ‘?ou blisse þe rode ?if ?e beþ ycomen for gode.’ Quaþ king [Ban] ‘So Crist me spede Com we nou?t hider for þi qued No for þi schame ac for þi gode So ous help þe gode rode We beþ souders of fer lond Men doþ ous to vnderstond Þat þou to socour haddest nede Þerfore we com fram our þede Þat is fer hennes saun faile Þe to help in þi bataile And to serue on swiche maner So þou schalt now yher, We aske þe on Godes name Noiþer to þine harm no þi schame Ac þat þou graunt ous now a þing And þerof no make werning— Þou no schalt aske name our No wo we beþ no non of our No apose ous of our being What we þe wil make scheweing, And ?if þe likeþ so our seruise Telle it ous now in al wise And bot þou like we seruen þe We wille ?ern fram þe te To sum oþer and serue swiþe Þat of our come wil be bliþe.’ Leue toke Leodegan To asky conseil of his man, Alle his barouns him seyd ywis It sembled men of gret priis Her semblaunt hem bar witnisse, He schuld of hem nim sikernisse And afong her seruise And nou?t hem lete o non wise. O?ain com king Leodegan And þus seyd to Arthour and to Ban ‘Bewe seygnours me þenkeþ schame Þat ?e me heleþ ?our name For ich vnderstond wele þat ?e Ben of more power þan ich be Ac ?e semble so wi?t and fre Þat ?e beþ welcome to me And ?our seruise ?eld y schal ?if He me saueþ þat welt al, Ac arst ?e schul me make siker Wiþ me held in eueri biker And ?our names telle ?e me When ?e seþ þat time be’— His treuþe þerto þe king Ban, And þerto ?af Leodegan. Þerwhiles þe clerk Merlin Hem hadde ypuruaid a riche in And ledde hem þider al faire Her ost was ycleped Blaire (Leonele hete his wiif) A fair buriays and ioliif Boþe þai wenten o?ain Arthour And him welcomed wiþ gret honour, Arthour and his feren wi?t Soiournde þer seuen ni?t, In her in and wiþ þe king Þai maden oft solausing. Þe king þo sent his messangers Oueralle to her souders And sent oueralle in his lond Euerich gentil man his sond Þat þai comen to him alle To Carohaise into his halle Atte last bi Holy Þorsday To help him in his medlay And who so nold to him come As traitour he schuld ben ynome So ich in boke writen finde And him hing bi þe winde, For so long trewes bitven Rion Weren and þe king Leodegan— Ac listneþ now swiche traisoun Hem come ar þe Assensioun. In Estre on þe Tewisday Þe euen of seint Philip in May Four kinges gret geaunts Þat were vnder þe king Rioun? Went hem out in iren and stiel Wiþ sexti þousand armed wel, Þe first king hi?t Roulyons Þe oþer hete king Clarions Þe þridde king hete Sonegrens Þe ferþ hete king Sorhens Þise went fram þe gret ost To Carohaise wiþ gret bost And robbeden al þe cuntray Boþe in doun and in valaye Man and wiman al þat þai founde Þai slowen doun into þe grounde, Þe cuntre wiþ wild fer Oueral þai set on fer, Ten hundred cartes on on route Biforn hem brou?t saun doute Charged wiþ mete and wiþ drink Þat ani man mi?t of þink And vc kni?tes þe pray toke Forto condue hem and loke. To Carohaise þe kinges wente And at þe gates wolden entre Ac þe gateward þe gates schetten Ac þero?ain anon þai stetten Boþe wiþ launce and wiþ sword Þai dusched and hewen on þe bord, And wenten to þe plaines o?an To quellen wiif child and man— Men mi?t hem here schriche So fer þat it was ferliche. Þo in þe cite sei?e þis harmes Manliche þai grad ‘As armes!’ Þai went and armed hem euerichon And to þe gates comen anon, Opon gode stede hem rest Forto abide þe kinges hest, And þe kni?tes of þe table rounde Of al þe warld of mest mounde Wiche hadde made Vter Pendragon, Ac king Arthour no knewe her non— Tvo hundred and to score and ten Verrament þer weren of hem Herui [d]e Riuel and Malot þe broun Were maisters of þe gomfainoun So ich in þe brut finde Her gomfainoun was of cendel ynde Of gold þer were on þre coroune, Þo it bar Malot þe broune.
