Of þe cite four þousand were þar Her maister gomfainoun so bar Þe kinges steward Cleodalis A kni?t he was of gret priis His pensel hadde riche colour Alle he was couched wiþ a[?]ur Of gold þer were four bore-heuedes ybete. Þese houed al in þe strete. Þo com king Arthour Bohort and Ban Wiþ her feren eueri man So y in boke telle can Non nere armed hem o?an A queintise þai hadden riche Þat non nas hem yliche, On stedes þai lopen euerichon In þe world nar better non Merlin rode biforn ichil avowe And bad hem alle swiþe him suwe So þai deden wiþouten faintise On hors in fair queintise; Merlin bar her gomfanoun Opon þe top stode a dragoun Swiþe griseliche, a litel croume, Fast him biheld al þo in þe toune For þe mouþe he had grininge And þe tong out flattinge Þat out kest spa[r]kes of fer Into þe skies þat flowen cler, Þis dragoun hadde a long taile Þat was wiþþerhoked saun faile. Merlin com to þe gate And bad þe porter him out late Þe porter seyd he schuld rest What he hadde of his lord hest ‘Certes’ quaþ Merlin ‘y þe telle No lenger resten here y nille’ He toke þe gate bi þe legge And slong hem vp at his rigge, Þo he was out and his feren eke Fast o?ain þe gate he leke Wiþ lockes haspes and mani pin Wiþ mani bar and mani gin, Þus fast loken he hem fand And as fast after him lete hem stand— Alle þat sei?en þis saun faile Of him hadde gret meruaile Boþe þo of þe cite And eke his feren bi mi leute. Þo bad Merlin his compainie Her stedes priken and swiþe hi?e, Wiþ þe baner dast Merlins Among to þousand Sarra?ins Þat ledden a wel gret pray Toward king Rion y say, Ich of hem so dede bere Þurth a Sarrain wiþ his spere Afterward her swerdes drowe And Þe Sarra?ins to grounde slowe Sum þai cleued to þe brest Sum þai binomen fot and fest Of mani þai hadde helme and heued Sone fro þe bodi weued. Þe to and fourti weren ?ep (Þai leten þer hors gode chep Boþe wiþ sadel and wiþ bridel For nou?t to haue and oway ride) Þe to þousand todriuen and slawe Þai hadden in a litel þrawe So man wold in a mile-way Ouergon his iurnay, And þat priis ladde at aise Toward þe cite of Caroaise. Ac so þai comen bi þe way Eft þai metten michel pray A þousand cartes almast Comand wel swiþe on hast Swiche þre kinges wiþ xvi þousinde Comen and condid, hem bihinde, And Merlin seyd wiþ griseli chere ‘Now suweþ me gode fere!’ Forþ he flang and þai after anon So swiþe so þe stedes mi?t gon; Þo þai com þe kinges nei?e Merlin hef his heued on hei?e And kest on hem enchauntement Þat he hem alle almest blent Þat non oþer sen no mi?t A grete while y ?ou pli?t And our fourti smiten hem on And slowen of hem mani on And mani c of painems hewe Ar ani þer oþer knewe. Þo of þe cite sei?en þis Þai seyden it were men of priis. Þo were vp vndon þe gate Cleodalis rode out þerate Þe steward wiþ fiue þousinde Opon þe painems gun to winde, Þer was din þer was cri Mani schaft broken sikerly For in þe coming of Cleodalis Þe paiens mi?t sen ywis Þer was swiche contek and wonder Þat it dined so þe þonder. Þis ich heþen kinges þre Ato parted her meine Seuen þousand to ben þer ri?t O?ain þe fiue þousand to fi?t, And setten þer þousandes ei?te O?ain king Leodegan to fi?t Þat hem toward [com] in þat stounde Wiþ þridde half hundred of þe table rounde, Ac bi hemself þe rounde table wes (Þe king Leodegan naþeles Wiþ him brou?t þousandes to) And to þe bataile flongen þo. Þe viii þousand hem com o?ain Þer was meting of men o main Wiþ spere and wiþ scharp sword Þer les mani man his lord Þer was sched so michel blod Þat it ran as a flod, Leodegan wiþ his fewe Noble main he gan to shewe He slou? þre o?aines anne And craked mani hern-panne, Þe kni?tes of þe table rounde Mani þer slou? in litel stounde And bilimeden and feld of hors Mani heþen orped cors Ac þei her swerdes wele þer bite And to ded mani smite It was swiþe litel sene For o?aines on þer wer tene, Ac so sarre was þe þrang Þat non mi?t com hem omang. Þe Sarra?ins hadde gret despite Þat so hem schent swiche popel lite He swore bi Mahoun and Dagon Hem no schuld ascape non And drou? hem wel fer aroume (Þat Crist hem ?eue confusioun!) And baren doun in þat stounde ?ete fourti of þe table rounde And were abouten, hem to dere Ac her feren hem gun were Þat he no hadde power non Non of hem forto slon. Þat time was Leodegan Feld adoun and his man ?ete an hundred oþer mo, Leodegan þai nomen þo And beten him sore and ?euen him wounde And to an hors fast him bounde And token fif hundred kni?tes To lade him forþ anon ri?tes, And so þai deden sikerliche Defuiland vilanliche Toward þe riche king Rion And wenden her bataile were ydon, And þo þe king Leodegan Him sei?e fer fram al his man And him aboute socour non And him loþeliche lade to king Rion ‘Allas’ he seyd ‘þat y was bore Mi liif and priis so is forlore And Gvenoure mi dohter gent Of vile paiems worþ yschent And alle min noble kni?tes Worþ yslawe adoun ri?tes And þe leuedis of mi lond Alle ynomen in payems hond’— For ri?t gret sorwe and care Aswon he fel as he ded ware To gret mile fram þe bataile Þo he was, wiþouten faile. His douhter stode on þe cite-wal And biheld þis misauentour al Hir hondes sche sett on hir here And hir fair tresses al totere Sche hir totar to hir smok And on þe wal hir heued gan knok And swoned oft and seyd, allas Þat hir socour lorn was, So deden al þo of þe cite Maden endeles pite. Þe kni?tes of þe table rounde Kedden þai were men of mounde, Bitven hem þai wolden speke Leodegan þai wolden awreke Oþer steruen þai wolden alle And renged hem o?ain þe walle For þai no sei?en no socour And schewed þo her vigour Þridde half hundred o?ain m seuen Me þenkeþ certes þat was vneuen Ac þer þai fou?ten vnder þe toun And mani Sarra?in leyd adoun Hem þai tohewen and hors also Þay þoled michel pine and wo, Þe citisains þat ysei?e And sore wepen wiþ her ei?e— Now lete we hem fi?tand here And speke we of Arthour and his fere. Now seyt our tale saun faile Þat orible is þe bataile Of gret crie and swiþe strong Almest þennes fiue forlong Þat Arthour held wiþ fourti and to And Cleodalis wiþ four þousand and mo, O?aines hem Sornegreons and king Sapharen Þat seuen þousand hadd wiþ hem, So fele paiems þer lay slawe Þat fele hepes þer lay on rawe Of armed men of fatt stede Þat her liif þer les to mede. Þo seyd Merlin to his ferrede ‘Now me suweþ alle ich rede’ Forþ riden þe fourti and to So swiþe so þe hors mi?t go, Þer bileued Cleodalis Wele fi?tand and al his; Þo Merlin hadde riden a while Þe mountaunce of to mile He seyd to king Arthour and Ban ‘Lo ?ond men ledeþ Leodegan Ybounden toward king Rion On hard dede forto slon, After hem now dasseþ swiþe And oftakeþ hem biliue ?if ?ou ascapeþ of hem ten Schal i ?ou neuer held men.’ Þai stirten forþ and ouertoke hes And dassed hem amid þe pres, Þe first slou? Merlin verrament To ?euen þe oþer gode talent, Arthour smot on hem saun faile So on þe singel doþ þe haile So we finden on þe bok Al he slou? þat he oftok, So dede Ban þe gode kni?t He clef mani on doun ri?t, So dede king Bohors He slou? þer mani heþen cors, So deden al þo gentil feren Her swerdes þai dede in blod steren Alle þai laiden doun ri?t And made þer swiche a slei?t Þat man sei?e neuer in so litel stounde So fewe bring so fele to grounde For þer no schaped fram hem oliue Of fiue hundred vnneþe fiue, Þer men mi?tten haue frely Four c steden for gramerci Þat ?ede drawend her bridel brod To þe fitlokes in þe blod. Þus Arthour and his felawered Deliuerd Leodegan fram þe dede, Michel wonder had Leodegan Þat swiche a litel poine of man So fele in so litel þrawe So manliche had yslawe, Bi þe dragon þat kest fer He wist it were þe newe souders Þat he was deliuerd fram his fon He þonked Ihesu Crist anon. Þo li?t þe clerk Merlin And sir Bretel and sir Vlfin And þe king Leodegan vnbounde And sett him on a stede of mounde And armed him fineliche wel And dede on his heued an helm of stiel About his nek a scheld strong And toke him a launce long And sett him vp as a king Þat er lay as a breþeling, He ioined his honden ioe vus di And ?alt hem þank and gramerci. On his stede þo lepe Merlin, So dede Bretel and sir Vlfin, Þo seyd Merlin ‘Mine kni?tes fre Prikeþ ?our stedes and folweþ me’ So þai deden wiþouten abod So aruwe of bowe ich forþ glod. Ac þo Gvenoure opon þe walle Þis to and fourti sei?e com alle Bi þe dragon þat cast fer Þat flei?e into þe skies cler Sche wist it were þe fourti and to, Hir fader sche sei?e com also On hors yarmed and wele atired And fram his fon þurth hem deliuerd— No ask no man of þe gret blisse Þat sche made þan ywis And al þe men þat it sei?en For ioie þai wepe wiþ her ei?en. Þis þre and fourti com on hast Wiþ norþþen-winde so doþ tempast, Þe kni?tes of þe table rounde Þai founden alle felled to grounde Þat stoden afot and wered hem O?ain on euer xx and ten, Bot xx of hem openliche On hors fou?ten nobliche And ouercarked weren þo Her liif þat was nei?e ago. Þis xliii of gret mounde So dassed on þe heþen hounde Þat ich of hem who so mett Hastiliche þe heued of grett And slowen hem doun into þe grounde Mani geaunt in litel stounde, Euerich dede swiþe wel Wiþ scharpe swerd of gode stiel Mani þai smiten þurth saun faile Fram þe top to þe taile Of sum þe side God it wot Wiþ scheld and arme eueri grot Of sum þe midel euen ato Of sum þei and legge also, Auberk aketoun and scheld Was mani tobroken in þat feld And mani paiem wiþ deþes wounde And mani stede coruen to grounde; Þe king himself þer Leodegan Wele him wrake of his foman, O?ain þe þre and fourti of our Non armour no mi?t dour No hors of priis no heþen kni?t Þat he nas dede anon ri?t. Þer was an heþen king hi?t Canlang Fiftene fet he was lang (He and anoþer þat strengest were Of alle þe paiems þat were þere) Þis dede his mi?t saun fable To stroie þe kni?tes of þe rounde table. King Arthour mett Canlang Togider þai made fi?ting strang And so strong was Canlang verrament Þat king Arthour mi?t fest no dent To him haue bot bihinde Bot ones he him hitt, kerueinde Vnder þe scheld, þe scholder on Þurthout armes and flesche and bon Vnto þe nouel he him carf, Þe misbileueand paiem starf A boþe half his hors he hing Þat ernne forþ [c]rudand in þat þring. Þe paiems sei?e Canlang so hit Agrisen of þat dint out of wit; Gvenour þat dint of Arthour seye And þonked Ihesu Crist on hei?e And ‘?eue þat he mi lord were Þat ?ong þat fi?teþ so þere,’ Anon seyden al her men ‘So were it me dame amen For we no sei?e neuer of his power Noiþer eld man no bacheler.’ King Ban þo mett Clarion Þat oþer strongest of euerichon He was gret xiiii fet long And swiþe gret and swiþe strong He hadde mani of our yslawe, King Ban him mett wiþouten awe So we finden in þe boke And ouer þe ere he him toke Þe cheke he carf þe schulder also To þe girdel þe dint gan go His ribbes and scholder fel adoun Men mi?t se þe liuer abandoun; King Bohort of gent power Met Sarmedon þe gomfanoun-bere On þe schulder he him hit Þat arm and scholder of he kit His scheld and his gomfanoun And himself þer fel adoun. King Leodegan þo gan crie ‘For loue of þe quen Marie Bistireþ ?ou min gentil kni?tes And leggeþ doun þis paiems ri?tes!’ Þe kni?tes of þe table rounde Alle lopen on hors o mounde And hewen on þe Sarra?in Wiþ gode wille and hert fin. Þe paiems sei?e ded Canlang And Clarion þat was so strang And þe baneour Sormedon Þo þai nist what to don Ac so swiþe so þai mi?t Oway flowen anon ri?t, To þousand com out of þe cite And feld hem doun wiþouten pite Wiþ kni?tes of þe table rounde Þai hewen he[m] doun vnto þe grounde. King Arthour and king Ban King Bohort and king Leodegan And þe fourti li?t and wiþstode And gerten her stedes gode Þurth conseil of Merlin ywis And went and holpen Cleodalis Þe king[es] steward Leodegan Þat fau?t o?ain seuen m man Wiþ four þousand and namore So ?e herden herebifore, Þis fourti and to and on Opon þis seuen þousand smiten anon And hewen on wiþ gret powers On schides so doþ þis carpenters— It was nede for Cleodalis Stode on fot, and mani of his Aboute him stode sarreliche Fram deþ to were sikerliche. Þer king Arthour and Bohort and Ban And þe king Leodegan Paiems wiþouten tale slouwe A þousand stedes her bridels drowe Þis þre and fourti fou?ten so For?eten mi?t it be neuer mo For þe blod of kni?tes dede And of destre[r]s and of stede Ran hem after al day so ?erne So water out of wel-streme, Þurth þe pouwer and mi?t of þos Cleodalis þat kni?t of los Was ybrou?t on hors ywis And kni?tes oþer fele of pris. Þe kinges of þo heþen man Heten Sornegrex and Saphiran Aiþer of hem was xiiii fot lang And swiþe hardi and swiþe strang And hadden swiþe gret despite Þat hem schent pople so lite, A schille horn þai gun blawe Togider þai gader her felawe. Kay and Vlfin, þe buteler, And Grifles þat was of gret power Ich of hem tok a launce long And dassed þe Sarra?ins among Kay king Sornigrex hitt And kest him to grounde in þat flit And rode on him wiþ his hors And defoiled his cursed cors And had him slawe wiþouten letting Ac mani com to þis rideing, Wiþ his launce dan Lucan Þe hert þurth smot of Abadan, Ac on hors in þis toiling Was brou?t Sornigrex þe king. Þo aros gret batail and strif For of þe Sarra?ins ?ete m fif, Were ouercomen vnder þe wal, Þider were flowen alle Þerfore so fel þer were Þat litel was sene her slei?ster þer. King Sornigrex þat was yfeld His bodi tobrussed tobroken his scheld For schame he was out of wit Our folk he þou?t forto hit And gred to alle þo Sarains Þat for loue of Apolins Þai schuld of al his fon Him awreke sone anon, Of Sara?ins gret þreng About our Cristen made reng And hem biclepten in þat place And leyden on wiþ swerd and mace And wiþ axes and wiþ gisharm Our folk þai deden michel harm; Ac in þis ich self stounde Kni?tes of þe table rounde Þat folweden þe paiems fleinde Al on hors com flinginde And sei?e þe pensel of fourti and to Þat day þat hadde hem holpen so, Into bataile to hem þai drowen Alle þat þai met þai doun slowen Boþe wiþ launce and swerd bri?t Þo þai metten þai slou? doun ri?t And þurth mi?t þai keuerden so Þat þai com to fourti and to And þo so gret slei?t made Þat y no may it fulrade. At þe oþer half Cleodalis Fau?t wiþ Sarra?ins of priis Þat wiþ gret iniquite Brou?t hem o?ain to þe cite, Þe strong king Saphiran It was þat fau?t him o?an Wiþ nei?en þousand verrament And dede him gret encumbrement; Ac þo ich to þousinde Þat folwed þe oþer fleinde To help þer com Cleodalis And on þe paiems smot ywis, In her coming and smiten to grounde A þousand paiems in þat stounde And þurth þe [h]elp of our Dri?t Cleodalis halp wele to fi?t And helden gode contre o?an Saphiran and al his man. Þo nar þo wiþ king Arthour Bot to and fourti of valour And of þe rounde table kni?tes To hundred and fifti wi?te No more þer ner so y finde And fou?ten o?ain viii þousinde, Sornegrex hete her king An hardi paiem þurth al þing. Þer hadde ben miche mischef No had Merlin seyd a conseil bihef ‘Bieu seygnours y nil nou?t hele Of þis paiems beþ so fele Þat we no may o?ain hem doure, Bot to mi conseil nimeþ coure Her ben among þis Sarra?ins Ten geauntes wel strong afins And þai were of dawe ydon Þe bataile were passed sone’ Þai asked him wiche þai were And he hem tau?t anon ri?t þere. King Ban þat was gode and strong Tok his swerd in his hond His stede he smot and forþ glod O?ain king Sornegrex he rode His helme he smot bi þe side Þurth helme and palet it gan glide Fram þe cheke þe neb he bar Þe scheld fram þe schulder þar And þe left arme and þe hond Ich vnderstond he dede him schond, Þe Sarra?ins kest a gret cri And flei?e oway wiþ gret hy. Bohort met Marganan And smot þat vnsely man On þe helme ichot forsoþ Þat he him cleued to þe toþ King Arthour so Dieu me saut Met wiþ [an] amiral was hoten Sinalaut On þe helme he him hitt And a quarter þerof kitt, On þe schulder slod þe dent And kitt it of verrament And þerwiþ ribbes four Þe painem starf wiþ misantour. Sir Vlfin slou? þo Sabalant And Bretel þe douk Cordant Þe steward Kay slou? dan Deriard And Lucan þe boteler slou? Malard And Grifles so slou? Menadap And Meragys slou? þe douke Sadap And Gornenis slou? þe douke Maupas And Craddok slou? Darrilas. Þese were þe geauntes ten And princes of þe heþen men, Þo þe paiems hem ded sei?e A cri þai gun areren hei?e And seyd it were deuelen þat þai wiþ fou?ten Sikerliche so hem þou?ten, Þai flowen oway wiþouten abode Our folk swiþe after hem rode And to grounde slou? doun ri?t Al þat þai oftake mi?t Þre þousend þai slowen of þe ei?tte. Þe oþer ascaped anon ri?t To þe riche king Saphiran Þo were þai xiiii þousand of man And smiten on Cleodalis Þat had bot four þousand ywis And þe to þat comen out of þe cite, Þer men sei?e wel gret pite Hou þe painems and king Saphiran Defoiled our Cristen men A þousand and mo þai slowen Þe remanant of hors drowen; Oft Cleodalis was wo Ac neuer wers þan him was þo Ydriuen he was vnder þe toun And loked after þe dragoun Þat Merlin bar ac he no mi?t Nowhar of him han a si?t, No þe kni?tes of þe rounde table Mi?t he nowhar se saun fable He wende þat dede þai hadden ben, Þer mi?t men gret pite sen Now he flowe now he wiþstode For drede he was nei?e wode, Þe citaisins þan sei?e þis And reweliche cri maden ywis. Ac þurth Merlin so ich finde Arthour was bileued bihinde And þe oþer wiþouten fable, Þe kni?tes of þe rounde table, And adden alle adoun ali?t Her stedes girt [þ]e sadels ri?t And soft and sarre saun faile [C]om to þis reweful bataile; Þo on þe walles of þe toun Sei?e comand þe dragoun Þo seyd þe fair leuedis To þe steward Cleodalis ‘Cleodalis þou gentil k[ni]?t Bistir þe and hardiliche fi?t For ?onder doun in þe valaie ?ou comeþ socour of gret noblay We seþ þe dragoun þat casteþ fer And after þe newe souders And Le[o]degan wiþ hem saun fable And þe kni?tes of þe rounde table Alle þai comen ?erne apli?t, Now kiþe þou art a noble kni?t’— Cleodalis in alle his liue Nas neuer ?ete so bliþe Þo he and his kni?ten So wele fou?ten so þai mi?ten. Arthour and Ban and king Bohort Þer hem com to gret comfort Wiþ her folk of gret mounde Þre hundred þai bar to grounde, Ac a left half and a ri?t King Arthour slou? doun ri?t Wiþ Esclabor his swerd so gode Þat day he schad so michel blode Also dede þe king Ban, Þer slou? mani heþen man, Bohort his broþer and eke he Spard noiþer þral no fre Of stiel no yren armes nan No mi?t doure hem o?an, No may y noiþer telle no rede Hou wele þai deden, her ferrede, Ac þe leuedis on þe tour ?erne biheld king Arthour And hadde wonder of his ?ingþe Þat þer kidde swiche strengþe. Þe heþen king Saphiran Despite hadde of so fewe men So miche folk þat slowen þo Mani geaunce þai cleued ato, He cleped to him Sortibran And Senebant and Engredan Molore and eke Frelent And Clariel a geaunt gent Landon and ek Moras And Randel þat noble was, To hem aloude he gan to speke Wiþ launce his anoie to wreke. Forþ dassed þe king Saphiran Þat vnsely hoge man Herui Riuel and his hors gent He frust doun at o dent Þat hors and man astuned lay, ?ete forþ he dassed par ma fay And þrewe sir Antor of his hors Þat al þat day him was þe wors, ?ete forþer he gan ride And smot Grifles bi þe side And kest him to þe grounde His launce brac in his wounde, And Sortibran wiþ iusting cler Feld Luca[n]s þe buteler, Clariel feld Meraugys And sore hirt him ywis, Engredan feld Gor[n]ains and Craddoc And sore agreued our floc, Senebant þrewe doun Bleoberis And his hors vnder him ywis, Þus þe geauntes our kni?tes þrewe; Our men gun it sore rewe Non of hem had dedeli wounde Ac sone stirt vp in þat stounde And wiþ scharpe swerdes of stiel Wered hem manliche wel, Our folk abuten hem gan þrest And socourd hem wiþ þe best. And ?ete in þis strong rideing Com Saphiran þe heþen king And in his hond a launce strong Þat was boþe gret and long Leodegan on þe scheld he hitt And wiþ strengþe it þurth slit, His hond he bar hei?e ferly Þe launce glod þe king forby Þat ran þurth þe hors bihinde King and hors adoun gan winde; ‘Allas’ þai seyd on þe tounes wal ‘Now we han ylorn al’ Þai wende þe king yslawe ware And maden diol and sorweful fare, Gvenour made gret diol ywis And so dede al þo leuedis Þat þat ich dint ysawe Þai wende þe king were yslawe— So he hadde forsoþ yben No hadde oþer stirt bitven And him halp in þat rideing. Þo spac Arthour þe king ‘Certes’ he seyd ‘þis nis no game Þe paiems doþ ous swiche schame’ And swore he wold sterue anon Oþer him awreke of his fon And namlich on Saphiran, ‘Nay lete me’ quaþ king Ban ‘For þou art to ?ong and ek to lite O?ain swiche a deuel to smite.’ Þo seyd Merlin to Arthour A word of gret deshonour ‘Wat abidestow coward king? Þe paiem ?if anon meteing!’ For schame Arthour was nei?e wode In wratþe brent al his blod His hors he smiteþ and he forþ glod O?ain king Saphiran he rode, Saphiran sei?e war he cam A strong launce in hond he nam Toforn him his scheld he grope Stef he strei?t his stirope His stede he smot of gret valour And rode o?ain king Arthour— A deuel rod o?ain a child. King Ban for drede was nei wilde And rode after king Arthour To helpen him par auentour. Saphiran wiþ king Arthour mett Wiþ mi?t gret on him stett His scharp launce gan to glide Þurth Arthour scheld and his side, Þe speres schaft al torof; Arthour nam no ?eme þerof Ac in sadel sat vpri?t To mete Saphiran apli?t, His launce he bar þurthout his scheld And þurth þe hauberk felefeld Þurth þe wombe and þurth þe chine Þe spere ?ede euen bi line, Quaþ Arthour ‘Þou heþen cokin Wende to þi deuel Apolin!’ Þe paiem fel ded to grounde His soule lau?t helle-hounde. G[v]eneoure sat on þe cite-walle And þe oþer leuedis alle Of Arthour sei?e iusting þis On him þai laiden al þe priis. Anon after þe king Ban Met þe geaunt Sortibran And on þe scholder so him hit Þe side fram þe bodi kitt, Þo com Malore and Frelent And nomen Ban þat king so gent Bi þe helme wiþ her hond, To smite of his heued þai gun fond; Þis ysei?e þe king Arthour And smot his stede to þat socour Malore in þe heued he hitt Þe heued fram þe bodi he kitt. Þo þou?t þe paiem Frelent Awreke his cosyn of þat dent To Arthour wiþ main he smot His scheld he clef God it wot And of his hauberk a gore And of his aketoun a fot and more Ac he no tok nou?t his flesche, Herof Arthour anoid wes A dint he smot anon to him And cleue his helme and eke bacin And al þe heued to þe brest, Þe paien fel wiþ iuel rest. Þe paiens schirt and made dol For þai no hadde þo bot Randol A geaunt þat bar [þ]e gomfanoun Alle þe oþer were leyd adoun, Þe paiens of deþ hadden doute And alle wenten Randol aboute Ac Ban no leued for no doute Þat he no dassed hem þurthout And Randoil on þe schulder he smot Wiþ his swerd þat wele bot Þurthout hauberk and aketoun To þe midel al adoun, Þe pensel fel and eke Randoil. Þe paiens þerof hadden diol And gun rere a wel foule crie So dorren don and flesche-flei?en And for sorwe and drede and ei?e Þai flowen euerich his wei?e, King Arthour wiþouten abade And alle þe oþer of whom y tofore sade After þis paiens fling And mani of hem to deþ sting Wiþ scharp swerd of gode egge Þe liif þai dede mani on legge; Of xiiii þousand, boten fiue No aschaped to king Rion oliue Wiþ michel sorwe and michel care And þat al forwounded ware. King Rion al þai teld Hou her feren weren aqueld, Wel wroþ was king Rion þo And made diol and michel wo And swiftliche he sent his sond Oueral into Irlond And into Danmark also, Þe messangers forþ gun go Þat bere letters and tidinges To on and xx strong kinges To hundred m þat schulden bring And l m of heþen genge And for to ?er her spending— And so þai dede wiþouten lesing. After þis bataile and scumfite Our men boþe gret and lite Togider gaderd hem comonliche And comen hom nobleliche And biforn hem driuen al þe pray Of xx c cartes y say And com to Carohaise þat riche toun Wiþ ioie and wiþ processioun; King Leodegan þo hete His men nimen þat pray skete Þat in þe tventi c cartes was Taken it Arthour more and las So deden þe kinges kni?tes, Arthour nome it anon ri?tes And parted it wel curtaisliche Bi Merlins conseil sikerliche And so miche ?af his ost Blaise Þat riche hem made and wele at aise. Ac Arthour no Ban no forþ his host No lenge wiþ Blasie soiourne most Ac to court þai were yfeched ra[þ]e And ydon in riche baþe; Gveneour wesche þe king Arthour And Ban and Bohort wiþ honour, Gvenore anoþer damisel And oþer maiden fair and fel Weschen alle her gentil feren— Here ?e schul now yheren Hou þe oþer Gvenour was bi?ete Y wil þat ?e it alle wite. Þo Leodegan spoused his quene A burmaiden he hadde fair and schene, On fair maner and gentil wise Þat serued þe leuedi of hei?e prise, Þe kinges steward Cleodalis Sei?e þis maiden of gret prise And spac so fair to þe king Þat he wedded þat swete þing. After a ?er oþer to ywis Þat gentil kni?t Cleodalis Went þer him hete þe king And left his wiif in þe quenes ?eming And ich ?ou sigge par ma fay In þe quenes chaumber sche lay. Ich ni?t it was þe quenes maner To chirche gon and matins here, Also þe quen herd matines Þe king aros bi wrongful lines And what bi loue and what bi striif He forlay þe stewardes wiif And bi?at a maide of gret mounde Þat was Gvenour þe secounde, And fram þat time al afterward He binam þe wif his steward And hadde hir fer in on trist Whiderward þe steward nist Naþeles Cleodalis Þat gentil kni?t of michel priis Noiþer in seruise no in bataile No feined o?ain þe king saun faile; Þis Gvenour was þe oþer so liche So pani is oþer sikerliche. Þese weschen þis gentil man And leyd tables after þan. Leodegan nam ?eme wi[ch] onour Alle þe oþer born king Arthour, King Arthour sat wiþouten fable Midelest at þe hei?e table King Ban at his ri?t half sat Ac þe oþer half king Bohort at Afterward her compeinie Was yset þritti and neie And next hem wiþouten fable Sat þe kni?tes of þe rounde table, After þat ysett were þere Al þo oþer after þai were. In halle þai hadden riche seruise, Whereto schuld y þat deuise? Ac Gveneour wiþouten les Serued Arthour of þe first mes; Leodegan þat wele y say Biheld his douhter and Arthour noblay So michel on hem he þou?t Þat of mete no drink he no rou?t, A noble kni?t Herui de Riuel Vndernam his semblaunt wel And seyd ‘Sir þi þou?t lete be And make þine ostes gamen-gle, Eten and drink men schal on benche And after mete in chaumber þenche,’ Þe king þis tale vnderstode And made his gestes semblaunt gode. Ac on Gveneour biheld Arthour And was al nomen in hir amour Ac he tempred so his blod Þat non oþer it vnderstode; Gvenoure on knewes oft gan stoupe To serue king Arthour wiþ þe coupe And he seyd to hir saun faile ‘Crist lete me ?eld þe þi trauaile,’ And sche seyd to him ‘Sir gramerci It nis nou?t to ?eld sir ie vus dy Ac swiche a þou[s]and so y be Sir no mi?t it ?eld þe Þe help and þe trauail and þe honour Þat ?e han don to mi lord and ?our socour, Yherd be Ih[es]us Cristes sond Þat ?ou sent into þis lond’— Gveneour was euer tofor Arthour And serued him wiþ gret honour And bifor eueri gentil man was Maidens to serue wiþ gret solas. Þer were trumpes and fiþelers And stiuours and tabourers Þai eten and dro[n]ken and made hem glade And þo þai were al glad made Þe cloþes weren vp ydrawe And þai weschen so it was lawe. After mete asked king Ban To þe king Leodegan Whi Gvenour his douhter precious To sum gentil man [n]ere yspouse Seþþen he no hadde non airs, ‘Certes sir’ quaþ Leodegan vairs ‘?if were ner so mot y liue Sche were mani day y?eue, Wist ich owhar ani bacheler Vigrous and of mi?t cler And he were of gode linage Þei he nadde non hirritage Mi douhter ich wald him ?iue And al mi þing wiþ to liue’— For king Arthour þat he seyd. Merlin þo toforn hem pleyd And cleped vp king Arthour and Ban And her feren fram Leodegan So þat Leodegan mi?t of noþing More wite of her being; Þer seyd Merlin anon ri?t To king Arthour al þe slei?t Þat Wawain and his feren of mounde Hadde ydon biside Lounde And al þat þerwhiles schuld falle He teld þer biforn hem alle, Wherþurth bliþe in þat toun Þai bileft til þe Assensioun. Lete we now here king Arthour And his feren wiþ gret honour And hereþ of þe chaunces ille Þerwhiles in Inglond bifelle. Listneþ now fele and fewe, In May þe sonne felleþ dewe Þe day is miri and draweþ along Þe lark arereþ her song To mede goþ þis damisele And fair floures gadreþ fele. King Arthour is leued at Carohaise And alle his frendes wele at aise, And euerich cite þat was his owe Castels tours hei?e and lowe He dede warnise wiþ store þan Þat he no douted non haþen man, Ac swiþe gre[t] confussiouns Bifel þerwhiles to our barouns Þat were ywent ato wel wide Euerich to loke his owen side. In þis time a messanger cam To þe king sir Cradelman And seyd so ich writen finde ‘Of paiens xx þousinde Comeþ a boþe half Arundel Yarmed swiþe wel.’ Swiftliche þe king Cradelman Nam x þousand armed man, Haluendel tok Pollidamas His nevou þat gode kni?t was Þe oþer del himseluen he tok So we finden on þe boke Þai riden forþ anon ri?t Til þai com to hem apli?t And founden hem on a grene plas Ich of hem slepeand was; Al abouten þai biclept hes And smiten on wiþouten les, Wiþ hors fete þai riden hem on And þurth stongen mani on, Þurth swerd and ax spere and kniif Þer les mani a man þe liif. Non hadde mi?t hem to were Noiþer wiþ swerd no wiþ spere Ac alle þat euer mi?t flen Swiþe gun oway ten To a castel wiche held Cramile Þennes ouer þre mile Hei?e and strong a roche opon (Hir broþer hi?t Bordogabron, Þer was in wiþ hir þo XX þousand paiems and mo), XV þousand king Cradelman Slou? of þat heþen man Þe fiue þousand flowen oway Our folk hem suwed par ma fay. Þe paiens þat wiþ Cramile were Her feren þai sei?e misfare ‘As armes!’ gred alle þat þer was Boþe þe more and þe lasse, XIIII þousand lopen on stede Armed alle in riche wede And smiten on king Cradelman, Þer was miche slei?t of man. Þerwhiles þe gentil men of Arundel Wenten out and deden wel— Gold and siluer and purpel pelles Mete and drink and mani þing elles Þat þe paiens þer hadden late, Þai went to Arundel and schet þe gate And stowen vp hei?e on þe walle To sen what mi?t to our bifalle. Bi þat þai com on þe wal on hei?e Cradelman was scomfite nei?e, Doun þai lepen of þe walle And ‘As armes!’ þai gredden alle On gode hors þai lepen of priis (Fiue hundred þer were ywis) To socour and comen anon And halp wele Cradelman Þat hadde lorn of ten þousinde Þe þre þousand so y finde, Þe paiens of þousindes fourten Þe four hadden lorn so y wen. Ac þer swiche bataile aros A boþe half þat hem agros Ac our had hadde þer more wo No hadde a chaunce ben þat bifel þo For þe king of þe hundred kni?tes Com hem vp þo forþ ri?tes Þat hadde yherd bifore teld Hou paiens þe cuntre hadde aqueld And come priueliche paiens to aspie To binimen hem her robrie, X þousand he hadde gode kni?ten (Þe haluendel he dede di?ten To Morganor his steward In armes stalworþ and hard) Þis dasched on þe Sarra?ins Wiþ gode wille and hert fins Eueriche wiþ his strong spere Þurth a Sarra?in gan it bere V forlong he dede hem recoile And vnder hors fete defoile. Ich on oþer fast hewe Ac þe Sarra?ins þo it sewe Hou þat men her folk hit And hou fele fel in litel fit, Þai arered a cri of more wonder Þan tempest vfer, or þonder, Alle þat euer fle mi?t Oway flowen anon ri?t Ac our kni?tes and our barouns Hem tau?t so her lessouns Þat of fourten þousand fram deþ No ascaped bot þre vnneþ, Of hem ran as michel blod So in riuer when it is flod, Þer lay of paiens mani tasse Wide and side more and lasse Mani fair stede dede þer lay And mani wiþ blodi sadel ?ede astray, For seþþen first, in on þrawe Fiftene þousand þer were yslawe, And er weren also ich finde Afor yslawe þritten þousinde, Þus fele þai slou? of haþen Þat schuld hem no more waite scaþen; It þou?t hem a fair praie Ac þo at arst agan her ioie For euerich oþer knewe sone And þonked God midydone Of þe help and þe socour Þat eueriche dede oþer wiþ vigour, And anon wiþouten onde Went into Arundel ich vnderstond And dede biri þat ich day Þe Cristen in chirche-hay. Of þe paiens þat were in lond Gret conseil þai held ich vnderstond. Þo seyd þe king Angvigenes, Þe king of þe hundred kni?tes wes ‘Ich rede we sende our sond To alle our peres of þis lond Þat we ous geder togider alle And on þe paiens at ones falle And fonden bi fine mi?t To slen hem alle doun ri?t.’ ‘Certes’ quaþ Cradelman ‘Me þink þat nere nou?t wele don For o?ain on of our men Beþ mo þan þritti and ten, ?ete is better for ich cas Þat eueriche baroun loke his pas And aspie hem bi tropie And so fond hem to astroie, No schal ich no non of mine Ben bihinde for deþ no pine.’ Þo þai hadden seyd þis word Ich bitau?t oþer our Lord Anon hom ich of hem went cert Of þat pray ich hadde his part Whereþurth þai mi?ten, after long, Þe better hem ?eme fram wer and wrong— Lete we now þes bileuen here And speke we now of her fere. Þer comen vp fer bi norþ Ten riche soudans of gret worþ Þe first king hete Oriens Þe oþer hete Pongerrens Þe þridde hete Manginoires Þe ferþ het Gondeffles Þe fift soudan het Sorbars And þe sext het Pincenars Þe seuend soudan het Fraidons And þe hei?te Salbrons Þe nei?d het Maliaduc Þe tenþ Vargon an heþen douc, Þes comen vp so ich finde Wiþ fiften c þousinde And wiþ þe stouer of to ?are Þerwiþ þai mi?t wele fare, Ac þo þai comen vp on lond Þai senten her folk ich vnderstond Bi seuen þousand and bi hei?te Vplondis men to sle doun ri?t, Bi ni?en þousand and bi ten Þai senten about to slen our men. In þis sorweful time and lange Into þe cite of Coruanges Messangers com to Angvisaunt þe king And teld him reweful tiding ‘Sir’ he seyd ‘bitven þis cite and Lanernv Fiftene þousand be comen nov Sarrains þat wiþ fire wilde Brennen man wiif and childe, Bot þou hem socoureþ anon Þai be forlorn eurichon.’ Þe king was sori and noþing bliþe ‘As armes!’ he grad swiþe, XV þousand al armed ywis Þer lopen on gode hors of priis, To on hille and gun hem hei?e Þis mesauentour forto aspie Þo sei?e þai al þe cuntray Stonden brenand on rede lei?e Man and woman vrn so dere Oueral for dout of þe fer, Mani man for drede lete his wiif Þe wiif hir child þe child his liif, Quaþ king Angvisaunt ‘Woleway Þat ich euer bot þis day And þat ich euer schuld sen Þus miche rewþe on erþe ben.’ His men þer he schift ato Half he tok himself and mo And haluendel he toke Gaudin Þat was a kni?t hardi and fin, Þat seþþen wiþ his mi?ti hand Wan þat maiden of þe douke Branland; Þese smiten þe hors of priis And deden hem gon gode scour ywis, Þurth mani bodi haþen Her launces þai dede baþen After þat her swerdes þai drowen And sex þousand to grounde slowen Als who seyt, al for nou?t, For þai wer abrod ydrey?t. Ac sone þerafter nou?t forþan Fourti þousand after hem cam Ac our þurth Godes mi?t Wele hem stode o?ain to fi?t And cleued mani heþen hounde Fram þe to[p] to þe grounde And deden al forþ manliche For leuer hem were be ded sikerliche In manschippe and in trewþe Þan euer more liue in rewþe And so nobliche her dint bisett Þat neuer men no deden bet. Allas allas! Gret pite Sone fel on þis gent meine Lenger douren þai no mi?t For opon hem com anon ri?t Þe forseyd soudans ten Wiþ alle þe cuntre wrei?en of men And biclept al about Our litel Cristen rout And slou? of our compainie Verament þousandes ni?e, Þo was þer of xv þousand Yleued bot sex bihinde And þe oþer flowen also ?erne So her stedes mi?t erne Ac þer no hadde non scaped oway Nadde chaunce comen fram Crist on hei?e— Vriens þe king of Schorham Þe Sarra?ins bihinde cam And his nevou Baldemagu A strong kni?t of gret vertu Wham Vriens ?af half his lond Out of Owains his sones hond, Þese wiþ hem xii þousinde brou?t Þat of dede litel rou?t. Men hem teld of michel sorwe Þerfore þai went out bi þe morwe And þou?t to don sum alegaunce Pouer men of her greuaunce And comen hem sodanliche Opon alle þe paiens sikerliche, Þese weren alle gode kni?t And flongen opon þe paiens anon ri?t Wiþ strong launce God it wot Euerich a paiem þurth smot And sum wiþ o launce-schaft What þurth mi?t and Godes craft Four oþer fiue slowe Þerafter ich his swerd drowe, And ich ?ou telle for soþe and siker Þer bigan a stern biker For þe Sarra?ins turned o?en On king Vrien and his men; Þer was mani heued of weued And mani to þe midel cleued And mani of his hors ylust, Forsoþe þer ros so michel dust Þat of þe sonne schineand bri?t No man mi?t haue no si?t, Here and þer crie and honteye Men mi?t hem heren þre mile-way. King Anguisaunt and meine his Was yflowen a fer weys, Socour com þat he vnderstode And turned o?ain wiþ hardi mode On þe Sarra?ins and smite Wiþ swerdes þat wele bite And a þousand on a rawe Þai haden sone brou?t o dawe, Þat was bataile of mende Bitven deuelen and kni?tes hende. Þe Sarra?ins ost and pray Last fele mile-way; Vriens at þat o nende fau?t And his kni?tes þat spared nau?t, Angvisant fau?t at þe oþer ende, Non no mi?t com oþer hende No bi fele wayes sen So fele deuelen hem were bitven. Our folk wi?tliche hem gan were Wiþ ex and swerd and scharpe spere, ?ete hadde þai lorn gret lore and slei?st ?if on hem no hadde comen þe ni?t Þat þai ne sei?e miche no lite Ani to oþer ari?t to smite; Ich wot forsoþe of þe heþen men Were yslawe swiche ten Þan were of our Cristiens. Ac swiþe anon þo wiþþerwins Her pauilouns þo telten ri?t Forto bileue al þat ni?t; King Aguisaunt went hom To Coranges ri?t anon— Ni?en þousinde hem were yslawe, Þo þe citeseines it sawe Þer was mani leuedi Þat sore biwepe her ami And mani gentil damisele Hir fader biwepe wiþ teres fele Þe soster biwepe her broþer And euerich frende biwepe oþer. Þis time went king Vrien To þe cite wiþ alle his men, Also he com bi þe way He fond cartes and michel praye And loges and pauilouns Telt on a grene, swiþe roum, Þo asked king Vrien Wiþ whom þai weren and wos men, Þai seyd wiþ king Brangore And Wandlesbiri [þai] lay [f]ore— Of Sessoine þis hei?e king was, And hadde made al þis purchas Opon our men ywis For þe sibred of douke Angis; King Vriens wiþouten abode And al his folk on hem rode, On her heueden and feld adoun Boþe longes and pauiloun. To mete þai weren alle yset Forsoþe hem was litel þe bet For on hem were stet þe hors And defoiled her foule cors, Tables cloþes bred and wine Plater disse cop and maseline Was vnder hors fete totoiled And mani riche þing defoiled; Vnarmed were þe paiens alle Our folk hem gun to talle Wiþ swerd and ax spere and kniif Þai binome þe paiens her liif And so hem tohewe anon ri?t Þat þai nadde power o?ein to fi?t Bot were al yslawe in litel stounde Euerichon vnto þe grounde Bot fourti paiens vnneþe Þat hem ascaped fram þe de[þ]e, Wiche þat ni?t vnderfenge Oriens þat riche king And miche biment þat he no mi?t Awreken hem þat ich ni?t Ac amorwe he wold fond Brennen and spillen al þis lond— Amonges men it were ille ?if eueriche vnwrest hadde his wille. King Vriens and his kni?tes, siker, After þis ich noble biker Token al þis riche praie Pelles purper gold and monaye, V hundred somers wiþouten lesing Þer were charged wiþ riche þing And sex hundred cartes so y biþenke Ful of flesche and mete and drinke, Alle þai ladden wiþ hem þis Into þe cite wiþ ioie and blis Þe hei?e boþe and þe lawe Þe bet ferd gret þrawe. Lete we now be þis soiourne And speke we of Oriens, wroþ and morne For þis ich viii þousinde Þat were yslawe him bihinde, Amorwe aros king Oriens And hete castels [and touns bren] And alle þe houses þat þai founde Þai schulden bren into þe grounde Man and hounde wiif and child Þai schuld bren wiþ fer wilde, And so þai deden wiþouten pite And spredden abrod in þe cuntre And setten on rede laite Al þat euer þai mi?ten awaite. Saigremor a child noble Was comen fram Costentinenoble In þis time þat ?e heren Wiþ seuen hundred gentil feren Of king Arthour kni?tes to ben ?if þai mi?t so yþen; Þes metten children and wiues And men, to sauen her liues Vrn and stirten þer and her For houndes so doþ þe wilde der, Segremor hem asked whi Þai vrn and made swiche cri, Þai seyd for drede of þe haþen Þat hem brent and dede scaþen, Þai asked where was þe king Arthour And þai him swore bi seyn Sauour To Carmalide he was ygan To help king Leodegan, ‘Certes’ quaþ Sagremoret ‘Oþer we schul sterue in þis flet Oþer doun leggen of þis haþen Þat in þis lond doþ swiche scaþen.’ Þer þai hem armed swiþe wel Boþe in iren and in stiel And v hundred of vplond Com to hem ich vnderstond, And dasched on þe paiens wiþ hert gode Þat were sprad þo abrode Þat v hundred in litel stounde Þai laiden doun wiþ deþes wounde, Ac sone afterward hem bihinde Come ?ete fourti þousinde Þat were wiþ Oriens þe king And afterward wiþouten lesing Sexti þousand and mo Come wiþ king Oriens also— Þus fele þer comen and no las, Wiþouten þe cuntre þat ful was. Ac in þis time an eld man As messanger to Wawayn cam Into þe cite of Lounde And him gret in þat stounde And seyd ‘Wele yfounden child Wawayn Crist saue þi mi?t and þi mayn And alle þi compaynie fre Þat ich here about þe se! Sagremor a ?ong man noble Is ycomen fram Costantinenoble And seuen hundred ?ong man gent To sechen king Arthour verrament Of him to afong swerd of stiel And to seruen him swiþe wel, In Souþesex þai ben ariue In strong periil of her liue Þis letters þai senten þe Her nede þou schalt yse.’ Wawain þis letters redde anon And seyd to his feren ichon ‘As armes feren! Nede it is, Y nold for þis cite ywis Þer þat Segremor were ded Bot we him holpen and deden red.’ To þeld cherl he ?aue a stede Þat hem brou?t þat message at nede And he hem tau?t þan way Toward Segremor þat ich day, Þai no hadde no desturbing No of paiens no meteing, Þis ich eld messanger Hem ledde boþe swiþe and ner Þat al bitimes saun faile Þai mi?ten com to þat bataile; Wawain hadde wiþ him so y wene Of orped boies þousandes fiftene And as he rode bi þe way Euer he gadred mo y say. Comand þese lete we And speke of Segremore so fre Fourti þousand smiten him on And he o?aines hem anon, XII hundred o?ain fourti þousinde Ferd so smoke o?ain þe winde Naþeles y telle it ?ou Seigremor and his hadde swiche vertu Þat, on of his ?if þe oþer afeld, Þero?aines tventi he queld. Ac þis was teld Oriens bihinde Þat was cominde wiþ sexti þousinde And he for þe lore and for þe anoie Þat he hadde þat oþer day Hete men schuld abouten hem gon And hem nimen euerichon, Abrode þai ?eden wiþouten doute And þe children comen about, Þe cuntre was ich way Of armed paiens f[u]l þai say Segremor no his fer No mi?t flen in non maner And hadden ment hem to ?eld Ac fer fram hem þo hye biheld Fele baners þai sei?en com And after hem gret trom Þo seyd child Sagremoret ‘?if wel gunne do we now bet For yherd be our Saueour, Y se ?ond com gret socour.’ Þan þai werd hem wiþ swerd naked Þat so fer so þai mi?ten take Non nei?e hem com no mi?t Þat þai no slowen doun ri?t. In þis time com Wawain And his feren wiþ gret main Euerich of hem gan to bere Þurth a Sarra?in wiþ his spere Afterward swerdes þai drowe And sexten þousinde to grounde slowe Mani mouþe þe gres bot And griseliche ?ened God it wot Paiens floted in her blod— Euer is Cristes mi?t gode. Wawain to Sagremor com þan And king Oriens werd him fram Wawain ?aue Oriens swiche a flat Boþe on helme and ysen hat Þat he to grounde plat þere Also he stef and stan-ded were, His folk abouten him pres made Euerich gan to crie and grade For her lord, and vp him toke So we finden on þe boke To Wawain þer com a kni?t And bad him wende anon ri?t Toward Camalot wiþ his felawe And so he dede in þat þrawe And al his feren God it wot Went toward Camalot Þerwhiles þe paiens aboute were Her soudan forto arere. Ac þerafter a litel while Wele þe mountaunce of a mile Oriens his limes drou? And gan arise of his swou? And seie þe diol sorweful and grim Þat his folk made for him, Vp he lepe wiþ chaufed blod So him no were nou?t bot god And asked anon ywis Newe armes and newe hors of priis And newe swerd and newe launce To nimen of his fon veniaunce, Þat he asked was him founde And he went forþ in þat stounde Sexti þousand paiens and mo Her steden after smiten þo; Wawain sei?e her coming coue And dede þe best wiþ hem houe Wele an tventi oþer mo And al þe oþer toforn hem go To Camalot þat cite To keueren wiþ his meine, And he bihinde to ben bi cas To susten þe paiems ras. Þe paiens ouertoken our men And fast leyd opon hem þen Ac Galathin and eke Wawain And Gveheres and Agreuain Gaheriet and Sagremore, And þe oþer y teld bifore Bihinde þat bileued were, Euer were here and tere And wiþ swerd and scheld and spere Her folk, toforn, wele gun were. Þo com Oriens to Wawain rideinde Wiþ a spere gode scoure bihinde And wende Wawain hit þurthout Ac he failed wiþouten dout For he smot him forbi, And Wawain for gret hei?e Hitt him wiþ his swerd aplat Amidward þe ysen hat Þat he tombled in þat stounde Stif aswon to þe grounde. Segremore smot Orian Russel On his schulder bi þe haterel Þat schulder and arm and ribbes alle He doun kitt wiþ liuer and ?alle; Galathin smot Placidan Amidward al his man Þat þe heued flei?e fram þe bouke, Þe soule nam þe Helle-pouke; Agreuain toke a launce long And rode o?ain a geant strong Guinat þat hete God it wot And þurth þe hert he him smot; Gveheres turned his pas O?ain a geaunt þat hete Tauras And bare him þurth wombe and rigge, His liif he dede him þere legge; Gaheriet mett þe douke Faunel Wiþ a launce, þe soket of stiel, And smot him þurth rigge and brest-bon Þe geaunt fel ded anon. ?ete þai smiten forþ on hast And þre oþer of hors cast And wiþ her meine eueri grot Smiten into Camalot, Bot Wawain and Galathin And Sagremore of gentil lin Þat riden wiþ her hors Amid Oriens cors Him forto sle wiþouten doute, Ac mani þousinde com him aboute Þat Oriens binomen hem, Ac Oriens slou? bi fiue and ten, Bi fine mi?t þai breken hem fro And into Camalahot wenten þo. Ac Wawaines breþer forsoþe to sain In Camalahot misten Wawain And þe þre deden hem o?an Wiþ hem went [no]n oþer man, Out at þe gate þis þre stetten And on his stede þat cherl metten To Wawain þat þe letters brou?t And swiþe fair þai him bisou?t He schuld hem tel fer or nei?e ?if he owar Wawain sei?e, He seyd anon to hem o?an ‘Certes ?e be nice men! Whiderward were ?e ycrope? In ?ou is ful litel hope Þat ?our broþer lete among his fon And ?e to herberwe gun gon, For ?ou he may now ligge yslawe No telle y ?ou nou?t worþ an hawe.’ Þese were aschamed and anoid Of þat þe cherl hem hadde seyd For stoutelich he haþ hem chidde Þe hors þai smiten þe spurs mide And sone þerafter her [broþer] metten Wiþ his to feren, and hem gretten And asked hou it wiþ hem was And þai seyd ‘Wele þurth Godes gras.’ Towarde þe toun anon þai stetten And þe cherles stede metten Þe arsouns blodi, bibled þe hors, Ac hye no sei?e nou?t þe cherls cors ‘Allas’ quaþ Wawain ‘allas allas! Verrament þis stede it was Þat ich ?aue þat eld man Wiþ letters to Londen þat to me cam,’ ‘?a, who rect?’ his breþer quaþe ‘Hei?e we to toun raþe’— For he hadde arst seyd hem schame Þai lowen þerof and hadde gode game. Wawain sou?t him here and þer Ac he no fond him nowhere, It nas no wonder sikerliche Merlin him turned flesche and liche And was bicomen a garsoun In hond berand a tronsoun And ?ede hem alle þo among; Þo Wawain hadde sou?t him long To Camalahot þai wenten on hast And schetten after þe gates fast Drowen brigge and eueri pin, In pais and held hem þerin. Ac þo Wawain sei?e Sagremor Þer was ioie bi Godes or Fair clepeing and welcominge And to Ihesu Crist þonkeinge Þat ich oþer hadde ydon And destroied her fon, Þer þai soiournd mani day Wiþouten ani kin anoy And sei?en paiens, seriaunce of helle, Þat no tong no mi?t telle Al day passen hem forbi Wiþ howe and noise and grete cri— Lete we hem here soiouringe And speke of þe oþer kinge. Now telleþ þis romaunce cert Oriens was sore yhert Tofore Camalahot in þe pleyn And wounded of child Wawain, For his hurtinge and his damage He was nei?e wode and eke rage He wald him wreke anon ri?t Ac it was almost þo ni?t, Ac, to eke þat, fele of our Were wiþinne walle and bour And oueralle stert him fro Þat he no mi?t comen hem to. Also fer also he mi?t His folk and he went þat ni?t And her pauilouns telt And made hem at aise wiþ fresche and selt; Amorwe king Oriens aros, Wele mani men þerof agros, Bi ten þousand and bi fiftene He sent about to do men tene He hete bern into þe grounde Man and hous al þat he founde, And so he dede þre iurneie Oueral bi ich way Man and hous þai brent and bredden And her godes oway ledden, Wiþouten no[m]bre cartes fele Þai ledden oway wiþ alle wele And setten þe cuntre a fer wilde Wiþ man and wiif and wiþ childe, Ac mani ascaped sikerlik Into þe lond of Canbernic And comen to þe douke Estas Douke of Arundel þat was, Biforn him and fel on croice And grad on him wiþ pitous voice And seyd ‘Sir for Godes gras Þine help þine ore in þis cas! Sarra?ins wiþ griseli chere Þis cuntre haþ sett afere In vplond and in toun Euerich hous han brent adoun, Of child and man and eke of wiif Alle þat þai mai nimen þai reue þe liif, Sir help ous at þis nede Oþer we ben euerichon dede!’ ‘Now Lord’ quaþ þe douke Estas ‘Help ous for þine holy gras!’ For þe pite þat he sei?e Sore he wepe wiþ his ei?e (Wiþ him was þe lord of Paerne) He gred ‘As armes!’ swiþe ?erne Ten þousand wiþ him he toke Þe oþer left þe cite to loke, Forþ he went swiþe anon What he com to king Clarion Þat woned fram him bot litel swiþe (Þe king of his cominge was bliþe) And seyd him so ich tofore teld Hou þe paiens his folk aqueld. ‘What rede’ quaþ king Clarion ‘Waldestow ?euen ous to don? ?if þai pas ous bitven We are lorn so mot y þen Man and best in þis cuntray Were destroid and alle away.’ ‘Certes’ quaþ þe douke Estas ‘We schul laten in þis pas Of our men a parti And nim wiþ ous fair compainie And wenden ous wel swiþe on hast To Brekenham to þe forest, In þe wode and hide ous And þurth þe grace of swete Ihesus So we schul wele aspie Þe paiens doinde robberie And smiten on hem and sle hem doun And þe pray bring into our toun.’ Quaþ king Clarion ‘God merci! What conseil seistow gode ami? Hou schuld we o?ain hem fi?t? Y dar þe mi treuþe now pli?t Þei our folk tohewen waren To smale morsels so beþ taren To ich of hem vnneþe men mi?t A morsel of ous to hem di?t.’ ‘A sir’ quaþ þe douke Estas ‘Wiþ ous schal be Godes gras His grace is better in to afie Þan armour oþer compeinie And þai be spred wide here and tere And we ben al togider here, Ich hope þurth Ihesu Crist We schul hem driue so sonne doþ mist.’ ‘Certes’ quaþ Clarion þe king ‘Þero?ain am y noþing Ac alle hem to asaily Forþ to wende icham redi ?if ?e so reden, þis pouer men.’ ‘?is’ quaþ þai euerichon ‘Sir par seynt charite Rewe on ous and haue pite We han leuer sterue ari?t Wiþ manschip and in fi?t Þan sen kin and wiif and child And ous forbren in fer wilde’— Þe king for pite wepe apli?t And seyd ‘Certes ?e han ri?t.’ Þo schosen þai so Dieu me saut A noble kni?t lord of Nohaut, And þe lord of þe toun sori Brandris a kni?t hardi, And Brehus saun pite also A feller kni?t mi?t non go, Þese bileft þer ri?tes Wiþ a þousand orped kni?tes Þe cuntre to loke and þe paþe Fram Sarrain þat wald hem scaþe; Þe lord of Paerne so ich finde Þer toke seuen þousinde, Into þe forest of Rokingham Wiþ hem alle forþ he nam; Þe douke Eustas and Clarion þe king Bi anoþer way went wiþouten lesing And helden hem a litel bi hest Vnder þe selue forest. In May is miri time swiþe Foules in wode hem make bliþe In euerich lond arist song— Ihesus Crist be ous among. In þe forest of Rokingham Hidden hem our Cristen man, Þer was a launde of noblay Where come togider seuen way Þai hem hidden a litel þerbi Forto aspien sikerli Þe route of þe Sarra?ins and þe pray Þat mi?ten comen of selcouþe cuntray Forto skecken on hem on hest When þai sei?e time best. Also þai were þere soiourninge Abouten vndren com gret cartinge Bi ich of þis seuen way Ful of ich maner pray Of venisoun and flesche and brede Of broun ale and win white and red Of baudekines and purpel pelle Of gold and siluer and cendel, Sum þai brou?t fram her lond And robbed sum in Inglond; Þis carting lest mile-ways Forsoþe hou fele no can y say, Fif þousand ?ede þe cartes to loke So we finden on þe boke To hem dassed þe lord of Paerne Wiþ seuen þousand also ?erne And þe carters euerichon Of liif-days þai brou?ten anon And her lokers anon ri?tes Fif þousand heþen kni?tes Þai metten wiþ swerd and kniif Þat non ascaped wiþ þe liif, And nomen swiftlich al þat pray And ladde it þennes to mile-way Into þe toun of Arundel And þer it token to ?eme wel And went hem o?ain anon To þe king Clarion. Ri?t also þai comen ware Fiftene þousande þer comen fare Sarra?ins yarmed wel On gode hors in yren and stiel, Our kni?tes were so y finde Gode kni?tes tventi þousinde, Þai smiten þe hors and lete þe rain And metten þe paiens wiþ gret main. King Clarion mett king Guifas (Sexten fet o lengþe he was) He hit him wiþ þe speres ord Þurth and þurth scheldes bord Þurthout hauberk and aketoun And bar him of his hors adoun His schaft tobrast, þe geaunt fel His nek-bon he brac þertil. Þe douke Estas of Arundel Mett a king sir Mirabel, Þe paien on him brac his schaft And hitt him on þe side l[e]ft, Þe douke him hit in þe brest And wiþ his dint hard þrest An ellen long þurth þe bouke, Þe soule went to þe Pouke. Þe gode kni?tes þat wiþ hem ware Þe oþer to þe grounde bare Wiþ dint of spere and of swerde-egge Þe paiens þai made to deþ legge, Bitven vndren and none so y finde Of hem þai slowen ten þousinde Þer lay mani paien þurth-þrest Heued of-smiten and fot and fist, Bi þe blod of hors and man A mile men mi?t haue ygan. Of hem fiue þousand þat wald scape Toward king Oriens gan rape, Our Cristen hem suwed at þe rigge And spared nou?t on to l[e]gge What king Oriens þai saye Wiþ folk wreien al þe cuntraye, O?ain þai wiþdrou? hem þo And conseil toke what to do Doun of her destrers þai li?ten Her stedes to rest her armes ri?ten And afterward made a renge Of hem alle þe launde alenge For þai nold for no gode Þat paiens binomen hem þat wode. Þo asked Oriens an hast His folk wereof þai weren agast, ‘Sir’ þai seyd ‘heretofore Beþ tventi þousand oþer more Cristen men þat ?our kni?tes Han yslawe doun ri?tes And sodanliche þai com ous on Er we sei?e of hem on And no hadde we þe better be Hem of scaped nadde we.’ ‘A Mahoun’ seyd Oriens þo ‘Þou nart no god worþ a slo Þerfore þi folk þou dost no gode So for Cristen doþ her lord. Com forþ’ he seyd ‘wiþouten letting King Eliedus min owhen derling Nim wiþ þe fourti þousinde And sle bifore þat þou mi?t finde,’ ‘It schal be don’ he seyd ‘bi dan Dagon,’ Euerich lepe his stede opon And fond our men alle at a tasse Þat þe paiens no mi?t passe. Þer ich oþer sone mett And wiþ scharp launce grett Þer tumbled mani paien haþen, And mani Cristen—þat was scaþe Ac þo þat ware ded of our To heuen brou?t soule pure And þe slawen Sarra?ine Went into helle-pine. Þe Cristen fond þe heþen dere So þe lioun doþ þe bere, Euerich on oþer leyd [þer]wiþ So on þe yren doþ þe smiþ, Þer ouerþrewe in litel stounde Mani orped kni?t to grounde Sum ycleued to þe brest Sum of-smiten arm and fest, Sum hors smiten and sum astray; Þis fi?t last fram þe midday What it were euen almast, Þo com Oriens driueand on hast Wiþ an hundred þousand and mo And þou?t our men alle slo Ac on hem þo com þe ni?t Our to wode deden hem þo ri?t, Þurth Godes help and his pite And so ascaped to her cite. Bitven king Clarion and douke Estas Þer was parted alle þe purchas Þat þai hadde ywonne þat day, Long hem was þe bett par fay. Of Cristen were slawe y finde Þe mountaunce of four þousinde Ac þere were slawe of þe heþen men Wele mo þan þousendes ten; Wroþ was Oriens þe king Of þis slei?t and þis scapeing, Þai telt her pauiloun þer þat ni?t, Amorwe were sou?t anon ri?t In wode and doun and in fen After our Cristen men Ac þai no founde þerof non For nou?t þat euer couþe þai don. Oriens þo was so wroþ His owen liif was him loþ, For wretþe he cleped an amirail Napin þat hete saun fail, Wiþ fiften þousand wreyen kni?tes And bad him þe cuntre sle doun ri?tes And toke him ribaudes þre þousinde Þe cuntre to brenne bifore and hinde, Waines and cartes and somers also Fif hundred he dede after go Charged wiþ ale and win red Wiþ fische and flesche and corn and bred Wiþ cloþes and wiþ armerie, Sum þai hadde of robberie And sum brou?t fram her cuntray; ?ete dede Oriens more y say, Wiþ ten þousinde Rapas a king He dede loke þat carting, He sett king Eliteus at her hele Wiþ xv þousand in on eschele, Himself Oriens com bihinde Wiþ Sarra?ins xx þousinde. Þis ribaus þus þousandes þre Ofersett þe cuntre And brent and slou? man and wiif O child no leten þai oliif Þe cri and sorwe y say Men herd fele mile-way; Þe douke Estas ysei?e al þis Wo was him oliue ywis He [tok] kni?tes þousandes to And out of his cite dassed him þo Among þe ribaus anon he dast And sum þe heued of he laist, Þis þre þousand he slou? anon (Bot fourti þat hem fro were agon) Þurth þe mi?t and help of Crist Ar Napin ou?t þerof wist Into her cite þay wenten o?an Wiþouten letting of ani man. To Napin com a ribaud þo And seyd ‘Sir where bileuestow so? Þou no dost nou?t as þe wise For þurth þi targinge and þi faintise Alle our feren yslawe beþ And we vnneþe ascaped deþ.’ ‘Held þi pes’ quaþ þe douke Napin ‘Or þou art ded bi Apolin! A worde speke y þe more here Þou art dede and al þine fere’— For al þat is vnder Crist He nold Oriens it hadde wist. Forþ þai passeþ þis lond acost To Clarence wiþ alle her ost, King Bardogaban of gret mounde Wiþ tventi kinges þer he founde Þat bilay þat cite And slou? þe cuntre wiþouten pite, Oriens was welcome swiþe For wonderliche þai weren bliþe Of þe ei?tte and stouers Þat þai brou?t, þo pauteners. Þere þai bileft wiþ þat king Lete we hem now at þis segeing And schewe werres and wo In þis lond þat weren þo— Who so wille ?iue lest Mai now here noble gest. Mirie it is in somers tide Foules sing in forest wide Swaines gin on iustinge ride Maidens tiffen hem in pride. Los sprong of Wawaines dede Of his breþer and of his ferrede. Vriens þat was of Schorham king Of whom y made bifore scheweing Hadde spoused Hermesent Blasine suster and Belisent; Þai hadde a ?ong man hem bitven, Michel Ywain a noble stren, He was ycleped michel Ywain For he hadde a broþer-kni?t, certein, Bast Ywain he was yhote For he was bi?eten o bast God it wot; Vriens bi anoþer quen ?ete had bi?eten a gentil stren Þat was hoten Morganor A gode kni?t bi Godes or, He had made him in al air To þe lond þat of h[i]m com veir, Þe lond þat com of Hermesente Was Ywains þurth ri?t decente. To Hermisent com child Ywain And seyd ‘Dame of child Wawain Þat is mi nevou spekeþ al þis lond Allas ma dame it is me schond Þat y no com in non werre Whe[r] y come to conquerre.’ Þo seyd Hermesent him to proue ‘Whider wostow Ywain for mi loue?’ ‘Dame to seche min em Arthour Of him to afong þe anour Of wi?tschippe and cheualrie And leren manschippe and curteisie.’ ‘What?’ sche seyd ‘for wiche bi?ete Wostow oþer seruise and þi faders lete?’ ‘Dame’ he seyd ‘þine owen land Mi fader haþ laten me on hand, His owen lond he ?aue anoþer, Morganor mine halue-broþer, And þei he schuld me al bireue ?ete ichil bi ?our leue Wende and serue mi nem Arthour It schal falle to our honour.’ ‘Sone’ sche seyd ‘icham wele paid Of þat þou hast to me seyd Þi nem is Arthour verrament Serue him wiþ hert gent And fond forto make acord Bitven Arthour and þi lord.’ Þer sche him puruaid anon ri?tes To felawes an hundred kni?tes And þre hundred ?ong men Þat wiþ him kni?tes schuld ben And fond hem armour and stede Boþe soure and gode at nede, In þe name of Heuen-king Sche him ?af hir blisseing And lete him forþ wende in þe name of Crist Þat his fader þerof nist, Ywain bastard wiþ him went And four hundred of feren gent. Now com þai fram Schorham Al bi þe forest of Bedingham Toward Arundel in Cornwaile Ac þider þai no mi?t saun faile Bot þai wolden passen þurthoute iiii m Sarra?ins wiþ rowe snoute Þo com þer forþ, wiþ mi?ti hond Wiþ king Soriendos to stroi þis lond, He de[de] ribaudes ten þousinde Bren þat þai mi?tten finde, So he dede michel rewþe. Þis was on Yders lond in trewþe Ac to Gawaynet ful of priis Sone men telden al þis; Þo he and his gentil feren Al þis reuþe deden heren He toke wiþ him þritti þousinde Gode felawes so y finde Þat wenten alle wiþ Wawain For his largesse and his main, Out of Londen þe way þai nome Al what þai to Cardoil come, Fro Cardoil þai wenten souþe-west To Bedingham al þurth þe forest Where welcominge þai hadde onest Wiþ gret ioie and gret fest. Þis fi?tinge vnder Cornwaile Was fer ?ete saun faile. Yder in whos lond it was And bifel to kepe þat pas Of his men herd þe pleinte Sum forbrent and sum fordreinte, For diol he topped of his hare And himself tobete and tare And acurssed oft þe time grim Þat Arthour was wroþ wiþ him. King Yder was sikerli A noble kni?t and an hardi Þat wiþ him ledde xiiii m kni?t Boþe hardi and eke wi?t ‘As armes!’ he gradde wiþ tonge And on gode stedes þai flonge. King Soriandes þat soudan was; To a king þat hi?t Bilas He hadde taken fiften þousinde Bifore þat went so y finde And passed along ouer a brigge, Þo þai ouer com ich ?ou sigge Þai rested hem a litel wi?t And þo forþ went anon ri?t; King Soriandes after cam Wiþ fourti þousand haþen man; To Morgalant his steward He bitoke þe after-ward And xxv m Sarra?ins Þat schuld him help wiþ mi?t fines— Ten mile-ways lest þis route Icham siker wiþouten doute And bitven euerich floc naþeles To mile oþer þre þer wes. Þis ich folk þat was bihinde Wiþ fiue and tventi þousinde King Yder and his ouertoke Opon a cauci bi a broke; Þai sei?e him come and wiþstette, Wiþ scharpe spere ich oþer gret, Our Cristen þurthout hem þrust And out of þe sadel mani lust Amirail and heþen kni?t Mani þrewe doun deueling ri?t And gnowen boþe gras and ston Þo þat deþ her hert chon, Sum lay wiþouten arme and þi And sum cleued into þe fi, Our men þer in litel stounde Ten þousand slou? to grounde; Þis sei?e þe steward Morgalant Hardi and strong and gret geant, XV kni?tes he slou? of our Al arawe and to and four And þo he mett wiþ Yder king Ac þat was bataile of þincheing For ich smot oþers scheld ato Helmes tokoruen and brini also. Þis herd Soriandes þe soudan, Of fourti þousand þe tventi he nam And sodanliche on our smot And alle hem slou? ner God it wot Ac king Yder fram þe deþe Scaped wiþ a fewe vnneþe Wiþ wepeing and wiþ gret wailing, Ac he no hadde ascaped bi Heuen-king ?if anoþer cuntek no hadde ybe Þat þe soudan dede ferst yse Wharfore he no durst him suwe for doute Ac went o?ain wiþ al his route. Now þe childer y spac of bifore Ywain þe hende and Ywain bastard ybore And Ates an orped kni?t Wiþ four [hundred] ?ong men wi?t Weren passed þe forest Toward Arundel souþe-west And wenden ben alle soure and siker, And þo metten wiþ a sori biker Wiþ Soriendes formward Þat Bilas ladde a kni?t hard, XV þousand o?ain four hunder Þis was a meteing of wonder. Four mile out of Arundel Allas þis ich meting fel Also þis bachelers hadden a bregge Ypassed forsoþe y sigge Þe children fle nou?t no mi?t For þe brigge y ?ou pli?t Her scheldes þai gropen and scharp spere Ich a Sarra?in gan doun bere Swerdes þai drou? and ?euen dintes And paid paiens deþ-rentes, Þis ?ong men of whom y say Tocoruen in þre mile-ways Fiue þousinde Sarrains to grounde And ?ete were hemself hole and sounde. At þe hindeward king Yder Fau?t al at ones, and þis children her; Soriandes þat wele yherd And lete Yder and o?ain ferd Forto taken quiclike Þe children ded oþer quic. Ac ri?t now a litel knape To Bedingram com wiþ rape And toke a letter to Wawain On his nevou half hende Ywain (Ac Ywain wist nou?t þerof), Wawain hem toke þe knaue of Þe letters he red anon And grad ‘As armes euerichon! Armeþ ?ou al wiþ main For mi nevou hende Ywain Haueþ nede and bot we hei?e He is ded and his compeinie, Ded me were leuer bi Ihesus Þan he starf for faut of ous.’ Agreuein and Gaher[i]et Gveheres and Sagremoret Armed hem wiþ hardi cher And ich lepe on his destrer Swerd þai tok and launce and scheld And forþ priked on þe feld, Þai toke wiþ hem xx þousinde (Þe oþer þai leten hem bihinde) A-sex þai schift her compainie, Agreuein schuld þe first gie Þat was of noble þre þousinde, Gveheres also y finde Þre þousand bodis gied also Non better no mi?ten go, Þe þridde ferd ledde Gaheriet And þe ferþ Sagremoret Þe fift ladde Galathin And eueriche þre þousand wiþ him, Wawain ladde þe sext bihinde And hadde wiþ him ei?te þousinde. Þe knaue tau?t her way sikerliche Þa[i] riden wel sarreliche Þair gilt pensel wiþ þe winde Mirie ratled of cendel ynde Þe steden so noble and so wi?t Lopen and nei?ed wiþ þe kni?t. Þese beþ also fast cominge, Þe children þerwhiles were fi?ting O?ain ten þousand, for first fiue Þa[i] had wi?tliche brou?t o liue, Þai defended hem so wel Wiþ scharp swerd of gode stiel Þat þe four hundred hadde driuen o?an Þo ten þousand of heþen man. King Soriandes herd al þis And sexten þousand he sant of priis Biforn him hem to nim And after com þat wiþþerwin Wiþ xx þousind almast Forto taken hem on hast, Þis forseyd xvi þousinde Our folk comen bihinde And passed þe brigge Drian And smiten on our ?ong man And mani þerof þrewe to grounde And ?auen hem bitter and hard wounde, Þe ten þousand at þe oþer half also Deden hem swiþe miche wo. At on half and at oþer so y finde Were sex and tventi þousinde And wiþ a fewe children fou?t, Ac Ihesu Crist on hem þou?t For he ?aue hem strengþe and mi?t O?ain þo deuelen forto fi?t, When ani were falle adoun Þe oþer hem lift to arsoun Euerich oþer wiþ scheld biclept And fro oþer dentes kept And mani of þo heþen houndes Þai koruen doun into þe grounde— Ac al þai were so forfou?ten Of her liif þat þai no rou?ten And ?elden hem þai hadden ment. ‘Nay’ quaþ Ywayns ‘verrament Whiles our ani liueþ in feld Our þonkes nil we ous ?eld, Ac do we now bi mi red Prike we at onnes into þe mede And ?if we may owhar abreke Fle we hem wiþ gret reke.’ Al at ones her main þai kedde And large roume about hem redde Into þe mede þai smiten wiþ rape ?if þai mi?t ouer þe water scape— Þe water was swiþe depe Þe brink hei?e þe strem stepe, Þai loked ouer into þe londes And seye come king Soriandes, Fele mile-wais wiþouten doute Lest þe tail of his route. Ates þe wi?t þo seyd ‘Allas We mot ous ?eld in þis cas For we no mow nowhar oway So ful of deuelen in þis cuntray,’ Al þai were in gret desmay; Þo loked Ywain and saye Fram Bedingham on her side Baners and pople com ride, To his felawes he seyd on hast ‘Beþ now bliþe and nou?t agast Y se ?ond com gret socour For þai han þe signe of our Saueour Wherþurth’ he seyd ‘ich vnderstonde It is socour of þis lond.’ ‘Yherd be Crist!’ quaþ lasse Ywain ‘Her is conseil certain ?if we here leueþ in a þrome We worþ nomen ar þai come Ac þei we han pople lite Þurthout hem we mot smite And slen al þat mowe we, Þurthout hem and swiþe fle Fleand euer wereand ous Til help ous haue sent Ihesus.’ Bi [his] rede þai deden ?erne Her stedes þai gun terne On þe sexten m þai com flinge So hail doþ on þe singel, In þat coming God it wot Þai slou? þre hundred fot hot And wiþ gode hert and main fin Þai þurth perced þo Sarra?in, Ac Bilas wiþ his ten þousinde Hem oftoke anon bihinde And metten hem in a mede Wiþ an hundred of her ferrede And ?auen hem wel bitter wounde For þai hem wold haue nomen and bounde, Ac þai vp stirt and wered hem siker Wiþ swerd þai maden dedeli biker. Agreuein wiþ þis bikering Wiþ þre þousand com on hem flinge Þat wiþ spere þo ten þousinde Beren o?ain so y finde Þe schote of an alblast, Þer was mani þurthout dast Heued of koruen smiten of arm Bodi cleued into þe barm, On boþe halue was swiche a cri Men mi?t it here into þe sky. Þis sei?en þe sexten þousinde And comen swiþe on our winde And wiþ mi?t o?ain hem bar To þe stede þer þai wer ar, Þer was mani wombe þurth schoue And mani heued cleued aboue, Þat ich time Agreuein In slei?t kid so michel main Þat his feren wondred euerichon And token ensaumple wele to don For he seyd þei he dede schuld ben Of þe stede he nold flen Ac wiþ swerd he wald delite On þe paiens to don it bite. Ywain þan and alle his floc On steden sat so stef so stok And dasched hem amid þe pres So lyoun doþ on dere in gres And cleued boþe man and hors Of þe foule heþen cors, Ich of hem so wi?tliche fau?t Þat tong no may it telle nau?t, Ac Sarra?ins were bi mi panne Euer fourti o?aines anne Wherfore our litel folk kene No mi?t amonges hem ben ysen— Þis was in time of May Ri?t aboute midmorwe-day. Þo com Gueheres Wawaines broþer Wiþ þre þousand f[ol]k oþer And smiten on þis heþen hounde Þat euerich of hem fel to grounde And þe oþer rekeuerd o?ain wiþ main Whider first hem brou?t Agreuein, Þer was fi?ting þer was toile And vnder hors kni?tes defoile; Þo þonked Ywain þe wi?t Of þat socour God almi?t And desired to wite who it were Þat him dede swiche socour þere, Þo seyd Ates ‘Sir Ywain Smite þi stede wiþ mi?t and main And of þi greuaunce þe awreke Þat oþer it sen and þerof speke, Bi her pruesse þou schalt hem knawe And bi þine be her felawe Y þe rede now lay on fast Our fomen forto agast.’ Þer Ywain and eke his broþer, Ates and mani gentil oþer Tokoruen þis Sarra?ins Wiþ gret mi?t and wille fins Y wene þat Ywain and his broþer Þer slou? an hundred and anoþer So þat Gveheres and Agreuein Hadde gret wonder of her main. As Ates com rideinde hem bitven He asked h[i]m who it mi?t ben, ‘Certes’ quaþ Ates ‘of ?our ken, Þe kinges sones Vrien Ywain þe hende and Ywain bastard Þat þus com hiderward To ben kni?tes of ?our em Arthour And seruen him wiþ gret honour, Al þat han white on ri?te armes And red on left half on her armes Beþ erls and barouns sones Þat ben wiþ him hider come Þat metten here þis deuelen felle Þat ben ysprongen out of helle Þat hadde hem slain wiþ deshonour No hadde ben ?our socour.’ ‘Yherd be Crist’ þe children quaþe ‘Þat we to hem com þus raþe,’ To hem þai smiten þe stedes swiþe And welcomed hem wiþ chere bliþe, Þo her ich oþer knewe Ich ouer oþer armes þrewe Gret ioie wiþouten les Þai made amidward þat pres And made couenaunt in al þat fi?t Togider þai wald riden apli?t. As þai þus togider spake Fresche paiens on hem com rake XV þousinde, þat hadden born o?an Par fors into Bedingham, Wiþ þre þousand ne hadde bet On hem smiten Gaheriet Wawaines broþer sikerliche O?ain hem held sarreliche, Þer was broken mani spere Wiþ deþes dint and liues lere And mani paien to deþ ysmite Wiþ swerdes of stiel þat wele bite. Margalaunt þe steward and king Pinogres To þe brigge were comen wiþ gret pres Of Sarra?ins xx þousinde And wele mo also y finde Al þai sei?en þis ich biker, At þat half þe brigge hem þou?t siker On þat ich fair roume To aloge her pauiloun To kepe wele her charrois Her astore and her harnois And to help at tide and time At þe oþer half her cursed lin, Þe brigge þat was hem bitven Þai þou?t schuld her socour ben. Soriondes her hei?e king Com sone after wiþouten lesing Wiþ so mani þousand Sarra?ins Þat no man þerof couþe þe fins And loged on þat riuer Fram Morgalant nou?t wel fer Of bataile to sen þe fin Of Cristen and of Sarra?in Þer at þe oþer half þe brigge Wiþ scharppe swerd gun on legge Wiþ fauchouns axes and battes Ich ?aue oþer sori flappes, Of Sarra?in þer fou?ten ten and ten O?ain on of our men Wherþurth þe feld o?ain þai bare Mani of our children þare. In þis toil, wiþ þre þousand skete Sagremor hem com mete Mest what euerich wiþ his spere A paien gan to grounde bere, And in þis ich coming Þer were slawe four heþen king In þe feld of our bachelers, Were brou?t on her destre[r]s; Þe paiens were to fel and kene Þe slei?t of hem nas nou?t sen And eke þer ourne stremes of blod Also it were a wel gret flod. Now wiþouten more dueling Galathin com swiþe flinge Wiþ þre þousand wi?tling And smot o?ain þat heþen king, Ich of hem wiþ stef launce A Sarra?in smot wiþouten balaunce And wiþ her feren brou?ten o?ain Al her f[om]en to þe brigge Drein In þe water hem driuen so y finde, Of þe heþen and slou? seuen þousinde, Ac al our childer toforn and þo Hadde hem contened so Þat of m x and sextene No hadde þai leued bot þrittene And of our so y finde Nas nou?t slain a þousinde. Now hadde al þo þeues heþen Ben tofrust doun ri?t to maþen ?if Morgalent and Pinogres [N]adden brou?t ouer her pres XX þousand o?ain our, Of our wer þousandes ten and four And certes nou?t an hundred mo And þai were þre and þritti þousand and mo; Þer was batail of mende Hou our wi?tlinges so hende On þe heþen wiþ swordes losten And mani tocleued and tofrusten, Ac Morgalant and his ferrede Were strong and fers to þe dede And hadde don our harm wel gret ?if Wawain no hadde don þe bet Þat wiþ ei?te þousand and swerdes egge Brou?t hem to þentre of þe brigge And mani þousand ouerþrewe saun fail Into þe water top and tail Þat þai adreint wiþouten les. Wawain smot into þat pres It was sumdel after none Wawain strengþe duble gan His ax in his hond he lift Durarls heued of he smit, King Malgar on þe heued he gert Þat þe dent stode at þe hert, Segor on þe heued he smot Þe ax into þe sadel bot, King Malan also he hit And wiþ his ax þe heued of slit, A-left he smot and a-ri?t Non his dent asit mi?t Stel and yren his ax þurth carf Wherþurth mani heþen starf; He met þat geaunt Pinogres Amidward al his pres Þat cleued Wawaines scheld Þat it flei?e in þe feld, Wawain him ?aue a dent of howe And cleued him to þe sadel-bowe— Y no mi?t it nou?t fulrede Þe pruaunce of Wawaines dede. After him hende Ywain Best y wene kidde his main For king Sesox he cleue ato And Baldas an amiral also, Minardes heued of he smot And Bilaces also God it wot And Morgalant þe steward Dedliche wounde he ?af him hard, And mo kni?tes þan y can telle Wawain and he sent to helle For y neuen now saun faile Bot kinges doukes and amiraile— ?ete no wist nou?t Wawain Þat it was his felawe Ywain, He hadde wonder of his pruesse Þat so leyd doun hard and nesse. After hem Galathin Kidde in dede mi?t afin Wiþ swerd he hit Farasan A geaunt and an hoge man Þat ere and cheke and scholder also Wiþ his swerd he carf atvo, King Creon he cleued þurth And king Beas doun in a furth, Darian and king Fulgin Boþe he cleue to þe chin. No child no mi?t do þer bet Þan dede also Gaheriet, Of þe king Briollo Þe midel he smot ato Pinnas and ek Donadord He biheueded wiþ his sword Pamadas he cleued doun ri?t. Sagremor þer schewed his mi?t For he biheueded Linodas Of fourtene fet þat was, Fauel he cleued to þe brest And Guindard he made heuedles prest. Gueheres dede also wel, Of Guos he carf þe hatrel Goweir he cleued to þe ribbe Þat he no mi?t no lenger libbe. Agreuein dede also Þre kinges he slou? and mani mo, Ates and lesse Ywain and her route To grounde laiden wiþouten doute Whom so þai hitten wiþ ful dent Keuerd he neuer verrament, Ac verrament o?ain Wawain No man no mi?t kiþe main For he carf man and stiel and ire So flesche-hewer doþ flesches lire. Ni?t com hem on, þai mi?t nou?t sen, Ich to his kiþ gan to ten; Þo Gawainet knewe Ywain Þer was ioie and blis certain He and al her compeinie To Bedingham went on hei?e And þer token aise and rest Wiþ gamen and gle and solas mest. Soriandes sei?e of his ferred Of four score m þe fourti ded, His hert was sore his cher murne Lenger nold he þer soiourne He trussed his armes anon ri?t And went oway al bi ni?t To her hei?e ost to Wandlesbiri Þer þai made hem ioie and miri For store and tresor þat þai brou?t; Wawain amorn hem sou?t And fond he was ascaped oway Þat him oþou?t par ma fay, Þat hie þer founden þai ladde hem wiþ And left þer stille in pais and griþ Mani day at Bedinham— Now listneþ what after bicam. Now seiþ þis romaunce hou Wawain Of þis letters asked Ywain, Ywain seyd he wist of non Whereþurth þai wonderd euerichon. Þo herd þai telle of Sarra?ins Deden wo and michel pins Þe ?ong men of Arundel, Wawain þerof hadde diol Ten þousand þe best he toke (Þe oþer he tok þe toun to loke) And went hem Arundel toward. In þis time fel chaunce hard For Kay Destran and Kehedin Tvo gentil swaines of wi?t lin Erles sones of Strangore, Of þe marche come hem bifore Wiþ seuen and tventi sweines of gentil stren Comen alle kni?tes forto ben And to serue king Arthour ?if þai mi?t wiþ gret honour, Þese no hadde nou?t are ysaye Hou Arundel was bilay Of king Harans and ek Daril, Bramagnes sones þe etenild, Wiþ so mani heþen þousinde Þat þe noumbre y no can finde. Þese squiers on hem come, And þe paiens also sone So þai hem sei?e on hem þai last, Þe squiers were armed and on hem dast And in þe first of þat seylinge Þai slowen michel heþen genge Ac heþen mani þousand þo On our flongen and dede hem wo And biclept hem al about Forto nim þat litel rout. ?ong men of Arundel Sei?en it out of þe castel Wi?t ?onglinges þre hundred ich vnderstonde Þe first was Ywain wiþ þe white hond Þe oþer Ywain of Lyonel Þe þridde Ywain Desclauis le bel And Ywain of Strangore of hei?e parage Þe v was Dedinet þe saueage Alle þai were wi?t and hende And nei?e of Wawaines kende, Þese wiþ þre hundred com þere And on þe paiens smiten wiþ gode chere Ich dede his launce go Þurthout a paien oþer to And redden hem wiþ mi?t fin Til what þai come to Kehedin, Togider þai cleued in þat werre So wiþ oþer doþ þe burre And leyden þer Sarra?ins doun ri?t Boþe a left half and a ri?t. Þe paiens an horn gun blowe And hem come socour in litel þrawe XX þousand þat smite on our And bar hem doun bi þre and four And hadde hem slawe and do miche wo No hadde Wawain vp comen þo Wiþ x þousand þat doun stett Alle þat þai wiþ launce mett And after her swerdes drowe And xv þousand heþen slowe And holpen so þo oþer squiers Þat þai were brou?t on destrers; Þe oþer paiens wiþdrou? hem þo Sarra?ins to feche hem mo, Þerwhiles Wawain knewe þis Ywains Alle four and þe oþer swaines, Þer was ioie bi Godes ore Y wene þer mi?t be no more Þan was þer of þat socouringe. Þerwhiles com an eld kni?t flinge And seyd to Wawain conseil ?if he and his feren wald ben hayl Þai schuld swiþe to Arundel te And þan he schuld more yse, Bi his conseil þai deden anon And went into Arundel ichon Alle þe gates þai schetten fast And lete falle portcolice on hast, On walles þai stei?en hei?e And sei?en of heþen ful þe cuntreie— King Harans wiþ sexti þousinde And Daril wiþ fourti him bihinde, XII hundred cartes after come Wiþ gode and store þat was binome In þe cuntre men and wiues Al sori in her liues, After hem come xx þousinde Of fel robours so y finde Þat so hadde robed and brent þe cuntre Þat þeraboute four iurne No schuld man finde man no childe Bot wildernesse and desert wilde. Wawain and his felawes Þer soiour[n]d seuen dawes, Þer lete we hem soiurne And speke we of chaunces hard and murne. King Harans and his harnoys Went toward þe lond of Leoneis And brent into þe grounde Al þat þai biforn hem founde Man and child þai brent þo And dede hem al michel wo; Sum ascaped wiþ gret paine Into þe cite of Dorkeine And reweliche gun [grade] o king Lot For þis lere God it wot, Lot tok xx þousand kni?tes And went him out anon ri?tes. A ferd of xxx þousinde He smot on also y finde, V þousinde in his cominge He slou? wiþ speres meteinge Egreliche her swerdes drowe And ix þousinde þerto slouwe Wiþ so noble swerdes dent Þat hem astint verament And hadde hem alle sone yslawe ?if Harans (þat þe Deuel todrawe!) Wiþ lx þousand [nadde] þo Com on our to michel wo Þat our biclept and wiþ fou?t And slowen our gentil men and du?st, Þat Lot vnneþe wiþ þre þousinde Scaped at euen so y finde Into þe cite of Dorkeine Sore ywounded wiþ michel peine. Þe king Lot sei?e þis lere Himselue he gan here tere And bad þe time mesauenture Þat he cunteked wiþ king Arthour, And his kni?tes þat leued were And leuedis and children maden care For her faders lordes and frende Were so slawe wiþ helle-fende; Harans biseged and dede his peine Þe cite to winne of Dorkeine. Lot þou?t to saue Belisent Arthours suster his quen gent And Wawains moder saun fail, His kni?tes he asked conseil Conseil he tok and went bi ni?t Toward Glocedoine ful ri?t His strong castel, to don in his wiif For chaunce þat mi?t be oþer striif Wiþ Modred his sone beld Þat nas ?ete bot to ?er eld, V hundred kni?tes on gode stede Wiþ him he tok for al nede And went toward his castel swiþe— He was þerof seþþen vnbliþe.
