In þis time child Wawain Wiþ mani feren and eke Ywain On Arundels wal þai gun lene, A kni?t com arnand wiþ gret rene Yarmed in armes alle Þat to Wawain þus gan calle ‘Wawain’ he seyd ‘Crist þe se And alle þine feren fre! Durst ?e gon wiþ me siker Y wold ?ou schewe a selcouþe biker Whar ?e schul win wining ?e nold it ?eue for noþing.’ ‘Þan schaltow’ quaþ Wawain ‘swere Þou no schalt ous wiþ tresoun dere,’ ‘Bleþeliche’ he seyd and swore anon He no schuld hem qued no traisoun don. Wawain him armed swiþe And tok wiþ him x þousand biliue Þis kni?t sei?e hem com and dassed forþ And hye him after swiþe, norþ, So þai wenten þai metten a kni?t Arnand wiþ al his mi?t Wawain nam to þis kni?t hede Þat he ladde wiþ him Modrede He rode him to and asked him whi He ladde his broþer so suiftli, ‘Wawain’ he seyd ‘par ma fay Al þis ni?t and al þis day Þi lord haþ fou?t o?ain king Taurus Þre þousand o?ain fiue hundred of ous, Þi lord is wounded his men be dede Modred þi broþer y tok for drede And wiþ him þus oway drawe Þat he no ware of hem yslawe.’ ‘Allas’ quaþ Wawain ‘allas allas Þat ich euer born was! Who schuld euer of me ?elp Now sterue mi frende wiþouten help? Frende’ quaþ Wawain ‘þou here abide In on busse þou þe hide What þou se al þe fulle Wiche socour don we schulle.’ Wawain wiþ his folk forþ drof Hastiliche vnder a grof, Þo he herd a reuly cri A wiman euer cri ‘Merci!’ He dasched forþ biforn hem alle And sei?e a leuedi þries doun falle Fram Taurus stede to þe grounde, Þat heþen king þat vnwrast hounde Þat feloun rage in his wodenesse Pli?t hir vp bi þe tresse And sche gred ‘Seint Marie Help me leuedi Cristes drurie!’ And he went vp anon his fest And buffeyt hir vnder þe lest So oft so sche crid ‘Marie!’ Sche was buffeit of him þrie, Sche fel doun of his hors rigge And he gan anon his hondes legge On hir tresse, and forþ hir drou? Þe leuedi vpri?t stode aswou? He laid on wiþ schourge and bad hir go And sche no mi?t a fot for wo No for hir cloþes long, Bi hir tresse he gan hir hong Sche wiþbraid and fel vpri?t, Taurus ali?t anon ri?t And knett hir to his hors tail Bi her tresse saun fayl So he drou? hir him bihinde Euer ‘Mari help!’ criinde, What for sorwe and eke for paine Sche les winde and ek alaine Hir ei?en turned hir voice wiþsat At point of dede was hir stat. Þo seyd Wawain to þat kni?t Þat hadde him brou?t þider ful ri?t ‘Knawestow ou?t þat leuedi Þat þoleþ al þat vilanie?’ ‘Wawain’ he seyd ‘verrament Hir name is hote Belisent Þou ou?test amende hir stat For þou souke of hir tat.’ Wawain was oft wele and wo Ac neuer wers þan him was þo Nei?e aswon he sat vpri?t Þo nist he war bicome þat kni?t, He mi?t long loke after him He was oway—it was Merlin. Wawain wiþ spors his stede smot And he forþ stirt God it wot He grad aloude to king Taurus ‘Abide þou þef malicious! Biche-sone þou drawest amis Þou schalt abigge it ywis!’ An heþen swain sone doun stett Þe leuedis tresse sone vnknett. King Taurus was xiiii fet long An vnrede geaunt and a strong He sei?e to him com Wawain He toke a launce wiþ gret [m]ain And smot þe stede þat he bistrode, Aiþer to oþer wiþ wretþe rode, Taurus hit Wawain arst Þat his launce al tobrast, Wawain him hit wiþ main and schof Þe launce þurth þe scheld drof Þurthout hauberk and hert-polk And ded him cast among his folk; Wawains breþer on and oþer Smiten euerich liþ fram oþer And v hundred heþen ichon No leten ascape neuer on. Wawain o?ain went so seyt þe bok And his moder in his armes tok And wiped hir mouþe ei?en and viis For hir he wepe ful sore ywis He kist hir mouþe and hir ei?e[n], And his breþer þat ysei?e[n] And com to him and gret diol made No mi?t hem noþing glade, And for loue of hem alle her fere Made wepeing and reuly chere; In al þis diol-makeing Belisent wiþouten lesing Acouerd and vndede her eyin, Þo her sones it yseyn Þai made ioie swiþe gret Hir ei?en þo sche vndede bet And þonked Ihesu our Saueour Of hir sones gentil socour. Þo teld sche Wawain and his feren So þat þai it mi?t yheren Hou Lot wiþ þre hundred kni?t Dede o?ain þre þousand fi?t And of þe þre þousand he lete oliue Certes bot hundredes fiue ‘Ac of mi lordes meine Certes no scaped oliue nou?t þre, Þo mi lord most chese Me forgon oþer his liif forlese Alon he fau?t a mile-way Wiþ þo v hundred y say What he hadde woundes ten and fiue, Vnneþe he ascaped wiþ þe liue Makand so reuli bere Þat it was pite forto here; Þe heþen me tok and totoiled Tobeten todrawe and defoiled— Now haue ich mi lord ylore And Modred mi sone þat wo me is fore,’ Aswon þo sche ouerþrewe. Wawain sone hir ablewe And seyd ‘Dame, Modred þi sone Y schal þe don anon come’ And him ofsent, þo sche him say Sche akeuered par ma fay And was yleyd in liter Almast liche an hors-bere And to Londen toke þe way Wiþ alle Taurus korray Sex hundred cartes bi Godes ore Al charged wiþ mete and store. Þo þai to Londen weren ycome Hendeliche þai were welcome Do deliuerd þe hei?e palays To sir Wawain þe curteys, Þerin he dede his leuedi And swore bi þe quen Marie Schuld he neuer sen his lord What Arthour and he were acord. Þo he teld al sir Do Of chaunce þat hem was comen to Hou he dede Sagremor socour Þurth an eld vauasour ‘And seþþen Ywain mi cosyn Þurth leters writen in Latin Þurth a page also ri?t, And mi moder þurth a kni?t, And y no couþe non of þo þre Neuer seþþen after yse.’ ‘O Wawain’ quaþ Do anon ‘Al þre it was on Merlin þe gode felawe ?ete sum day þou schalt him knawe’— Hereof þai hadde wonder and game. Lete we þis rest in Godes name And telle forþ in gode pays Hou Merlin doþ his maister Blays In boke writen saun faile Of Inglond þis meruaile And profecies and oþer þing Þat sum beþ passed and sum coming. Þo went he fram his maister Blais To Arthour to Carohaise And teld him and his conseil Of Inglond al þe meruail Hou Wawain dede and his ferrede And eueriche king in his þede, King Arthour and his ferrade Of þis tidinge were wel glade. Now seiþ our romaunce here Leodegan sent his messanger To Arthour Ban and ek Bohort Þai schuld com to his court Wiþ him won and soiourne, And seyd he was sori and murne Þat he no wist of her beinge For he vnderstode soþ þing Þat þai were of power more Þan he and hei?er ybore, Þat þai hadde wele yked Fram deþ when þai him hadde red, He sent hem to come bi kni?tes fiue So þe ?emers of his liue For al he wald don him saun fail In her rede and her conseyl. Wiþouten bileueing ani more Þai went to him, Merlin bifore; Þo þai comen into þe halle Þe king vp stode and his men alle And welcomed hem wiþ bliþeful chere, Þo spac Merlin so ?e may here ‘King wostow wite our being?’ ‘?a’ quaþ Leodegan ‘opon al þing.’ ‘To þis’ he seyd and schewed Arthour ‘We sechen a wiif of gret valour.’ ‘A seynt Marie’ quaþ Leodegan ‘And haue ich a douhter a fair wiman Fairer not y non veir Wise and hende and of mi lond air And ich ?ou sigge vterliche Þei in þis warld war non oþer swiche, Þei he no hadde doun no lowe On him y told hir wele bitowe So ful y knawe him of worþschipe Of nortour and of hendeschippe,’ He fet his douhter himselue alon (In þis world nas fairer non) And proferd hir to king Arthour And to ben his air wiþ gret honour And Arthour hir nome saun fail For Merlin him ?af swiche conseil. ‘Now’ quaþ Merlin to Leodegan ‘Wostow now wite to what man Þou hast y?ouen douhter þin?’ ‘?a þat were wil and ioie min.’ Þer he was of Arthour biknawe And of his feren al bi rawe And seyd he was her lord bi hirritage Þai most al don him vmage, Leodegan was þo wel bliþe And to Arthour dede omage swiþe And þe kni?tes of þe rounde table And al þat oþer folk saun fable, Þer treuþed Arthour Gwenore his quen Þe fairest leuedi þat mi?t ben. King Leodegan lete maken a fest Of alle þat come swiþe onest, Ich þat was of Cristen lay Fond þer fest of gret noblay Þe fest last seuen ni?t Of al deinte y sigge apli?t, And lenger it hadde ylast Bot her terme was comen almast Þat þai most smite batail O?ain þe Sarra?ins saun fail; Wide and side ner and fer Baroun kni?t and ek souder Sum bi fe sum for wining Were comen to Leodegan þe king, Were comen to his fi?t And soiournd a fewe ni?t. Mirie is Iune þat scheweþ flour Þe meden ben of swete odour Lilye and rose of fair colour Þe riuer cler wiþouten sour, Boþe kni?tes and vauasour Þis damisels loue par amour. On Mononday in þe Pentecost Leodegan and alle his ost Armed hem in aketouns Hauberkes plates and hauberiouns Boþe wiþ bacin and eke palet And helme on her heued yset, Stones precious and ?immes Gold and siluer þer were inne, Þai hadde aboue riche queintise Of beten gold, of mani asise After þat her armes bar (Mani was diuers to oþer þar), Mani riche sadel on hast Was on riche destrer cast. Þat ich day par amour Guenore armed king Arthour, At ich armour þe gest seit þisse Arthour þe maden gan kisse; Merlin bad Arthour þe king Þenche on þat ich kisseing When he com into bataile, ‘?is’ he seyd ‘Merlin saun faile.’ Þo bad king Leodegan Merlin ordeine al his man, ‘Bleþeliche’ he seyd and ches Arthour And Ban [and] Bohort of gret vigour And her feren wiþouten fable And kni?tes of þe rounde table And oþer kni?tes so y finde, In alle he nam seuen þousinde And made þe first compainie Himself he wald hem gye. Leodegans nevou Gogenar A noble kni?t and wise and war Merlin toke anoþer ferrede Of seuen þousand forto lede. Þe þridde ledde Elinadas A ?ong kni?t þat fin stalworþ was He was þe wise leuedis nevou Of þe forest saun? retour, Þe ferþe led a baroun hi?t Blias Þat was lord of Bliodas, Þe fift ledde Andalas A kni?t of meruailus los he was, Þe vi ledde Beliche þe blounde A kni?t he was of gret mounde, Þe vii ledde Yder of Norþlond Fel and hardi and strong in hond, Þe viii ledde Landon ful of vertu He was Cleoda[l]is nevou, Þe ix ledde Gremporemole Hardi kni?t and wi?t and fre No kni?t better on stede sat Ac he hadde a nose as a cat; Ich of þese ladde seuen þousinde; Leodegan so com bihinde Wiþ ten þousinde of þe best. Þo bad hem al Merlin lest ‘King’ he said ‘nou?t þe amay For king Rion schal wische þis day He hadde ?eue þe tounes fiue He war in his lond wiþ his liue. Fele hundred Sarra?ins He haþ wiþ him of biches lins We schul hem sle and noþing doute For it is al a curssed route, We han almast so y finde Four score þousinde And Cristes grace þat schal ous helpe To kerue doun ri?t þe heþen welpes; Þenke on ?our childer and wiues And ek on ?our owen liues And of ?our londes, wiþ vnri?t Þai þenke to winne wiþ strengþe and mi?t ?ou to slen and to exile, Leggeþ on þe traitours vile Spareþ nou?t ac sle doun ri?t ?ou schal help God almi?t. Þai han filled þe michel forest And walled hem bi norþ and west Þat þerforþ no man no may Comen hem to par ma fay And a souþe half walled certes Wiþ mani þousand waines and cartes, Ac on þat est half ich wot We schul comen opon hem God it wot And finde hem slepeand and sle doun ri?t For þai were al dronken toni?t.’ Þer he ches kni?tes ten And sent biforn her men Forto take and slen and binde Þe spies þat þai mi?ten finde, Þat so deden, and hem bifore Nomen herlotes ten score And so hem bistirden þat no tiding Spie no brou?t to þat heþen king. Merlin come bifore wiþouten þe toun And vnspa[n]d his dragoun Fer þat kest of þe mouþe vair So it li?ted in þe air, Arthour alder next him cam And Ban and Bohort þat gentil man And al þat oþer ferred Ordeind so ich ere sede, Of armes þat was gret schining Þe stedes maden gret naying; Þai wenten forþ also stilly So þai mi?ten wiþouten cri. Þo Merlin com nei?e king Rion Enchauntement he kest him on Þat mani of her pauiloun Opon her heuedes fel adoun, Merlin and his feren was y say Biforn al þe oþer to mile-way, In a Tiwesday in þe daweing He kest þis enchaunteing, Bitven a riuer and a grof He com hem on, þat þai nou?t schrof, And Merlin loude gan to cri ‘Help ous now þe quen Marie!’ Our folk on þe heþen lusten And vnder hors fet hem frusten And tohewen hem to deþ, and on gerten. Þe heþen þeues vp sterten Four c þousand and mani mo To king Rion ascaped þo And armed hem swiftlich vnder his tent, To slen al our was her entent Ac our slou? þousandes mani Ar of hem were armed ani, Ac þo þai hadde keuered armes Wiþ launces maces and gisarmes Bi þousandes mani a man Þe heþen smiten our o?an And gun on of þe grest bataile Þat euer was smiten saun faile. Passed was þe dayspringing Þe hote sonne was schininge Þo bigan kni?tes rideing Trumpes b[low]en tabours dassing Þer was fleinge and wiþstonding Tireing togging and ouerþroweinge, Of Sarra?ins in litel stounde Mani þousand was frust to grounde. Þat sei?e Rion þat vile hounde He cleped Salinas þat kni?t of mounde Whiche Salinas was his nevou A stalworþ man and ful of vertu He tok him an hundred þousand kni?tes And hete him wende anon ri?tes His folk forto socour And awreke his deshonour, Þis Salinas and his wiþ gret vigour Com o?ain king Arthour Wiþ his to and fourti of mounde And wiþ kni?tes of þe table rounde And wiþ oþer, in al y finde Þe mountaunce of seuen þousinde; Þo seyd Merlin to king Arthour ‘Þenke now of þi newe amour, For loue of þi last kissing Among þis heþen houndes fling.’ At þat word king Arthour Smot his stede of gret valour And hit a Sarra?in þurth þe scheld And his hauberk felefeld Þat þurth þe hert þat ysen cheld Pased and kest him in þe feld, King Ban bisei?e ri?t so anoþer And king Bohort þe þridde his broþer, Nei?e ichon of her felawe In þe entring brou?t a paien of dawe; Þer was mani stede yfeld Mani kni?t slawen vnder scheld Ich kni?t hewe on his per On schide so doþ þe carpenter, Þer dede so our kni?tes of los Þat mani paien þerof agros. Arthour was þat day biheld Hou manliche þat he paiens aqueld He hem tokarf he hem tohewe Mani wiþ ded his dintes knewe. King Ionap a paien kene (Lengþe he hadde o fet fiftene) He sei?e hou Arthour ded hem damage He tok a launce in gret rage And biforn him grop his scheld Arthour he þou?t his harm to ?eld; Arthour sei?e wher he cam A stef launce in hond he nam— He no sembled no more him o?an Þan doþ a child o?ain a man. Aiþer gan his stede dresse O?ain oþer in þat presse, Ionapes schaft bigan to glide Ri?t bi king Arthour left side Þurthout armes and þurthout schert And in þe side, nou?t sore, him hert, And Arthour smot him wiþ his launce Þurthout his scheld wiþouten balaunce And þurthout hauberk and aketoun And þurthout þe scholder fer aroum, Ionap was so proude and sterne No ?af he þerof nou?t a ferne, Wiþ þe brestes so þai metten Þat to þe grounde boþe þai stetten. Of Cristen [and] heþen þer was toiling Forto help þis to king Þer was mani swerd ydrawe Mani kni?t hirt and mani slawe, What wiþ wristling wat wiþ togging What wiþ smiteing and wiþ skirminge On boþe half so þai wrou?ten Her kinges on hors þai brou?ten; Þo Arthour and his fourti and to And [þe] kni?tes of þe rounde table also So korwen and hewen wiþ main hond Þat non armour mi?t hem astond And so slowen þat Salinas Flei?e and al þat wiþ him was. Among þe wele doinde of our men Was on wele fi?tand hete Nacien Perciuales cosyn þe fri On his moder half þat fair leuedi, In þis warld of more noblay Nas non bi Vter Pendragones day No forþ bi þe kinges day Arthour Nas þer non of more vigour. Haningnes his moder was (Iosepes suster a kni?t of gras) Whom Ebron hadde spouse A kni?t of dede vertuous Þat on hir ?at kni?tes seuentene Hardi and strong wi?t and kene In whom seþþen in mani fi?t Al Inglond so was ali?t, Þis was Colidoines cosyn þe rike Naciens sone of Betike Whiche Celidoine sei?e first saun fail Of þe holi graal þe meruail, ?ete þis Nacien þe curteis Was sibbe king Pelles of Listoneis And al his breþer God it wot And seþþen hadde Launcelot In his ward almest a ?er So þe romaunce seyt elleswher; Þis Naciens of whom y write Seþþen bicom ermite And lete kni?tschippe and al þing And bicome prest messe to sing, Virgine of his bodi he was Whom seþþen þe holi Godes gras Rauist into þe þridde heuen Where he herd angels steuen And sei?e Fader and Sone and Holi Gost In on substaunce in on acost, Þis ?af seþþen þe riche conseil To þe king Arthour saun fail Þo he was in gret periil To lese his londes and ben exil O?aines þe king Galahos Þe geauntes sone of gret los Þat ?af king Arthour bataileinge Wiþ þe power of þritti king. Þis Naciens and Adragenis þe broun Þe heþen kni?tes leyden adoun Tohewe hem and togert Y ?ou sigge forsoþe cert Þe gret strengþe of king Arthour Þes to folweden in alle þe stour So fer þat he no mi?t se no knowe Neuer on of her felawe, Bifor þes þre Merlin went And bar þe dragoun þat fer out sent; Þes þre deden michel wo Hors and man þai coruen ato Boþe a left half and a ri?t Þai felden kni?tes and slou? doun ri?t And forced hem wiþ mani dent hard What þai come to king Riones standard Þat four castels [vp] olifaunce Bar toforn king Riouns. Her feren þo misten hem And smiten after bi xii and ten Wiþ newe grounden fauchoun and sword Mani heued þai smiten ford Þai schouen wiþ schulder and smiten wiþ arm And deden þe paiens dedliche harm Ac þai no mi?t keuer to king Arthour Wiþ slei?t no wiþ vigour, Bot Ban and Bohort so seiþ þe bok Laiden doun al þat þai tok Sum into þe sadel þai smiten Her swerdes þai dede ful wele biten And so fou?ten and slowen par ma fay Þat þai redden and maden way Maugre þo paiens þurth fin vigour What þai com to king Arthour, And þo þai were togider fiue Þai binomen mani on her liue, An hundred haþen in litel fitt Þe fiue þurth koruen and heued of slit. In ich half was gret fi?ting Gret slei?t gret criing Socouring and wiþstonding, Of kni?tes barouns erls and kinge Lay mani heuedles on þe grounde On þe gras wiþ dedli wounde Sum lay wiþouten fet and armes Ato ygirt into þe þarmes. Among þis toil sei?e king Rion Our fiue so his men slon He was seuenten fet long And in þis warld no man so strong In his ri?t hond and in his left A mace he gan vp lift Þat no man no schuld bere No vnneþe fram þe grounde stere. In þis time king Fansaron so mot y liue Hadde on iuel dent y?eue, Bohort him gan after prike Curagus to ben awreke Fram his feren he folwed him almast Þe cast of an alblast And hit him þan a dint wel iuel Þat he fel on his hors adiuel, He wold his nek smiten eft And þe dint a litel gleft Þe stedes nek he smot atvo King Fansaron fel to grounde þo. Bohort him hadde slawe anon Ac opon hem com king Rion Wiþ þe power of xviii kinge On king Bohort loude gredinge Þe mace arered in his hond And ‘Fi? a putain wiþstonde! Þou schalt abigge þat þou þer come Lo here in mine hond þi dome!’ Bohort of þe gretnesse hadde meruail And of him was adred saun fail, Leuer he hadde þer ben yhent Þan fleand ynomen oþer yschent He set on him þe crouche verray And him vnder his scheld wray, Rion on þat scheld so smot Þat it tobrast God it wot, And king Bohort so smot o?an O þe helme þat hoge man Þat he sat astoned vpri?t And nist wheþer it was dai or ni?t. Þe hors he dast him forbi And com vp a chaunce sikerly Where king Aroans a geaunt fel Hadde felled Herui de Riuel And held him so bi þe code Þat mouþe and nose him ran a-blod, And hadde þer of his heued ysmite Nadde Adragenis to him stite Wiþ swerd o?ain fourti and mo; King Bohort com rideinde þo And ?aue Aroans wiþ þe swerd a flat Þat he þrewe of his hors aplat, Herui sei?e legge þe kinges cors Anon he lepe vp to his hors And smiten hem amid þe pres So grehound doþ out of les And so hewen and laiden on Þat non mi?t better don. Now is king [Leodegan] wiþ his folk hard Smiten on kinge Riones standard And doþ gret power ich ?ou telle Riones baner forto felle, Ac Rion com and his mace left And slou? a ri?t hal[f] and a left, Rion smot to king Bohors And wende todaschen al his cors And he failed of him and hit his stede Þe dent was gret and vnrede Þe hors chine he dassed ato, Bohort lepe afot þo And wiþ his swerd y ?ou pli?t Wered him anon ri?t Ac Rion was him about To nimen and slen wiþ michel rout And dede him tviis knely arawe And almast hadde him yslawe. Herui Riuel þis iknewe King Bohortes harm him gan rewe Þe stede he smot þat it quei?te Of a geaunt a launce he pli?t To king Rion he gan ride And smot him þurthout þe side, King Rion wiþsat þat dent And smot to Herui verrament So þat a qua[r]ter of his scheld He bar oway into þe feld, And eft wald so a deuel wi?t, Ac Herui þat was vigrous and li?t On þe scheld him hit a dint hard And cleued it to þe midward, And Rion smot and gan faile And Heruies hors slou? saun faile, Þo stode Herui bi Bohort Boþe in periil of mort O?aines fele score ypli?t And þai hem wered as noble kni?t. Þis sei?e Adregein þe broun ‘Now helpe’ he seyd ‘seyn Symoun!’ He rode to Rion and so him smot Þat he plat God it wot Aswon on his hors swere Mi?t he noiþer se no here; Þe heued he hadde him þer binome Nadde þe proude king ycome Rion nevou Solinas (Þat honged worþ bi þeues las!), Bihinde Adrageins com wiþ a spere And to þe grounde gan him bere And bitven þe schulders him hirt, Adragein anon vp stirt On fot and halp his compainoun So it were a wode lyoun And so hem wered wiþ steles egge Þat non no durst on hem hond legge, Ac þai hem þrewe wiþ spere and kniif And oþer armes to reuen her liif And wounded hem sore swiþe Þurthout þe armes mani siþe. So þai were ouerriden in a þrawe Þat nei?e þai hadde ben yslawe ?if Nacien no had ysein þis Þat þider smot his stede of pris, Þo þat in his way he met Doun ri?t of hors he hem stett Rion he smot on þe side ri?t And bar him of his hors vpri?t And rod him on and ouer þries; His hors was slain bitven his þies Gode and wi?t kni?tes of our Þo stode on fet four, So þai gun fi?t and lasse Þat þai made grete tasse Abouten hem þer þai stode And depe woden in þe blod And made swiche defense and slei?t Þat y no may telle it ari?t. Ac Rion þat wiþþerwinne Dede gret power hem to nime And hadde hem nomen wiþouten let No hadde Merlin riden þe bet To king Arthour and to king Ban And seyd ‘What do ?e man? King Bohort and Nacien Beþ ?ond biloke wiþ mani men And Herui and Agreuein ?ond þai ben on þe plein, Bot ?e hem soner socour Þai ben ded al four.’ ‘Allas allas!’ quaþ king Ban ‘Lade me þider ri?t onan For be mi broþer þer mislad Worþ y neuer þerafter glad.’ Merlin smot forþ, þai after dasse On aiþer half so grehounde of lasse And her feren after hem come Þat mani paien ?af her dome And s[e]nt hem wiþ scharp sword To þe Deuel her lord, And þo þai comen and sei?en hes Þai dasched forþ amid þe pres Euerich hit a paien þo Þat þai arisen neuer mo Kni?tes wi?t þai hem kedden And roume to þe four þai redden. Geauntes strong þer weren to Þe four þat deden michel wo Minap hete þat on veires Þat oþer was hoten Malgleires, King Ban ?af to king Minape On þe helme swiche a clappe Þat he him cleued to þe toþ, King Arthour smot after forsoþ So Malgleires hit on þe scheld Þat his heued flei?e in þe feld; Þes four sei?en her socour And lepen ouer wiþ gret vigour Gret hepes of hors and men Þat slain lay hem bitven, Hors wel gode chepe þai founde And anon in þe sadel wounde And conteined hem so wi?tliche cert So þai nere nou?t yhert. Þo at arst bigan þe bataile Þat last al day wiþouten faile Ich on oþer so leyd veir Þat it dined into þe air Also þicke þe aruwe schoten In sonnebem so doþ þe moten Gauelokes also þicke flowe So gnattes ichil avowe Þer was so michel dust riseing Þat sen þer nas sonne schineing; Þe trumpeing and þe tabouringe Dede togider þe kni?tes flinge, Þe kni?tes broken her speren On þre, þai smiten and toteren, Kni?tes and stedes þer laien aboute Þe heuedes of-smiten þe guttes out Heueden fet and armes þer Lay strewed eueriwher Vnder stede fet so þicke In crowes nest so doþ þe sticke, Sum storuen and sum gras gnowe Þe gode steden her guttes drowe Wiþ blodi sadels in þat pres. Of swiche bataile nas no ses To þe ni?t fram arnemorwe It was a bataile of gret sorwe, Þer was swiche cark and swiche defoil Þat al Leodeganes folk made recoil To Denebleise vnder þe wal, Bot Arthour and his folk al Þat helden hem in þe bataile Of armes þat dede wonder meruaile. So Leodegan sau[n] fail Houed vnder þe cites wal, Sadones seyd an hardi man To his em Leodegan ‘Listneþ me now mi lord þe king And ?e oþer lordinge What do we here, whi and warfore? ?if we fle þis lond is lore And wif and child and al our blisse Al is forlorn mid ywis Better is to sterue worþschipliche Þan long to liuen schandfulliche, ?if we be desirite Our cowardschippe we may it wite; O þing ou?t ous comfort wel Our newe lord ?ong naturel Þat so wi?tliche fi?tep for ous Helpe we him for Crist Ihesus, ?if he were hunist at þis asaut He mi?t wite it our defaut And bot we him help at þis nede We beþ forswore so Crist me rede, And ?ete sle þat folk Sarra?ine Is our soule medicine.’ Ri?t so king Leodegan Gan to crien hem opan, Þo seyd Goionar þe hende ‘“He naþ non heued þat nil it defende” Lete be sir þi precheing And o?ain þo houndes fling.’ Alle þai were at on asent And forþ dassed verrament, X m paiens of þos þai metten Þurthout hem bar, to grounde he stetten, Þo bigan bataile newe Ich on oþer wiþ swerd hewe Wiþ mace and ex and fauchoun Mani kni?t laide oþer adoun. Þerwhiles Merlin so y finde Dede his out wende to take þe winde Gert her steden and ek resten, What þe Sarra?ins o?ain þresten Our Cristen par fors o?an, Þo mounted Arthour Bohort and Ban Wiþ alle her wi?t compainie O?ain to bataile þai gun hei?e, Merlin tofore so seyt þe boke Wiþ baner feld al þat he tok. Arthour smot þe king Clarel Bitven þe schulder and þe hatrel Þat schulder and side and flaunke also Wiþ his swerd he smot ato, He was wroþ ?e schul here wite For Merlin hadde him atwite He hadde iuel ?olden þe kisseinge Þat Gvenour him ?af at his arminge Þerfore he tohewe þat route Tofore biside and al about, Al wondred þat him sei?e an And seyd he worþ a noble man. Þo knewe he þurth mani on Wher þat rod þe king Rion Þurth corouns and berdes þat were his armes, He made him way wiþ strengþe of armes His stede him bar to him anon Arthour smot to king Rion A quarter of his helme out hitt And his scheld ato ykitt And alle his armes verrament To þe purpoint, of o serpent, Next his schert þat sat þo Elles he hadde him coruen ato, Rion fel doun wiþ þat dent So he dede were verrament; Mani geauntes gret and long About Rion þer were and strong Þat on Arthour at ones last And wiþ her hors to grounde him dast Ac Arthour lepe vp afot anon And werd him o?ain euerichon. Merlin wist of þis dede And hete al Arthours felawered Wenden swiþe to þis rideing, Tofore dassed Ban þe king Al þat in his way stode He biheueded hem and lete hem blode So þat þurth his mi?t gode Þider he com þer Arthour stode ‘Arthour’ he seyd ‘þi kinde it nis To stond o fot forsoþe ywis’— An geaunt he tok anon And cleued him to þe brest-bon And brou?t on hors Arthour ywis Par for[s] among his enemis, Þat so þo dede verrament Þat non no mi?t stond his dent. Þo Arthour was vp so y finde Comen his felawes vi þousinde And ich of hem on þer hitt Oþer heued of smot or bodi þurth kitt, Þer was defoiled king Rion Vnder stedes fet mani on And drawe and totore vilainliche Ac he him defended orpedliche, Wiþ gret pine naþelas Vp to hors couered he was And smot wiþ mace al about And mani slou? of our rout; Ac an fewe of our best In al þat pres togider þrest, Arthour and Ban and Bohort his amis Naciens and Agraueins and Heruis Lucans Griflet Vlfin and Kay And her feren so fou?ten þat day Þat in þe cuntre ran heþen blod So in þe riuer doþ þe flod And so fou?ten wiþ dintes hard Þat felled was king Rion standard And þe four olyfaunce yslawe Baners and castels adoun yþrawe. Þo flei?e Riones folk here and ter Non durst leue nowher Ac king Rion þan was so wo Þat nist what he mi?t do, Wiþ his swerd scharp and bri?t XX Cristen he slou? doun ri?t Ac his men þat were him midde Wiþ strengþe oway wiþ him ride Ac fram his men he dassed sone Bi a wode oway alone Makeand ful sikerly Swiþe michel diol and cri. Swiche noyse ros in þe bataile Þat þei it hadde þondred saun faile No schuld men it yhere Þe paiens made so rewely bere, And our gred ‘Sle! Lay on! Kepe þere! Kepe here! Lete passe non!’ Þus þai slou? in litel stounde Mani þousand to þe grounde And euer þai ben tohewe and smite So schepe þat were wiþ wolues ybite. Leodegan and Cleodalis his steward Folwed al on Goionard Riones nevou þat hadde wiþ him Fele Sarra?ins wroþ and grim, Ban and Bohort vertuous Þai todriuen four kinges orgulous Þat hete Gloiant and Minados Calufer and Sinargos, Þe oþer and þo of þe table rounde Bi v, bi vi of gret mounde Were departed her and tar To folwe þe paiens eueraywhar, Naciens Adrageins and ek Herui VI heþen kinges driuen hardi Þat hete Mautaile and Fernicans Bantrines and Kehamans Forcoars and Troimadac Forto ?euen hem her mat; Alone certes king Arthour Drof king Rion wiþ gret vigour. Arthour otok him wiþ drawe sward And seyd ‘A?eld þe now traitour coward!’ Arthour on þe helme him smot Þe dent sanke þurth God it wot, Þurth þe pelet to þe panne Ac dedli dent no hadde he nanne, Rion o?ain smot a dent Ac Arthour him couered verrament Of his scheld he carf a corner And of his helme a quarter, Þe dint swarf and flei forbi Þerfore was non sori; Arthour smot o?ainward Vnder Riones scheld a dint hard And smot Rion þurth armes alle Þurth þe side nei?e to þe ?alle, King Rion so feld him hert And gan fle ful swiþe cert, Arthour wald after sue Ac sex king gun on him hewe Wiche y nemde tofore ?ou to Þat Herui drof and his feren also, Þai grad ‘Abide traitour!’ on hei?e ‘Wroþerh[a]le þou Rion sei?e!’ Þo lete Arthour Rion scape. Kehenans com wiþ gret rape And ?af king Arthour swiche a las Þat Arthour al astoned was, Arthour smot þat geant o?an A dint þat fro main cam He smot his schulder, wiþ arm and scheld Þat it flei?e in þe feld, Kehenans dede his stede forþ steppe And king Arthour wald bicleppe About his swere wiþ his ri?t arm Þat þe oþer mi?t don him harm Ac bitven his hond and elbowe Arthour him ?aue a dint of howe Wiþ his swerd, þat his hond Amidward þe feld wond; Þe stede him bar here and tere Criand so wode he were Ac sone þerafter ded doun he þrewe His soule to þe Deuel blewe. Þe oþer dasched on Arthour al fiue Forto reuen him his liue Ac Arthour king Ferican smot To þe hert God it wot, Forcoars bi þe side he hitt Þat ribbes and þi he of slit. Þo com Naciens Herui and Adragein Rideand to Arthour wiþ gret main, Wiþ his to feren king Mautaile Fram Arthour gan swiþe fle, Arthour wiþ his feren þo li?t Her hors girten and sadles ri?t. Now seiþ here þis romans Of king Bohort and king Bans, So driuen king Minados Wiþ his þre feren of proude los Þai metten wiþ ten heþen kni?tes Strong geauntes fel and wi?t Alle þritten þai smiten þo On our Cristen kinges to And perced boþe scheld and armes And dede hem wel gret harmes, Ac Ban hit king Calufer And cleued his heued into þe swere After he tok so Sinargos His heued fram þe bodi was los, Bohort hit king Glorion His ri?t schulder anouenon Þat al þe schulder and ek þe scheld Wiþ þe ribbes flei?e in þe feld. Sornigrens and Pinnogras Gaidon and king Margaras Wiþ vii heþen sikerliche Ban asailed wodeliche, Ac Ban so noble kni?t and hende Wi?tliche gan him defende Pinogras he feld of hors And foiled al his cursed cors Sornigrens he smot wiþ main Þurthout helme into þe brain. King Bohort sei?e his broþer fi?t Alon o?ain ten kni?t, Þe stede wiþ þe spors he dust To þe grounde a paien he frust Anoþer þurth helme and bacin Þurthout he clef him to þe chin; Þo þre paines wiþ wi?t bones On þe helme him smiten at ones Þat he nei hadde wiþouten balaunce Ylorn hors and contenaunce Ac he akeuered wiþ hert li?t And smiten hem on wiþ main wi?t. Ac in þat ich toilinge Fram Arthour com Rion þe king Fleand, his sw[erd ydrawe], Folio 254A is missing. [sir Antour] And Kay and Griflet and Lucan And Meraugis and Craddoc and Gernan And Belchin þe broun and Bleoberiis And Galescounde and Lectargis Kalogreuant and Kehedins Folweden and slowen þe Sarra?ins Her and ter so seyt þe boke, And a compeinie oftoke To hundred paiens ful of grame For her ler and for her schame And for king Rion was oway Her hert was ful of ten and tray; Ich on oþer þer gan smite Wiþ swerdes egge þat sore gan bite, Þai weren arwe and our hardy And hem todriuen sikerly, And wenten o?ain to Danbleys And wiþouten þe gates iuel at ayse Bileueden þer for her king Forto han of him tiding. Þai no hadde of Merlin no conseiling For he was went wiþouten lesing After king Galat of mi?ti hond Lord-ouer of herdene lond, Wiþ ten þousand þat was aschape Sarra?ins wiþ gret rape Forto make enchauntement Hem tofore verrament He made alle a valaye Also it were a brod leye Þat Galaþ no non of his Þat ni?t no mi?t oway ywis— Herafter sone in þis write Whi he it dede ?e schul it wite. Now telleþ þis romaunce þat king Arthour Com driueand gode scour And bar Marandois in his hond Worþ al þe swerdes of Inglond Þat he hadde of Rion wonne, He bad þe King þat made sonne For his swete moder loue He most þat ni?t his swerd proue; Auentours to seke his stede he smot, King Ban rode after God it wot Bohort also and Nacien Herui de Riuel and Adragein And com dasseand al bi cas Whar Goionar and Salinas Wiþ a kni?t of þe table rounde To lix bataile founde. Þese four smot on hem certes So þe lyoun doþ on þe hertes, Arthour tau?t on a lessoun of howe And cleued him to þe sadel-bowe, Anoþer he biheueded, þe þridde he hit Vnto þe girdel he him slit, Þe ferþ he tok on þe chine And carf him ato bi line, Ten forsoþe in litel þrawe Þer he brou?t o liue-dawe Wiþ his swerd Marandoise Þat carf doun ri?t wiþouten noise. King Ban smot about also And cleued a geant atvo, Anoþer he schare of al þe side Þe þridde he dede of þe heued glide And biheueded þre oþer þerto And þe seuend he smot ato; And Bohort boþe þi and arm Schare of [on] and dede him harm, Anoþer he cleued to þe toþ Þe þridde he biheueded forsoþ, Þe ferþ and fift also To helle-grounde he de[de] hem go. Þe gode kni?t Adragein Þurth hem smot on wiþ gret main, Anoþer he cleued to þe brest And of þe þridde þe heued he daste, Þus he binam þer fiue Al arowe day o liue. Nacien dede ful wel Wiþ scharp swerd of broun stiel On he cleued doun ri?t And anoþer þerto apli?t, Þe þridde to þe brest he cleued And of þe ferþe þe heued of weued And þre also þerto he slou?. Herui also it made tou? To þe chine he on slitt And of to þe heued of kitt. Goiomar and Balinas And þe þridde þat wiþ hem was Sei?en her noble socour And leyden on wiþ gret vigour Ich of hem þo orpedeliche Four slou? sikerliche, Þo þan leued þer bot ni?e Of al þat iche companie And þo flowen anon ri?t Also swiþe so þai mi?t Gredeand it ner non men Ac deuelen þat þai fou?ten o?en. Our hem suwed as men kene Til þai herden michel dene Boþe on helmes and ysen hatten Þe dintes of swordes flatten, Þo seyd Ban ‘We moten heye, Al ni?t and wiþ swerd d[r]ie.’ Quaþ king Arthour ‘Þat haue y l[e]ue Al what ichaue mi swerd proued,’ Quaþ Ban ‘?e no haue it nou?t deleid Þat ?e no haue it wele aseyd,’ ‘Nay sir’ quaþ Arthour ‘þat folk was lite Þat y no mi?t to wille smite And, to ek þat, ?e slou? so fele Þat half no mi?t y me bistere.’ Þo seyden our oþer hem bitvene, Most he libben and ythen Bitvene Breteine and Costentinenoble No worþ anoþer kni?t so noble. Now seyt þe boke þat sir Antore Wiþ his feren y nemd bifore At Danebleise Arthour þai no founde O?ain þai went in þat stounde Wiþ drawen swerd to sechen him, An hundred geauntes wroþ and grim Wiþ fauchouns and wiþ swerdes stett— Ich oþer sone mett. Antore was feld among þat floc And Gornain and Gales þe calu and Craddoc And Blioberis and Beichardis, Þat hem defended afot ywis And bi help of her feren seuen O?ain an hundred—þat was vneuen. Arthour com rideinde in þis cas, For sir Antour desmaied was He smot amidward þe pres So grehounde doþ out of les, A geaunt sone he tok, anne, Þurthout helme and heued-panne And þurth þe side and þe hert, Of anoþer þe heued he girt ?ete he tok þe þridde And cleued him to þe midde, In þe swere he toke þe ferþ Þat þe heued flei?e to þe erþe, Fiue and sex seuen and ei?te O rawe he bisei?e so ri?t, Þo gan king Arthour Maru[n]dois His swerd to king Ban praise And seyd it carf so wel men mi?t delite Þat witeþ þe geaunce of þis smite; Hem fiue afot on hors he lift. King Ban aside glift On a paien wiþ main he girt Þurthout þe heued into þe hert, Anoþer he schar þe side of Þe þridde þe heued he al todrof Þus her and tar he leyd adoun So it were a wode lyoun. Bohort als a geaunt laiste And þe heued al todaiste Anoþer to þe chine he karf Þe þridde he hit þat he starf, Al abouten he leyd on And slou? to grounde mani on. Adragein wiþ wille fre Arawe biheueded geauntes þre And oþer mo feld to grounde Þat neuer more ner sounde, Þe gode kni?t also Herui Slou? so fele it was ferly, Nacien so seyt þe boke Of a geaunt þat heued he tok Anoþer to þe chine he lu?ste Þe schulder of þe þridde he du?ste. Þus þai laiden her and tar And her heuedes fram þe bodi schar, Þe xii feren þat hye þer founde Non no hadde dedli wounde Ac þo þai sei?en þis fair socour Þai laiden on wiþ gret vigour Ich of hem þre oþer to Of þe paiens biheueded þo. Þer was noble main ysene, Of an hundred wiþouten wene No leued paiens bot fourtene (Þe oþer lay dede opon þe grene) And þe xiiii flowen swiþe So her stedes mi?ten driue; Our sueden wiþ wille fin, And metten þe clerk Merlin Þat hem wiþstode and dede hem li?t Her stedes girten her sadles ri?t, So þai dede and blisse made Ich of oþers helpe was glade. Whiles hye hem graiþeþ resteþ and ri?teþ Listneþ hou Leodegan fi?teþ— Hou Leodegan now vnder an oke Fi?teþ so seiþ þis boke Wiþ his steward Cleodalis Gentil kni?t and trewe ywis, O?ain seuen and tventi fou?ten hye to Certes þat was michel wo; On fot was Cleodalis So ich ?ou seyd er þis Leodegan on his hors was Cleodalis fau?t on þe gras, Wiþ michel sorwe and gret pine Þai werd hem o?ain þo Sarra?ine. Colocaulnus an hoge man Smot so to Leodegan Þat he aplat fel of his stede Boþe mouþe and nose gan blede, For feblenis of oþer wounde Strei?t he lay on þe grounde; Þe Sarra?ins to him come And þo him wold han ynome Ac Cleodalis herof nam kepe He bistride his lord and wepe, Abouten he leyd wiþ his sword And defended his lord So he smot to his wiþþerwine Þat non mi?t his lord winne, Þai him þrewe wiþ kniues and stones And ?auen him woundes for þe nones. Vp stirt Leodegan þe king Þo passed was his swoninge, His steward mi?t stond vnneþe For he him forfau?t al to deþe, He sei?e his steward so ful of treuþe His hert was ful of sorwe and reuþe He biþou?t him, wiþ wrong His wiif he hadde helden long O?aines ri?t þurth iniquite, A word he seyd of gret pite ‘Hay’ he seyd ‘Cleodalis Trewe kni?t wiþouten feintis Þurth mi sinne and mi desray Icham comen to mi last day; Haue on me pite gentil man And rewe on me Leodegan, Ich was þi lord now am y knaue On me pite and merci haue For?iue me now þe trespas Þat y þe haue don allas, Y pray þe þat neuer mi misdede Mi soule into helle lede.’ A-knowe he sat and seyd ‘Merci! Mine owen swerd take bel ami Mine heued smite of for mi misdede, Crist me wil þe better rede.’ Cleodalis wepe for pite He sei?e his lord humilite He lift him vp in his arm And for?af him al þat harm Þat he him hadde don and schame And bad him fi?t on Godes name, So þai deden and fou?ten boþe Þe paiens þerof weren wroþe. Þo com rideand a geaunt ywis And smot to grounde Cleodalis Þer he lay strei?t along Leodegan to him sprong And him wered al about Fram al þat ich curssed route, So long he fau?t he was weri And fel adoun wel dreri; Cleodalis þo vp made astert As he nere nou?t yhert And wiþ main fair and hende His lord-king he gan defende. Þus þai ferd oft, when fel þat on Þe oþer vp stert þo anon And him defended wiþ alle his mi?t; Þus þai fou?ten til midni?t Þo were þai wounded so strong Þat þai no mi?t doure long, To Cleodalis þo seyd Leodegan ‘Help now þeself gentil man For to lese and winne al þis lond Y no may lenger stond’ (Often þai made dounfalleing And when þai mi?t vpriseing), And halp Cleodalis him to were and fi?t Also wele so he mi?t. In þis time hadde Merlin To Arthour and Ban teld her pine, And þo hadde Leodegan ben ynome ?if Arthour no had ycome Wiþ his sextene þat on hem plat And euerich a paien to deþ flat, Merlin rode out in a stounde And þider brou?t xii of þe table rounde Þat dede wiþ strengþe her swerd baþen In bodi and blod of þe haþen, King Arthour and Bohort and Ban Keuered on hors Leodegan And Nacien þat kni?t of pris On hors keuered Cleodalis, Þat also wele yfou?ten cert So þai ner þat day yhert. Merlin he[m] tau?t to four geauntes saun fail Þat sustend þat bataile, Naciens rod Ancalnus to Þe side he schar his bodi fro, Arthour cleued king Maulas And Ban ato girt king Ridras, Bohort biheueded king Dorilan And ich of þe oþer slou? a paien þan. Þe oþer paiens flowe swiþe And our went o?ain biliue Into þe cite of Carohaise, Wiþ her feren hem made at aise, Þai maden gret blis and fest And after ?eden hem to rest.
